name: Aruba
notes_H1: "ORANJESTAD – In connection with the COVID-19 pandemic, the Department of Public Health launched its website www.arubacovid19.org. The website provides: Information on the latest developments on the COVID-19; Decisions and instructions by the government to contain the spread of the virus and to flatten the curve; Ads and video’s on precautionary measures you can take to protect yourself and others against the coronavirus". Retrieved from: /web/20200406202057/https://www.overheid.aw/news/news_47033/item/department-of-public-health-launched-its-website-for-coronavirus-updates_48638.html
notes_C7: No data found
notes_E2: No evidence found of measures in place to freeze financial obligations.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210114030731/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#A
notes_C2: As of Feb 5 bars and rum shops are closed  "The Aruba government has also implemented additional island-wide measures to further maintain the health and safety of visitors.     Curfew in effect extended until further notice:  Curfew starting at 12:00am until 5:00am   All establishments are required to close by 11:00pm at the latest. This is not applicable to establishments on hotel properties but is applicable to hotel casinos. Please check with your specific hotel for more information on closing times.    Prohibition of public gatherings: Between 7pm and 5am it is not allowed to gather in public spaces such as parking lots and on beaches. A maximum of 4 persons can be together.    Tables at restaurants can have a maximum of 4 seats inside or 6 seats outside (excluding children under the age of 12). Tables must be at least 1.5 meters apart.     All bars, rum shops, and nightclubs are closed until further notice. Restaurant bars can serve at tables only. There will be no bar stools and no standing at bars.    Hotel bars can serve at the bar only to registered hotel guests.    Musical entertainment and dancing at restaurants etc.: Only 1 musician allowed. No dancing allowed.   Yachts/boats: No more than 4 persons at one time on board. This is not applicable to commercial vessels such as charter boats/catamarans which are allowed to operate at a maximum of 50% of capacity.    Sports: contact sports not allowed; other sports allowed with a limit of 25 persons outside or 10 persons inside. No spectator public allowed.  For any social / family gatherings, the maximum number of persons allowed are 10 (inside) and 25 (outside). No dancing allowed, all rules must be adhered to for social distancing and mask-wearing.    In shops/supermarkets the maximum allowed is 1 person per family, all rules must be adhered to for social distancing and mask-wearing. Compulsory to wear a mask also outside if social distancing of at least 1.5m is not possible."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210209002737/https://www.visitaruba.com/traveling-to-aruba/entry-requirements-and-visas/aruba-travel-restrictions-covid-19/
notes_H3: Statistics update daily.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210322211435/https://www.visitaruba.com/traveling-to-aruba/entry-requirements-and-visas/aruba-travel-restrictions-covid-19/
notes_E1: The Minister of Social Affairs and Labor announced on March 25, 2021 that the government will prolong FASE till the end of 2021 until TIO (Temporary Income Support) will come into effect.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210419162844/https://www.government.aw/news/news_47033/item/fase-is-prolonged-for-the-remainder-of-2021until-tio-comes-into-effect_56201.html
notes_C1: Schools will be reopening on Monday the 12th of April, schools must apply stricter measures; Hygiene measures, parents cannot enter the school premises, there cannot be physical contact between the teacher and the student, every student over the age of 13 must wear a mask on the school premises.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210424115438/https://www.arubacovid19.org/ddg-eng
notes_H7: Walk-in vaccination drive organized on 24 and 25 April 2021, in 4 centers across the island, for all people over 18 who have not yet been vaccinated.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210424120120/https://www.arubacovid19.org/post/vacunathon
notes_C3: Allowed but must be registered with the Bureau of Disaster Relief.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210516161328/https://www.arubacovid19.org/ddg-eng
notes_C8: Travel ban from South Africa, India and Brazil was lifted on 7 June 2021.  Border with Venezuela has been closed prior to the pandemic.    Residents of all countries with whom Aruba’s borders are open still need to take a molecular test 72 hours prior to departure and the results need to be uploaded no later than 12 hours prior to departure to Aruba. Any persons arriving without a negative result from a molecular COVID-19 test will be tested at the airport at their own expense, followed by a mandatory quarantine period of up to 24 hours in their accommodations while awaiting test results.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613135119/https://www.visitaruba.com/traveling-to-aruba/entry-requirements-and-visas/aruba-travel-restrictions-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613142033/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/489131/aruba-authorities-ease-covid-19-restrictions-as-of-june-10-update-27
notes_C4: Gathering bans are eliminated as of 9 June 2021. No limit in the number of people that can gather inside or outside, but social distancing protocols (1.5 meters distance) is still recommended.   There is no more limit in the number of people that can attend funerals.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613142717/https://www.arubacovid19.org/post/flexibilisacion-di-medidanan  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613141557/https://www.arubacovid19.org/ddg-eng
notes_C6: Specific recommendations are no longer in place. Social distancing is still recommended.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613142717/https://www.arubacovid19.org/post/flexibilisacion-di-medidanan  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613141557/https://www.arubacovid19.org/ddg-eng
notes_H6: From 9 June 2021, the use of masks is no longer obligatory, but it is recommended if you cannot maintain 1.5 meter of distance.  Establishments can still require the use of a mask in their establishment.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613141557/https://www.arubacovid19.org/ddg-eng
notes_H8: From 9 June 2021, no more specific recommendations for retirement homes are mentioned.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210613142717/https://www.arubacovid19.org/post/flexibilisacion-di-medidanan

name: Afghanistan
notes_H1: While journals like Lancet and official embassy websites of US and UK provide updated information on COVID-19 situation in Afghanistan, there seems to be no coordinated initiative by the Afghan government.
notes_H2: GOV.UK: 'If you’re in Afghanistan and displaying symptoms of coronavirus, you should seek medical advice while self-isolating. The advice from the Afghan Ministry of Public Health is that if you’re displaying symptoms, call 166 and they will guide you on what to do next. The advisors only speak Dari (press option 1) or Pashto (option 2). You should also contact your insurance or medical assistance company.'    https://archive.vn/l0FOt
notes_C7: 'There are only minor COVID-19 related restrictions on internal travel. Specific measures vary between provinces and domestic flights are operating on a limited basis.'    https://archive.vn/l0FOt
notes_E2: Since there are no new updates on this, this is coded to a 0 again (assuming this was a policy implemented in May only).
notes_C2: https://web.archive.org/web/20200606160220/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/344451/afghanistan-three-day-curfew-announced-in-kabul-during-eid-al-fitr-may-23-25  There is no policy in place after May 25.
notes_H3: Only older data are available of contact tracing, no refreshment since then.   "Afghanistan used 520 sentinel sites in all the 34 provinces in both public and private health facilities (11,13). In addition, active surveillance sites have been established in all border-crossings around the country and involvement of polio workers and rapid response teams (RRTs) used to expand contact tracing, sample collection, and risk communication in insecure areas"    "Volunteers – a network of around 60,000 people trained in vaccine-preventable disease surveillance, who will also orchestrate COVID-19 surveillance, contact tracing, diagnostics and quarantine duties."  http://web.archive.org/web/20210425162847/http://www.emro.who.int/emhj-volume-26-2020/volume-26-issue-12/early-responses-to-covid-19-in-afghanistan.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20210203035047/https://www.gavi.org/vaccineswork/how-can-fragile-countries-afghanistan-respond-covid-19
notes_C1: 'Afghanistan on Saturday (June 12) announced the nationwide closure of all educational institutions, amid surging coronavirus infections and deaths in the country.'    https://archive.vn/1N47E
notes_H7: A (Afghan security force members and doctors); D (other: journalists)  AstraZeneca    Note: i am adding a fourth "D" and calling it "others". Vaccinating journalists does not fit the given A/B/C rubric: "A- Key workers, B- Clinically vulnerable groups (non elderly), C- Elderly groups"    https://archive.vn/GJOHR#selection-2775.0-2790.0  Feb 23 2021  "Afghanistan officially launched its coronavirus vaccination program on Tuesday at an event held at the Presidential Palace. President Ashraf Ghani participated, along with officials from the Health Ministry and elsewhere.  In this first round, Afghan security force members, journalists and doctors received the vaccine.   The first stage of the vaccination in Afghanistan will start with 500,000 doses, President Ghani said at the event, adding that "efforts are underway to cover 40 percent of the population in the second round."   Recently, Afghanistan received 500,000 doses of AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccine from India. The vaccines were produced by the Serum Institute of India. "
notes_C3: Sport-and music events are under governmental suspension.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210511185131/https://konzuliszolgalat.kormany.hu/azsia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210320102003/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/afghanistan/coronavirus  http://web.archive.org/web/20210312120211/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/453336/afghanistan-officials-continue-ongoing-covid-19-measures-as-of-march-10-update-13
notes_C8: According to the UK foreign office:    "Everyone arriving in Afghanistan needs to have their temperature checked at the airport. If your temperature is high, the government will advise you to quarantine and will offer you medical attention at two hospitals in Kabul."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201120094516/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/afghanistan/entry-requirements
notes_C4: According to the IMF report, there are currently no restrictions on gatherings. See report, archived: http://web.archive.org/web/20200825172817/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C6: https://web.archive.org/web/20200606160220/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/344451/afghanistan-three-day-curfew-announced-in-kabul-during-eid-al-fitr-may-23-25  There is no measures after May 25.
notes_H6: "Everyone should wear a mask in public settings and when around people who don’t live in your household, especially when other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain.”  However, people do not ted to abide the rule.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210312120211/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/453336/afghanistan-officials-continue-ongoing-covid-19-measures-as-of-march-10-update-13  http://web.archive.org/web/20210511185131/https://konzuliszolgalat.kormany.hu/azsia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210522094839/https://community.apan.org/wg/ronna/afghanistan-coronavirus-covid-19/b/announcements/posts/yes-you-still-need-to-wear-a-mask
notes_H8: No evidence of policies aimed at the protection of the elderly as of Sep 15.    "Authorities continue to enforce restrictions across Afghanistan as of mid-September to curb the spread of coronavirus disease (COVID-19). Officials are allowing intercity and interstate travel. Social distancing measures remain in effect, with people required to stay at least 2 meters (6.5 feet) away from each other; people must also wear face coverings in public. Residents are allowed to participate in public recreational activities. Authorities are allowing some commercial venues to operate, including gyms, shopping centers, and swimming pools, though other facilities such as museums remain closed. Some schools have reopened. Private vehicles are allowed to travel with a maximum of four passengers. Public transport services have resumed. Regional variation is probable, dependent on local caseload. Additional measures may be introduced in the coming days to stem the spread of COVID-19."    https://archive.vn/qxUhZ
notes_C5: https://web.archive.org/web/20200606160220/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/344451/afghanistan-three-day-curfew-announced-in-kabul-during-eid-al-fitr-may-23-25

name: Angola
notes_H1: Angola has set-up a central COVID platform with current legal information about what is allowed, as well as statistics and new developments...    source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200715000000*/https://www.covid19.gov.ao/
notes_H2: Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Angola?  Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours?  Yes  RT-PCR testing for COVID is available at Luanda Medical Center (LMC), Sagrada Esperanca, Girassol, and Centralab clinics by appointment only.??Appointment requests should be made at least five days in advance of the date the test is needed.? The cost for the test varies between 120,000 and 187,500 kwanza.? If you would like the technician to come to your place of employment or home, there is an additional fee.  A serological (rapid) test can be obtained at the following clinics:  Luanda Medical Center, Sagrada Esperanca, Girassol, Mediag, Cligest, Centralab, and Cedil.? The cost for the rapid test varies between 19,000 and 50,000 kwanza.? There is an additional fee if the technician comes to your place of employment or home.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185655/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: Domestic flights between Luanda and the remainder of the country’s provinces resumed on September 14, 2020.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185655/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: No statement of national debt relief to be found
notes_C2: Public services operate nationwide from  8:00 a.m. to  3:00 p.m., with 75% of the workforce. The public services of port, airport and related services, customs offices, defense and security bodies, health services, electronic communications services, media, energy, water, waste collection and educational establishments, may operate with their full workforce. Restaurants and similar continue to operate every day between 6:00 am and 9:00 pm and  their occupancy should not exceed 50% of capacity. No more than 4 persons may be seated at a table and counter service and self-service are not allowed.   Nightlife clubs is prohibited.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510043733/https://governo.gov.ao/fotos/frontend_1/gov_documentos/diario_republica_62_de_9_de_abril_17630932006076bb2a2941b.pdf
notes_E1: Cannot find any evidence of further income support beyond last update.
notes_C1: Pre-school establishments reopened as of 5th April. Primary schools, secondary schools, and universities are permitted to hold in-person classes as of 10th Feb 2021    https://web.archive.org/web/20210512053011/https://www.angop.ao/en/noticias/educacao/alunos-do-pre-escolar-retomam-no-pais/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210512060558/https://www.lexlink.eu/FileGet.aspx?FileId=3026356
notes_H7: Anyone over 18 years of age can register for a vaccine.    Astrazeneca    https://archive.vn/NQKJi
notes_C3: Religious activities are limited to four days a week with no more than 50 percent capacity or 150 people and are limited to a maximum duration of 2 hours if held in enclosed spaces.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307205259/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: The Angolan government has instituted mandatory home quarantine for anyone entering the country, regardless of citizenship.    Angola has banned entry to arrivals from Brazil and India, with exceptions for Angolan nationals and those with residence permits who must go into mandatory quarantine on arrival at a government facility.    https://archive.vn/NQKJi  https://archive.vn/jzNV5
notes_C4: Museums and monuments, cultural and art fairs, libraries, and media centers are limited to 50% capacity. Religious gatherings limited to 100 people.  https://archive.vn/NQKJi
notes_C6: Citizens must refrain from circulating in public spaces and roads and must remain at home, especially between 10:00 pm and 5:00 am, except for necessary and unavoidable travel.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210510043733/https://governo.gov.ao/fotos/frontend_1/gov_documentos/diario_republica_62_de_9_de_abril_17630932006076bb2a2941b.pdf
notes_H6: Face masks are compulsory in all areas outside of home or hotel room, including in private motor vehicles.    https://archive.vn/So4HR
notes_H8: No mention of extra protections for elderly people beyond the restrictions.    https://archive.vn/NQKJi  https://archive.vn/So4HR
notes_C5: Health centers and hospitals are fully operational.  Restaurants are open Monday to Friday from 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. for table service, and from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. for takeout and delivery.  Restaurants are closed for table service on Saturdays and Sundays, but open for takeout and delivery until 8:00 p.m.  In person dining is limited to 50 percent capacity with no more than four guests per table.? Stores, including supermarkets, can remain open until 6:00 p.m.? Museums and monuments, movie theaters, cultural and art fairs, libraries, and media centers are open but limited to 50 percent capacity.? Religious activities are limited to four days a week with no more than 50 percent capacity or 150 people and are limited to a maximum duration of 2 hours if held in enclosed spaces.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210604185655/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Albania
notes_H1: On May 3, the Minister of Health appealed to citizens to continue to respect the established measures, despite the controlled epidemiological situation.  "An appeal to all citizens not to neglect the observance of the measures, distance measures, hygiene and the placement of the mask everywhere in open and closed environments, are mandatory measures for all citizens". See Ministry of Health and Social Protection website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210507163810/https://shendetesia.gov.al/vijon-vaksinimi-masiv-manastirliu-kete-jave-mberrijne-mbi-11-mije-vaksina-pfizer-objektivi-i-ri-1-milion-vaksinime/
notes_H2: Generally available to anyone willing to get tested.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210606112307/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/
notes_C7: No restrictions on internal movement.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210527093259/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/
notes_E2: https://web.archive.org/web/20210323001340/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C2: Order no. 680- For closing bars, restaurants, fast food and restaurants  In the order no. 615, dated 9.11.2020, "On the closure of bars, restaurants, fast food and bars", as amended, the following change is made:  1. Item 1 3 The order is reworded as follows:  "Limiting the activity of bars, restaurants, fast food, bars that provide service to customers throughout the country, from 20:30 to 06:00 starting from 24.12.2020 until 04.01.2021."  This order enters into force immediately and takes effect on 24.12.2020. After the date 04.01.2021 the restriction of the activity of bars, restaurants, fast food, premises that provide service to customers throughout the country will be in the time range from 22:00 to 06:00 until a second order    https://web.archive.org/web/20210123122535/https://new.shendetesia.gov.al/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Urdher-Nr.680-1.pdf
notes_H3: Appears to have a comprehensive mechanism in place.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210103165123/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/albania/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Chapter
notes_E1: Support to salaries and firm liquidity: USD 100 million, through the instrument of a sovereign  guarantee, was allocated to companies that have difficulties in paying employee salaries. The  government will support businesses who stopped working due to the COVID-19 pandemic with a  benefit of not more than USD 14 000 by paying their employees the minimum wage, ALL 26 000.  The self-employed will also receive the same amount.    Median monthly salary in Albania is ALL 92, 300; Average salary as of Q4 2019 is ALL 53458 (http://web.archive.org/web/20201108183838/http://www.salaryexplorer.com/salary-survey.php?loc=3&loctype=1 ; https://web.archive.org/web/20200604191537/http://www.instat.gov.al/en/themes/labour-market-and-education/wages/publications/2019/wage-statistics-q4-2019/)    Coding All workers because of the point around 'self-employed'    https://web.archive.org/web/20200604183631/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Albania.pdf
notes_C1: On 05 may The Technical Committee of Experts determined that at the request of the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports, the opening of university auditoriums will be allowed only for the consultation process and exam period. The duration was not specified. See Ministry of Health and Social Protection, archived : https://web.archive.org/web/20210506183944/https:/shendetesia.gov.al/hiqet-karantina-me-greqine-dhe-maqedonine-e-veriut-manastirliu-ne-mbledhjen-e-komitetit-teknik-te-eksperteve-hapen-auditoret-e-universiteteve-per-konsultime-dhe-sezonin-e-provimeve/
notes_H7: A. the vaccination of all medical staff is expected to be completed within March 15.  C. Today we have opened the vaccination centre focused on Durres, we have started with the elderly +80.   Pfizer     https://web.archive.org/web/20210316092309/https://shendetesia.gov.al/fillon-vaksinimi-i-te-moshuarve-ne-durres-rama-manastirliu-brenda-mesit-te-marsit-perfundon-vaksinimi-i-stafeve-mjekesore-dhe-nis-vaksinimi-i-mesuesve/
notes_C3: On 8 March, the Albanian Council of Ministers stopped all flights and ferries with quarantined areas of northern Italy until 3 April, halted all schools for two weeks, ordered cancellation of all large public gatherings, and asked sports federations to cancel scheduled matches.  Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200528143137/https://tvklan.al/ndalohen-fluturimet-me-10-destinacione-drejt-italise/ https://web.archive.org/web/20200528143219/https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-health-coronavirus-albania/albania-halts-schools-italy-flights-ferries-over-coronavirus-idUKKBN20W01E?il=0
notes_C8: There is no test or quarantine requirement when traveling to Albania. The quarantine requirement for travelers from Greece or Northern Macedonia was removed on 05-May-21.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210527093042/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-situation-in-albanien.html  and  https://web.archive.org/web/20210527095503/https://shendetesia.gov.al/hiqet-karantina-me-greqine-dhe-maqedonine-e-veriut-manastirliu-ne-mbledhjen-e-komitetit-teknik-te-eksperteve-hapen-auditoret-e-universiteteve-per-konsultime-dhe-sezonin-e-provimeve/
notes_C4: Gatherings are restricted to no more than 2 citizens - see: https://web.archive.org/web/20200427212500/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/
notes_C6: Public movement is restricted during the hours between 10:00pm and 6:00am; except for work reasons, health care emergencies, or urgent needs. e-Albania portal must be used for special permission to move during this time.  https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/ (Wayback Machine giving errors when saving)
notes_H6: Change found. As of June 1, 2021, wearing a mask outdoors is no longer mandatory. Wearing a mask indoors for any individual 11 years old and above continues to remain mandatory, Non-compliance with this rule may result in a fine up to 3,000 ALL.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210606112307/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/
notes_H8: On May 7, the Minister of Health reported continuing mass vaccination with a combined regime, for people over 60 and employees of critical services, including employees of tour operators to prepare the country for the summer season. See Ministry of Health and Social Protection website, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210507171227/https://shendetesia.gov.al/kemi-dale-nga-zona-e-kuqe-e-covid19-manastirliu-jep-lajmin-ne-kuvend-zgjerojme-vaksinimin-me-dozat-qe-vijne-cdo-jave-sipas-kontratave/
notes_C5: "Public transport and taxis are operating as normal." It no longer appears that the government is recommending any closure of public transport. Masks are required.     http://web.archive.org/web/20200817080741/https://al.usembassy.gov/updates_covid19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20200817080250/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/albania/staying-during-coronavirus

name: Andorra
notes_H1: The government's  website has regular updates. They also have a Twitter account with regular updates. As well as a Facebook account. Cannot find information about traditional media.    https://archive.vn/Z1BuN  https://archive.vn/Zp9l5
notes_H2: In addition to the diagnostic tests performed in labs, citizens can be tested for antigens in private pharmacies and laboratories. In this case, "the tests check if you are infected at that precise moment and have a shorter validity than the lab test, of one or two days" according to the Minister of Health. The advantage is that the result is known in a few minutes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201124035502/https://www.govern.ad/comunicats/item/12098-la-pressio-al-sistema-sanitari-baixa-arran-del-seguiment-per-part-de-la-ciutadania-de-les-mesures-decretades
notes_C7: No restrictions.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210517161740/https://visitandorra.com/en/covid-19-in-andorra/faq-how-to-get-to-and-travel-within-andorra/
notes_E2: No policies found.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210517180326/https://www.govern.ad/
notes_C2: Businesses--including shops, restaurants, and tourist accommodations--are open with strict social distancing and sanitary measures in place, as well as restrictions on capacity. Additional regulations apply to restaurants which are allowed to open for service from 11:30AM to 4:30PM and 7PM to midnight (takeaway service is allowed outside of these hours).    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210517120706/https://visitandorra.com/en/covid-19-in-andorra/
notes_H3: The portfolio holder recalled that the country's strategy is rapid screening - anyone suspected of having been in contact with the disease can ask for a diagnostic test on 821955 - and tracking. In this regard, he confirmed that about 300 diagnostic tests are currently being performed daily and the number of available trackers continues to increase and now exceeds one hundred.  https://web.archive.org/20200729111541/https://www.govern.ad/comunicats/item/11752-salut-realitza-300-proves-diagnostiques-diaries-per-cribrar-positius-per-la-covid-19
notes_E1: No policy change.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210607134921/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210607135011/https://www.govern.ad/mesures-economiques-laborals-i-socials

name: United Arab Emirates
notes_H1: the UAE launches a website dedicated to awareness of the COVID-19 crisis  http://archive.fo/9oRXW
notes_H2: Initially, you had to have symptoms and a travel history to be tested (https://gulfnews.com/uae/health/when-and-where-to-take-a-coronavirus-test-in-the-uae-1.70405120) and this is still stated as conditions on the Ministry of Health's website: https://www.mohap.gov.ae/en/AwarenessCenter/Pages/COVID-19.aspx. However, recently the UAE has been opening up a lot of drive through test centers and while priority is still given to certain segments, it seems the general public is now able to get tested by booking through an app or calling a hotline: https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.thenational.ae/uae/health/coronavirus-how-to-get-tested-in-the-uae-and-how-much-does-it-cost-1.1006284

notes_E2: Under directive from Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, banks have come together to offer relief to consumers. Among the relief offered:   • Retail loan customers placed on unpaid leave can ask their bank for a repayment holiday of up to three months with zero interest and fees.  • Customers with personal loans, car loans or mortgages can apply for a one-month repayment holiday with zero fees.  (https://web.archive.org/web/20200502084637/https://www.thenational.ae/business/money/how-your-bank-will-help-if-you-are-affected-by-covid-19-1.997187)

notes_H3: When did the UAE start contact tracing Covid-19 cases?  Since the very first four cases of coronavirus were detected in the Emirates in late January.  - exact date unknown therefore, coded as 1st February  https://web.archive.org/web/20200430175534/https://www.thenational.ae/uae/health/coronavirus-the-contact-tracing-method-explained-1.1004887
notes_C1: UAE: Ministry of Education allows the gradual return of students to schools  The Ministry of Education, in coordination with the Emirates schools establishment, announced that the gradual and phased return of regular learning is permitted for all academic levels in public schools and in the various emirates of the country, starting from February 14, 2021 until the end of the school year.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210319152758/https://gulfnews.com/uae/education/uae-ministry-of-education-allows-the-gradual-return-of-students-to-schools-1.1612332648321

"The vaccine is available for free at over 205 health centres in the country."     According to the interpretation guide, a 5 is coded " when the vaccine is available to everyone 16+ or 18+ and there is evidence that this is taking place on the ground." As such, I am coding as a 5.     Source: https://archive.vn/J2r1d    https://archive.vn/PfK4G
notes_C3: Beginning on February 2, "The Dubai Tourism has suspended all the entertainment permits issued in the emirate. This came after the authority detected more than 200 violations of safety guidelines and closed down around 20 establishments in three weeks."     https://web.archive.org/web/20210208140628/https://www.khaleejtimes.com/coronavirus-pandemic/dubai-covid-19-full-list-of-new-rules-for-travel-malls-hospitals
notes_C8: Ban on travel from India from the 23rd of April.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210425230518/https://covid19.ncema.gov.ae/en/News/List
notes_C4: In Abu Dhabi, "Up to 10 family members can gather together but they must wear face masks and remain at least two metres apart...Up to 20 people can attend funerals and mourning services while up to 10 can attend marriage ceremonies."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621143754/https://www.thenationalnews.com/uae/latest-covid-19-rules-in-dubai-and-abu-dhabi-what-you-need-to-know-1.1155777
notes_C6: UAE announced it would shorten the night time curfew bye two hours.  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-emirates/uae-to-shorten-covid-19-prevention-curfew-by-two-hours-idUSKBN23524U
notes_H6: During the COVID-19 pandemic, wearing masks in the UAE is mandatory for all in public places, public transportation or commercial centers, when walking outside in high-density public areas and in private transportation. However, on 31 May 2020, Dubai Government issued new guidelines under which certain people under certain situations would be exempted from wearing a mask even in public areas.       Individuals who have been exempted from wearing a face mask  The individuals have been exempted from wearing a face mask in public are:  children under six years of age  people of determination - those with cognitive, intellectual or sensory disorders or any impairments that prevent their ability to breathe or communicate, normally  those for whom masks can lead to sensory triggering (a medical report is needed to confirm the condition)  the individuals who require supplemental oxygen or have severe respiratory issues or have difficulty breathing with a mask (medical report is needed to confirm the condition).       Conditions under which masks can be removed  Masks can be removed under the following situations:  when driving alone, or with your family members  while eating or drinking in indoor and outdoor settings, that is at restaurants  when engaging in strenuous indoor and outdoor physical exercise  while being alone in a certain setting, like your office and no one is around  while undergoing specific treatments such as dental work, eyes, nose and throat examinations, and other treatments related to hair and beauty.     However, physical distancing must be observed at all times.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207160732/https://u.ae/en/information-and-services/justice-safety-and-the-law/handling-the-covid-19-outbreak/tips-to-stay-safe-from-covid-19
notes_H8: Workers that can do their jobs remotely, and those over 60 or with health conditions, must work from home.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207141756/https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/uae/abu-dhabi-brings-back-some-restrictions-to-curb-covid-19/articleshow/80723345.cms?from=mdr    advise people with chronic diseases and the elderly to not attend social events.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201004205829/https://u.ae/en/information-and-services/justice-safety-and-the-law/handling-the-covid-19-outbreak/guidelines-related-to-covid-19/safety-protocols-for-social-events

notes_H2: While Argentine government authorities may only test symptomatic patients, citizens may obtain COVID-19 tests at many private labs (diagnósticos/laboratorios). Appointments are generally required, citizens must pay for the cost of their own test.     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201009214732/https://ar.usembassy.gov/covid-19/
notes_C7: From October 25 to November 8, some provinces will be under ASPO (Aislamiento social, preventivo y obligatorio = Social, Preventive and Compulsory Isolation) and some others will be under DISPO (Distanciamiento Social, Preventivo y Obligatorio = Social, preventive and mandatory distancing). Under DISPO, internal movement is allowed.    Provinces under ASPO: City of Buenos Aires, Buenos Aires, Chaco, Chubut, Córdoba, La Rioja, Mendoza, Neuquén, Río Negro, Salta, San Luis, Santa Cruz, Santa Fe, Santiago del Estero, Tierra del Fuego and Tucumán.    Provinces under DISPO: Misiones, Corrientes, Formosa, Entre Ríos, Catamarca, Jujuy, La Pampa and San Juan.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201028220922/https://argentina.as.com/argentina/2020/10/25/actualidad/1603627708_473148.html

notes_E1: 495/5000  The Family Emergency Income (IFE) is established for informal workers and monotributistas, between 18 and 65 years old, with the highest degree of vulnerability, who in mid-April will collect $ 10,000 one-time, although it could be repeated in May if circumstances so require. merit.    The IFE joins the package of measures already in place that reach formal workers in the critical, informal, monotributistas, retired, pensioners, allowance beneficiaries and companies sectors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200603182807/https://www.argentina.gob.ar/noticias/covid-19-el-gobierno-implementara-el-ingreso-familiar-de-emergencia-ife-para-aliviar-la

notes_C6: 5th June    The Government of Argentina has announced that the national quarantine that began on March 20 has been extended through June 28, with greater restrictions in the greater Buenos Aires area under DNU 297/2020. President Alberto Fernández on Thursday night announced the extension of Argentina's mandatory lockdown in selected large cities, especially Buenos Aires and its surroundings, until June 28. Provincial and local authorities may request exceptions to isolation from personnel affected by certain activities and services” Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20200620154857/https://www.boletinoficial.gob.ar/detalleAviso/primera/228261/20200426    https://web.archive.org/web/20200622180219/https://ar.usembassy.gov/covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20200614231327/https://www.argentina.gob.ar/coronavirus/medidas-gobierno

name: Australia
notes_H1: 25th January- Information at ports after first cases confirmed, but no national campaign as yet. Information is on display at all major international ports around Australia, with instructions on what to do if travellers have symptoms or if symptoms develop.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200413093831/https://www.health.gov.au/ministers/the-hon-greg-hunt-mp/media/first-confirmed-case-of-novel-coronavirus-in-australia
notes_H2: Recommendation for testing if showing a symptom of coronavirus, or for other reasons such as working in a high-risk environment or if having received an organ transplant.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201106223200/https://www.health.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/2020/09/coronavirus-covid-19-guidance-for-people-tested-for-covid-19_0.pdf    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201117175657/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/what-you-need-to-know-about-coronavirus-covid-19
notes_C7: South Australia  The South Australian government COVID-19 website states that “If you have been in Regional Victoria (excluding Greater Melbourne and the City of Greater Bendigo) after 7.00 pm 26 May and entered South Australia before 7.45 pm 28 May 2021, you must:  get a COVID-19 test as soon as possible and quarantine until you receive a negative result.  get tested again on day 5 and day 13 after arrival. There is no requirement to quarantine after receiving a negative result in your first test, unless you have symptoms.  ”  This reaches threshold for a level 2 code.  South Australia has to the most stringent travel restrictions currently in place.  Therefore, change code to a 2T.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604110704/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/restrictions-and-responsibilities/travel-restrictions   https://web.archive.org/web/20210604111830/https://www.sahealth.sa.gov.au/wps/wcm/connect/public+content/sa+health+internet/conditions/infectious+diseases/covid-19/testing+and+tracing/contact+tracing
notes_E2: Western Australia: As documented in the note on the 26th March 2021  "According to The Western Australian Government website, and current as at 26th March 2021” “In response to COVID-19, the Western Australian Government implemented a moratorium on some evictions and all rent increases, under the Residential Tenancies (COVID-19 Response) Act 2020. The extended emergency period ends on 28 March 2021, which means that all the existing laws will stay in place until this date, after which the ordinary tenancy laws will apply again.”   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326102604/https://www.commerce.wa.gov.au/consumer-protection/residential-tenancies-covid-19-response"    The Western Australian Government website, current at 4th April 2021 now states that "The extended COVID-19 emergency period has ended, which means the ordinary tenancy laws under the Residential Tenancies Act 1987 (WA) apply again. "    Yes, if rent arrears have accrued during the emergency period, tenants experiencing financial hardship can apply for a grant of 75 per cent of the debt, up to $4,000, paid directly to their landlord. In return, the landlord and tenant must agree to enter into a lease agreement for at least six months beyond 29 March 2021. Visit the Residential Rent Relief Grant Scheme page for more information.  However, the moratorium on some evictions and all rent increases has now ceased.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210404084211/https://www.commerce.wa.gov.au/consumer-protection/residential-tenancies-covid-19-response       Due to this reduction in debt/contract relief within Western Australia, household debt/contract relief is no longer available (as a government policy response to COVID-19) across all Australian jurisdictions.  Therefore changed E2 code to 0.
notes_C2: As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, and in response to reducing levels of community transmission of COVID-19, restriction for both Greater Melbourne and the rest/regional Victoria were, overall/in general, relaxed from 11:59pm on Thursday 17 June 2021.      For Victoria The Workplace Directions (No. 33) come into force at 11.59pm 17 June 2021 and replace the Workplace Directions (No. 32).  These directions commence at 11:59:00pm on 17 June 2021 and end at 11:59:00pm on 24 June 2021.  Under these new directions no workplaces are required to close.  However, there are a range of restrictions on the operations of different workplaces.  For example:   Hospitality: “Open with COVIDSafe requirements: density quotient of one per two square metres. A hospitality venue can host up to 25 patrons before the density quotient apply. Electronic record keeping must be used.”   Retail: “Open with COVIDSafe requirements: density quotient of one per two square metres. Record keeping required where practical and electronic preferred.”  Full details available at links.   Therefore, change to a 1T code.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210618131254/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-06/210616%20-%20Table%20of%20Restrictions_2.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618130810/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Workplace%20Directions%20%28No%2033%29%20-%2017%20June%202021.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618131813/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-work
notes_H3: First case in Australia confirmed on 25 January 2020. Health Minister's announcement says contact tracing will be undertaken. https://web.archive.org/web/20200402211239/https://www.health.gov.au/ministers/the-hon-greg-hunt-mp/media/first-confirmed-case-of-novel-coronavirus-in-australia
notes_E1: According to the Australian Government Services Australia website, the "JobKeeper Payment stopped 28 March 2021."  and "The temporary Coronavirus Supplement, at a rate of $150 per fortnight, ended on 31 March 2021."    "working age payments increase by $50 per fortnight the income free area for certain income support payments, including JobSeeker Payment and Youth Allowance for job seekers, changes to $150 per fortnight"    There is no longer any income support available for Australian workers or unemployed people as a specific policy measure in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.        https://web.archive.org/web/20210404080426/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/subjects/getting-help-during-coronavirus-covid-19/payments-and-services-during-coronavirus/if-you-get-payment/im-job-seeker  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404080941/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/news/jobkeeper-payment-ends-28-march-2021  https://web.archive.org/web/20210313205942/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/subjects/getting-help-during-coronavirus-covid-19/payments-and-services-during-coronavirus/if-you-need-payment
notes_C1: As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website on the 9th June 2021 media release Victoria’s current restrictions were to be further eased from 11.59pm Thursday 10 June.    A statement from the Acting Premier of Victoria, also published on 9th June 2021, stated that “In good news for families, schools will be able to resume face-to-face learning for all students from Friday [11th June 2021].”  The Workplace Directions (No 32) also came into effect on 11:59:00am on 12 June 2021.  Schools and higher education are open for in person teaching/learning.  Nonetheless, these directions, in part impose a density requirement of one person per 4 square meters.  This applies, to the non-classroom/teaching spaces of child care services, schools, and higher education institutions.      “The density quotient does, however, still apply to office areas including shared spaces that form part of an office area, spaces such as lunchrooms, photocopier room, principal’s office, back of reception and resource rooms. The density quotient also applies to any publicly accessible areas (including in relation to a school, non-school senior secondary providers, or childcare or early childhood service, or higher education service), and any such publicly accessible areas that are subject to the signage requirements under subclause (20).”    Therefore, changed to a 1T code.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111828/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-3   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111735/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-update-victoria-9-june-2021   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617114259/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Workplace-Directions-%28No-32%29-10-June-2021.pdf
notes_H7: 5th May 2021 this code was changed from a 3G to a 4G.  This change was made in recognition that in addition to Key workers, Clinically vulnerable groups (non elderly), and Elderly groups - Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander adults over 55 were also able to access the vaccine.       The Hon Greg Hunt MP Minister for Health and Aged Care announced in a media release on 22nd March 2021 that "Today is a momentous day for Australia’s fight against COVID-19, with the rollout of Phase 1B of the Australian Government’s vaccination plan." ...  "Priority groups in Phase 1B include:    elderly adults aged 80 years and over  elderly adults aged 70 years and over  health care workers not vaccinated in Phase 1A  Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander adults over 55  adults with a specified medical condition  adults with a severe disability who have a specified underlying medical condition  critical and high risk workers including defence, police, fire, emergency services and meat processing."  The COVID-19 vaccine is free for everyone in Australia.    Both the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine and the Oxford/Astrazeneca vaccine are in use for phase 1B.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210326090223/https://www.health.gov.au/ministers/the-hon-greg-hunt-mp/media/phase-1b-covid-19-vaccination-rollout-begins   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326090708/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/when-will-i-get-a-covid-19-vaccine   https://web.archive.org/web/20210326090821/https://www.health.gov.au/initiatives-and-programs/covid-19-vaccines/getting-vaccinated-for-covid-19/which-covid-19-vaccine-will-i-receive
notes_C3: As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website on the 9th June 2021 media release Victoria’s current restrictions were to be further eased from 11.59pm Thursday 10 June.    The Stay Safe Directions (Metropolitan Melbourne) (No 2) also came into effect on 11:59:00am on 12 June 2021.  These directions commence at 11:59:00pm on 10 June 2021 and end at 11:59:00pm on 17 June 2021.  These Directions allow for public out door gatherings of up to 10 people within Metropolitan Melbourne.     Outdoor fixed seated entertainment: Open up to 50% of seated capacity up to a maximum of 100 people per venue. Density quotient of 1 person per 4sqm applies.  This could include open large open air sports stadiums.      Therefore, change to a 1T code.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111828/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-3   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111735/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-update-victoria-9-june-2021   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617121311/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Stay-Safe-Directions-%28Metropolitan-Melbourne%29-%28No-2%29-12-June-2021-%28signed%29.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210610152436/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-06/20210609%20Table%20of%20Restrictions.pdf

The entry ban takes effect from 9pm AEDT Friday, 20 March 2020, with exemptions only for Australian citizens, permanent residents and their immediate family, including spouses, legal guardians and dependants. Archived statement: https://web.archive.org/web/20200510205042/https://www.pm.gov.au/media/border-restrictions
notes_C4: From 6 PM on May 25, community transmission in Victoria has led to to new restrictions. There may be no more than five visitors to a home on any given day.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210525010125if_/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/additional-covidsafe-measures-keep-victorians-safe
notes_C6: As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website on the 9th June 2021 media release Victoria’s current restrictions were to be further eased from 11.59pm Thursday 10 June.    The Stay Safe Directions (Metropolitan Melbourne) (No 2) also came into effect on 11:59:00am on 12 June 2021.  These directions commence at 11:59:00pm on 10 June 2021 and end at 11:59:00pm on 17 June 2021.  These directions removed the stay at home order and allowed residents for Melbourne to leave home for any reason.  With some exceptions residents of Melbourne may not travel, for any reason, within a limit of 25km from place of primary residence.  No residents of Australia are currently subject to a stay at home order  Therefore, change to a 0 code.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111828/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-3   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617111735/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-update-victoria-9-june-2021   https://web.archive.org/web/20210617121311/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202106/Stay-Safe-Directions-%28Metropolitan-Melbourne%29-%28No-2%29-12-June-2021-%28signed%29.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210610152436/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-06/20210609%20Table%20of%20Restrictions.pdf
notes_H6: The acting Premier of Victoria, James Merlino, released a statement on the 27 May 2021 stating that “On the advice of our public health team, Victoria will move to circuit breaker restrictions from 11:59pm tonight. These settings will remain in place until 11:59pm on 3 June – but if we can end that sooner, we will.”  This tightening of restrictions is in response to growing community transmission of the B1.617.1 variant which escaped from Australia’s hotel quarantine system.   These new restrictions apply across the whole of the state of Victoria and, in part, are enforced by the Stay at Home Directions (Victoria).   These directions mean that Victorian’s over 12 years of age cannot leave their home without wearing a mask.  There are some exemptions for safety reasons or if it is necessary not to wear a mask in order to carry out your authorised work role.  Furthermore, if you are alone in a confined space wearing a mask is not required.  For example: an essential worker working alone in a closed office would not need to wear a mask.   Coded a 3 level as there are some exceptions and also those outside of the home, but alone in an enclosed space are not required to wear masks.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210528082124/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/covid-19-chief-health-officer-update   https://web.archive.org/web/20210528082326/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-acting-premier-1   https://web.archive.org/web/20210528021246/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202105/Stay%20at%20Home%20Directions%20%28Victoria%29%20-%2027%20May%202021%20%28signed%29.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210528083855/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-05/210527%20-%207%20Day%20Circuit%20Breaker%20Restrictions.pdf
notes_H8: As published on the Victorian Government COVID-19 website, and in response to reducing levels of community transmission of COVID-19, restriction for both Greater Melbourne and the rest/regional Victoria were, overall/in general, relaxed from 11:59pm on Thursday 17 June 2021.    However, according to the Victorian Government COVID-19 website highly stringent limitations on visitors to residential aged care facilitates across Victoria are maintained.     No visitors are permitted into aged care or other residential facility settings, except for end-of-life reasons and other excepted reasons such as essential care and support  Visit from a prospective resident is permitted with no more than one person accompanying  Non-essential contractors are restricted from entry    Therefore maintain 3T code.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618131254/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-06/210616%20-%20Table%20of%20Restrictions_2.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210618133116/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covidsafe-settings
notes_C5: 18 May  “Hundreds of thousands of Sydneysiders will have to give up their public transport commute and drive to the city under strict new social distancing measures announced by the NSW government. Capacity on trains, buses and ferries will be slashed, temporary car parking set up at Moore Park and six new pop-up cycleways rolled out across Sydney, Premier Gladys Berejiklian announced on Monday. Just 12 people will be allowed on a bus and 32 in a train carriage as the government works to maintain strict physical distancing of 1.5 metres on the network.  Trains will run at 24 per cent capacity and buses at 14 per cent for the foreseeable future, meaning Sydneysiders may be prevented from entering railway stations as they fill up or watch near-empty buses drive past their stops”  Source: http://archive.vn/zhhOo

notes_E1: New, expanded form of short-time work for companies that are economically affected by COVID-19 introduced in spring 2020.   From October 1, 2020, working hours can only be reduced by at least 20 and up to a maximum of 70 percent for the entire calculation period.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201103001533/https://www.bmafj.gv.at/Services/News/Coronavirus/FAQ--Kurzarbeit.html  https://archive.vn/EziNK
notes_C1: Schools remain in operation with shifts for some classes and other Covid restrictions.  “In contrast to schools, universities , technical colleges and private universities in particular are independent legal entities. Here it is the rectors' offices, course heads and other management bodies who autonomously determine what happens at their university."    COVID guidelines define four operating modes for universities or colleges.  The four risk levels of the Ministry of Health's corona traffic light - level 1 - low risk (green), level 2 - moderate-medium risk (yellow), level 3 - high risk (orange) and level 4 - very high risk (red).  The university or college modes: presence mode (green), dual mode (yellow), hybrid mode (orange) and distance mode (red). The operating modes do not always have to correlate with the risk levels. So there can be a moderate-medium risk and a university can still opt for hybrid or distance operation.     Some in-person courses are running where it is necessary for the course to take place. For example, an Ordinance of the Rectorate on the participation in face-to-face courses and face-to-face exams at the Art University Linz was released on the 26 April stipulating requirements for proving a negative test or a recovered status to access the university buildings (including studios and workshops) and take part in face-to-face classes.      Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210518072434/https://www.bmbwf.gv.at/Themen/HS-Uni/Aktuelles/corona/covid_19_leitfaden.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210519070939/https://www.ufg.at/Events-News.1899+M5f6f8cc19d0.0.html
notes_H7: The proportion of people vaccinated now suggests a broader implementation in place and Phase 3 underway in all states.    Source: https://archive.vn/IrOp5.
notes_C3: To take part in public events the 3G rule applies (11 people or more) – rather like the Green Pass system in Israel (though specifics are different).    Concise version from sozialministerium.at  •  Events are now regulated under the term "meetings":  •  Meetings of less than 10 people are permitted without notification or approval.  •  The 3-G rule applies to 11 people or more, and a report to the local health authority is required. In addition, an FFP 2 mask must be worn both indoors and outdoors. The serving of beverages and the serving of food are not permitted. This rule applies to weddings, garden parties, and similar events.  •  From 51 people, only events with assigned seats are permitted. These must be approved by the local health authority. The maximum limits are 1,500 people indoors and 3,000 outdoors. 50 % of the seat capacity may be occupied      Further detail from the Corona-Ampel nationwide restrictions    In general:  •  Meetings of less than 10 people are permitted without notification or approval.  •  The 3-G rule applies to 11 people or more, and a report to the local health authority is required. In addition, an FFP2 mask must be worn both indoors and outdoors. The serving of beverages and the serving of food are not permitted. This rule applies to weddings, garden parties, and similar events.  •  From 51 people, only events with assigned seats are permitted. These must be approved by the local health authority. The maximum limits are 1,500 people indoors and 3,000 outdoors. 50% of the seat capacity may be occupied.  •  The following applies to weddings: Civil weddings are not regulated by the ordinance and are therefore permitted under the conditions of the respective house rules. Religious events are excluded from the ordinance, so denominational weddings may take place under the conditions of the respective house rules. Wedding celebrations on the usual scale are currently not possible. A maximum of 50 people are allowed to participate. The minimum distance of 2 meters to people who do not live in the same household must be observed and an FFP2 mask must be worn. However, no food or drinks may be given.  •  The following applies to funerals: A distance of at least two meters must be maintained from people who do not live in the same household. The number of people is not limited. An FFP2 mask is compulsory indoors, it is recommended outdoors.  •  The following applies to demonstrations: As before, demonstrations as assemblies are also permitted under the VersG. The minimum distance of 2 meters to people who do not live in the same household and the FFP2 mask requirement still apply. In addition, there is an assembly law obligation to notify the authority.    Events in the context of extracurricular youth education and youth work are permitted under the following conditions:    •  Group size is a maximum of 20 people up to the age of 18 and a maximum of 4 carers.  •  May take place in closed rooms and outdoors.  •  The organizer has to develop and adhere to a mandatory prevention concept.  •  If the person responsible for the meeting implements a COVID-19 prevention concept, the minimum distance of two meters from people who do not live in the same household and the wearing of a mask can be omitted.    Sources:   https://archive.vn/QDpVD (Information about current measures from sozialministerium.at)   https://archive.vn/aCVvf#selection-2497.0-2509.66 (Corona-Ampel nationwide restrictions 19 May)   https://archive.vn/pm8rj [link to Vorarlberg added to avoid confusion about the state's rules which had been under eased opening programme]    ** June 2021 recoded to 2G as per request to show restrictions for those without 3G evidence

notes_C4: From October 23, the following rules/measures go into effect:  - No more than six people are allowed to attend indoor meetings (outside of work), such as yoga courses, birthday parties, and weddings. Funerals are exempt from this order.  - Outdoor meetings are limited to 12 people. No further restrictions apply. At restaurants, the maximum number of people at a table is limited to six.  Link: https://archive.vn/zpRsC
notes_C6: Requirement restricting movement between 8pm to 6am ended 15 May.  People are free now to leave their homes at anytime. Limitations on meeting are to be introduced in the opening regulations to be introduced on Wednesday 19 May.    Sources:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210516122935/https://www.ris.bka.gv.at/Dokumente/BgblAuth/BGBLA_2021_II_206/BGBLA_2021_II_206.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210516123212/https://www.ris.bka.gv.at/GeltendeFassung.wxe?Abfrage=Bundesnormen&Gesetzesnummer=20011470
notes_H6: "No changes to the requirement to wear the mask indoors. There is no mask requirement outdoors."    "The requirement to wear a mask outdoors is largely not applicable. An FFP2 mask (or mask of the same or higher quality) without an exhalation valve must be worn in public, closed rooms"    Sources:  https://archive.vn/u3azj [showing planned restrictions]  https://archive.vn/bG4Mg [current measures as of 10 June]  https://archive.vn/xTG5b [nationwide measures as of 10 June]
notes_H8: For protection in hospitals and sanatoriums as well as in old people's and nursing homes, employees in the respective facilities - depending on availability - have to present a negative PCR or antigen test result every week or alternatively have to wear an adequate respirator at all times. Operators have to implement appropriate prevention concepts based on the risk analysis and the state of the art.    Visits are only allowed every 2 days up to and including November 17: a maximum of 1 visitor per resident per day, and a maximum of 2 people within the specified period. Visitors must either show a negative test result or wear an adequate respirator. The minimum distance must be observed and mouth and nose protection must be worn. The palliative and hospice care as well as pastoral care for critical life events is excluded. External, non-medical service providers are prohibited from entering retirement and nursing homes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201101015224/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html
notes_C5: In general public transport and other means of transportation are running as normal. The minimum distance must be observed on public transport and on the plane. Mouth and nose protection is mandatory. It is also mandatory to wear mouth and nose protection in underground stations, platforms, stops, train stations and airports as well as their connecting structures. Carpooling, taxis and taxi-like operations can still be used if only two people are transported in each row of seats, including the driver. This also applies to training trips, such as driving schools. Mouth and nose protection is mandatory. Cable cars may not be used for leisure purposes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109211208/https://www.sozialministerium.at/Informationen-zum-Coronavirus/Coronavirus---Aktuelle-Ma%C3%9Fnahmen.html

name: Azerbaijan
notes_H1: 'Operational Headquarters' set up by Government under the Cabinet of Ministers to "prevent danger that the coronavirus pandemic could cause, to implement prophylactic and urgent measures." Other aims are to "regularly inform the population about the situation". (https://nk.gov.az/az/article/680/)
notes_H2: Testing of anyone with COVID-19 symptoms. Testing appears to be concentrated in the district of Baku. Passengers arriving from abroad require a negative COVID-19 test, in response to which there are several laboratories where passengers can be tested 'without a doctor's appointment' (From Source 1, linked).    More detail: 'Testing is based on the WHO case definition and includes either a patient with acute respiratory illness (fever and at least one sign/symptom of respiratory disease (e.g., cough, shortness of breath), AND with no other etiology that fully explains the clinical presentation AND a history of travel to or residence in a country/area or territory reporting local transmission of COVID-19 during the 14 days prior to symptom onset, or a patient with any acute respiratory illness AND having been in contact with a confirmed or probable COVID-19 case in the last 14 days prior to onset of symptoms; or a patient with severe acute respiratory infection (fever and at least one sign/symptom of respiratory disease (e.g., cough, shortness breath) AND requiring hospitalization AND with no other etiology that fully explains the clinical presentation.' (From Source 1, linked)    For a list of laboratories and clinics where passengers can be tested, see Source 2 (linked).    'COVID-19 testing is available in Baku. Individuals are responsible for the entire cost of COVID-19 tests and the cost is in the range of 100 AZN.' (From Source 3, linked)    Source 1: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405185523/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/azerbaijan/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Section  Source 2: https://web.archive.org/web/20210320012208/https://www.azal.az/en/information/covid-clinics   Source 3: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405185940/https://az.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-for-azerbaijan/

notes_H2: First two people test positive for COVID-19 in Burundi:         http://web.archive.org/web/20200416094548/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/burundi-confirms-first-2-covid-19-cases/1787083     NB Both individuals had returned from abroad, but it is unclear whether this was a necessary criterion to be tested.
notes_E2: per the IMF, Taxes owed will be forgiven for hotels and industries that will not be able to pay. Subsidies are planned to help pay salaries in these sectors and avoid massive layoffs. Salaries for suspended government services such as those provided at the Melchior Ndadaye International Airport continue to be paid by the government: https://web.archive.org/web/20210419144716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C2: Nightclubs are noted as being closed since early April, perhaps earlier. Capturing in April to coincide with the article dating. https://web.archive.org/web/20210419144022/https://rtnb.bi/fr/art.php?idapi=5%2F0%2F241
notes_H3: none mentioned- https://web.archive.org/web/20210404073207/https://bi.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_E1: per the IMF, In addition to spending on the pandemic response plan, the authorities are providing support to hard-hit sectors such as the transport and hotel sectors.: https://web.archive.org/web/20210419144716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C1: Public schools have remained open as well.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207205721/https://bi.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: 72 hour into Burundi - https://web.archive.org/web/20210404073207/https://bi.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: There was no national lock down and it has been businesses as normal in many areas of society.  For example, soccer matches have continued, as have large-scale group exercises, parties, weddings, and other activities.  Burundians have stopped hugging and shaking hands to some extent, and many public venues have handwashing stations installed. https://archive.vn/yxS66#selection-2661.309-2661.654
notes_H6: Country-Specific Information:    The situation in Burundi with regard to COVID-19 has remained relatively stable throughout the pandemic as compared with other countries in the region. Social distancing and masks are encouraged but not enforced by law and large gatherings can be seen particularly with family, religious and cultural events. There was no national lock down and it has been businesses as normal in many areas of society.  For example, soccer matches have continued, as have large-scale group exercises, parties, weddings, and other activities.  Burundians have stopped hugging and shaking hands to some extent, and many public venues have handwashing stations installed. Overall, stores have continued to be fairly well-stocked, with the exception of imported fresh produce, which was affected slightly due to the interruption of commercial flights, while locally grown produce remains largely available. Public schools have remained open as well.  Melchior Ndadaye International airport reopened on November 8, 2020.    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322080552/https://bi.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Belgium
notes_H1: Belgian government launches Coronavirus information homepage, starts daily messaging on twitter and Facebook; https://web.archive.org/web/20200430193034/https://twitter.com/SanteBelgique/status/1223259642928590848
notes_H2: Tests available for people exhibiting symptoms age 6 and older, people who have come in contact with someone who has coronavirus, and travelers who have been abroad for more than 48 hours. Self-tests are available to buy in pharmacies.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210419091326/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/testing/    https://archive.vn/DQP02
notes_C7: The measures taken in certain coastal towns ended on 12 August 2020.  (http://web.archive.org/web/20200813063839/https://www.tijd.be/politiek-economie/belgie/algemeen/dagjestoeristen-vanaf-woensdag-weer-welkom-in-knokke-heist/10244578.html)    Moving to "0" as the recommendation made by the governor of the province of Antwerp on 28 July 2020 has not been repeated since and are not documented on an official government web-site.
notes_E2: ***Recoded from 2 to 1.     Limited measures for households in place, see below. However, most of the previous coding seems to draw on debt/contract relief for businesses. When looking at whats solely applicable to households, it doesn't meet the threshold of a 2.     A suspension of debt servicing to banks and insurers by households and companies affected by the crisis until end-June 2021, respectively.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210122230822/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#B    Flemish government:     Registration and inheritance tax: extension of deadlines to comply with tax obligations until 31 January 2021 (declaration of inheritance, registration of act, conditions of favorable regimes)    Flexibility in judging requests for payment plans    Walloon government:     Inheritance tax and registration duties: suspension of the deadlines to comply with tax obligations (filing, payment, conditions of favorable regimes, procedure)    Brussels government:     The abolition of the regional City Tax for 2020    https://archive.vn/7nRno
notes_C2: •	Non-essential stores are open again, under strict hygiene conditions  •	Hairdressers, restaurants and bars remain closed    https://archive.vn/sek2R    https://archive.vn/4pm3D
notes_H3: Note that contact tracing is handled by the regions.    H3 is set to 2 as of 18 May 2020 because:  -As of 11 May 2020 contact tracing has been fully operational in Flanders.  -As of 18 May 2020 contact tracing is operational in Wallonia:  "405 call center agents and 21 call center supervisors as well as 135 field agents and 8 field supervisors were recruited."  (http://web.archive.org/web/20200806150003/https://www.wallonie.be/fr/tracing)    However the press regularly comments about that the capacity is insufficient.  From a press article in "The Bulletin" of 20 May 2020:  "Since their work officially began on 11 May, Belgium's contact tracers have managed to get in touch by telephone with about 60% of people who have recently tested positive for coronavirus."   (see http://web.archive.org/web/20200530160643/https://www.thebulletin.be/coronavirus-how-does-belgiums-contact-tracing-operation-work)
notes_E1: •	Full-time employees are entitled to 70% of the (possibly capped) salary, regardless of the family situation.  •	The self-employed can also benefit from support regarding their social security contributions in the form of a reduction, delay or exemption of payment. If you are obliged to interrupt or stop your activity because of the crisis you can apply for a replacement income.  •	Walloon:  Taxpayers will benefit from a suspension of the tax payment deadlines during the crisis. Deadlines for claims against assessment will be frozen.    https://archive.vn/8a0RE
notes_C1: On 19 April, as seen below:  - Nursery education, primary education, special needs secondary education, the first stage of secondary education and the system of ‘learning and working’: full-time face-to-face education;  - 2nd and 3rd stage of secondary education: 50% face-to-face education;  - Higher Education: physical presence on campus 1 day/week.    Exams can take place in person.    If the infection rates evolve favourably and after an assessment by the Ministers of Education which will be submitted to the Consultative Committee, full-time secondary education can resume from 3 May.    https://archive.vn/j5zVc
notes_H7: Brussels is currently vaccinating  everyone born in or before 2003.(18 years and above). https://archive.vn/RabqC   Wallonia - Vaccination against Covid-19 concerns only the adult public (+ 18 years old). Young people aged 16-17 can be vaccinated from 07/01/2021. https://archive.vn/Sa4Yd    Vaccines available -  BioNTech/Pfizer, Moderna, Oxford/AstraZeneca, Johnson & Johnson.     6,031,553 persons i.e. 52.48% of the population  have been given at least one dose.  https://archive.vn/Z6VES
notes_C3: The Consultative Committee also confirmed the previous decisions relating to the culture and events sectors as from May. This includes major events such as cultural and other performances, competitions and trade fairs. As such, outdoor activities for up to 50 people are allowed during the month of May. In addition, a series of indoor test events will be organised.  https://archive.vn/NjstO    Events or shows such as theatre, professional sports competitions or concerts are now allowed for a maximum of 50people. This is only allowed outside. https://archive.vn/31N70     Brussels - The public events are allowed outdoors with a maximum of 50 participants. https://archive.vn/h95WD
notes_C8: The travel ban on non-essential travel within the European Union expired on 19 April. Travel to Belgium is permitted, however, it is strongly discouraged for persons having the nationality or the main residence in a country of the EU or the Schengen zone, as well as to persons having their main residence in a third country listed as   Australia: green  New Zealand: green  Rwanda: green  Singapore: green  South Korea: green  Thailand: green    All other third countries are to be given a red colour and only essential travel is permitted for these countries.    https://archive.vn/j5zVc and https://archive.vn/iiDqj
notes_C4: At the federal level the social bubble has been restricted to 5 people, fixed for the next 4 weeks: "A family may allow five more people into its social bubble for the next four weeks, not including children. And above all: that bubble should remain the same for the next four weeks."  (http://web.archive.org/web/20200729105618/https://www.standaard.be/cnt/dmf20200729_91848859)    C4=4G is chosen as a family of e.g. 2 people can only meet with 5 other fixed people implying a restriction on gatherings of fewer than 10 people.    Gatherings of up to a maximum 10 people are possible in case social distancing / face masks are used.
notes_C6: Curfew is lifted from May 8.  Work from home policy remains in place.     "Effective May 8, authorities will lift the nation's nightly curfew; however, gatherings of more than three people will be prohibited between the hours of 00:01-05:00."     http://web.archive.org/web/20210508091649/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/476161/belgium-authorities-to-lift-covid-19-related-curfew-and-certain-other-restrictions-from-may-8-update-35
notes_H6: ***Recoded from 3G to 3T; previous coding only referenced policy in Brussels but this appears to be a national policy. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210212210057/https://www.politico.eu/article/belgium-coronavirus-lockdown-rules-restrictions-overview/
notes_H8: On 27 April, the Walloon Government subsequently announced the conditions for visits in the care homes for elderly persons. The visitor will have to bring his or her own surgical mask, the distance rules must be observed and it will be strictly forbidden to hand objects directly to residents.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200722131458/https://fra.europa.eu/sites/default/files/fra_uploads/be_report_on_coronavirus_pandemic-_may_2020.pdf
notes_C5: Restrictions on public transports are eased from 19th April . https://archive.vn/5Edum

notes_E2: In order to respond quickly to the COVID-19 pandemic, World Bank support is being provided in three phases: (i) in the short term, saving lives; (ii) in the medium term, protecting livelihoods; and (iii) in the long term, preparing for the future. To that end, on December 15, 2020 the World Bank approved financing for budget support to address the health crisis and for the Local Development and Resilience Project —in the amount of $100 million and $350 million, respectively—all designed to ensure resilient economic growth. Other projects have also been restructured to ensure the continuity of public services and support vulnerable households and the country’s economic program.  ---------  https://web.archive.org/web/20210606153410/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/burkinafaso/overview
