name: Barbados
notes_H1: There is a coordinated public campaign in effect.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210524013606/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/
notes_H2: "The Ministry of Health and Wellness continues to appeal to members of the public to get tested for the COVID-19 virus whether they believe that   they are symptomatic or not." As per the sources, "PCR tests are available at government facilities for no charge."      https://web.archive.org/web/20210403100508/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/health-ministry-get-tested-for-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210403102203/https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel  http://web.archive.org/web/20210524015025/https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: No evidence of a policy change.  "Banks are now working with individual borrowers as needed on further repayment extensions."  source:  https://archive.vn/bZZSM
notes_C2: Bars and restaurants are allowed to operate at 50 per cent of the capacity but nightclubs, theatres and cinemas shall remain   closed.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210423135046/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/limited-curfew-among-new-covid-19-rules/
notes_H3: "The Ministry has initiated the process of contact tracing to identify every individual who came in close contact with all cases and will quarantine such persons for 14 days. They will also be tested for COVID-19 if they become symptomatic."  Archived Source: /web/20200402230214/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/two-new-covid-19-cases-in-barbados/
notes_E1: There is no change in this policy.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402214146/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/further-support-for-adopt-our-families-programme/
notes_C1: The Government has planned "The Trinity term was initially set to begin on Tuesday, April 20, with Class Three and Class Four students, preparing for the Common Entrance Examination, and Fifth and Sixth Form students, doing Caribbean Examinations Council (CXC) examinations, returning to physical school plants. Other year groups would be working online" but schools have been preventing to reopen for presential learning due to the ash   fall from the La Soufriere volcano."The Barbados Community College’s (BCC) Hospitality Institute, because of its small student roll, will reopen for   face-to-face instruction on Monday, April 19, once the all-clear is given."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423131218/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/ash-fall-delays-start-of-trinity-term/
notes_H7: Health and Wellness Minister Lieutenant Colonel Jeffrey Bostic is urging all Barbadians to take the vaccine. Reminding parents, teachers and the entire country that taking the vaccine would allow the country to be able to reach herd immunity.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210510190438/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/take-covid-19-vaccine-says-health-minister/
notes_C3: From January 2nd until January 14th, no person shall host or attend:  a party;  (b) a recreational or competitive sporting event;  (c) a banquet, ball, dance or reception;  (d) a meeting of a fraternal society, private or social club or   civic association or organization;  (e) the social event known as  (i) "a bus crawl"; or  (ii) "a lime";  (f) a karaoke event;  (g) a picnic; or  (h) a bus or other vehicular excursion  source:  https://archive.vn/kOBRg
notes_C8: Barbados Ministry of Tourism’s updated travel protocols came into effect on August 3rd.   These protocols state that “persons from High-Risk countries with a valid negative COVID-19 PCR test result will be quarantined at a designated holding hotel or approved villa at their own expense, or free of charge at a government facility, and will be monitored daily for the onset of symptoms. These persons will be quarantined for a period of 14 days with an option to take a second COVID-19 PCR test between 5-7 days after the last test accepted by the Ministry of Health and Wellness. Persons will typically be released once the test result is negative.” “High-Risk: Includes USA, Brazil, India, Mexico, Argentina, Peru, Colombia, South Africa, Indonesia, Philippines and Russia.”  Countries not classified as High-Risk, unless within the “Bubble”, which includes “Saint Lucia, St. Kitts & Nevis, Grenada, Dominica and St. Vincent & The Grenadines”, are required to take a COVID-19 PCR test prior to or on arrival.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200830211314/https://www.visitbarbados.org/covid-19-travel-guidelines-2020
notes_C4: Meetings of civic associations, private or social clubs, and other organizations may resume as long as participants follow protocols on mask-wearing, social distancing, and sanitization. Such gatherings are limited to 100 people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210620224323/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/487736/barbados-authorities-modify-and-extend-existing-covid-19-restrictions-through-june-27-update-30
notes_C6: Curfew in place between midnight and 5 am beginning on December 31st.  source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210103175958/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/download/emergency-management-covid-19-protocol-no-4-amendment/
notes_H6: Wearing facemasks remains mandatory in all public spaces. https://archive.vn/Lg3ZX  No person shall, without reasonable explanation, be in a public building or public place; or travel on a public service vehicle or other public transport, whether as a driver, conductor or passenger unless he wears a face mask, face shield or face-covering which covers his mouth, nose and chin.  For the purposes of this Directive, “public building” or “public place” includes a building or a place to which members of the public have a general or conditional right of access. https://archive.vn/WrB3e and https://archive.vn/zWgFX
notes_H8: First mention of a policy or measures for the protection of elderly in relation to Covid-19:  No more than 1 person at a time should visit a patient in a nursing home or senior citizens’ home    https://archive.vn/Tw3wF  https://1drv.ms/b/s!AjvFoN9mD2CwkZd19yyJawSWTntmaw?e=LFQ9GY
notes_C5: Public transportation is operating. Masks are required for public transportation and taxis. https://web.archive.org/web/20210614191523/https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

name: Brunei
notes_H1: The Ministry of Health has a website with all relevant information on Coronavirus. It also brings statements to the population often.  Campaign website: /web/20200404203230/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/COVID-19.aspx  According to this source, campaign started on January 6: /web/20200404203313/https://sites.google.com/site/weechiankoh/home/Covid-19
notes_H2: Information from Ministry on Health on general charges for RT-PCR tests for citizen or foreign travelers, effective August 14, 2020.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201219023333/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/Swab%20charges_website_14082020.pdf
notes_C7: Members of the public are still required to comply with physical distancing guidelines even when businesses and public services return to full operations.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200729111541/https://thescoop.co/2020/07/23/brunei-proceeds-to-final-phase-of-de-escalation-plan-on-july-27/
notes_E2: Deferment measures have expired. See the International Monetary Fund's section on Brunei, last updated April 2, 2021.    See IMF's website, archived at http://web.archive.org/web/20210406210001/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C2: From 17th August 2020 onwards, Cinemas will proceed to the third stage of reopening, operating at 80 percent of its full capacity compared to 60 percent in the second phase, and children will be allowed to go to cinemas. Cinemagoers must be kept one seat apart but family members can sit together.  Buffet restaurants will reopen, however only restaurant employees who wear protective face masks can serve food to the patrons. There is no capacity limit for dine-in at restaurants, cafés and food courts since the fourth phase of de-escalation plan took effect.  indoor and outdoor playgrounds as well as game arcades can operate at 60 percent of their normal capacity.  Museums, exhibition galleries and public libraries will also move to the final stage of reopening, hosting a maximum number of 100 people at a time as opposed to the previous 70 people.  For senior citizen centres, attendance is capped at 80 percent at a specific time – an increase from 60 percent.  Under the third phase of de-escalation plan, swimming pools are allowed to operate every day with no age restrictions and can accommodate 80 percent of its total capacity.  Visitors of swimming pools can use the facilities up to two hours a day.  The ministry has also increased the number of people allowed to train for team sports from 10 to 15 people.  Special needs centres and childcare facilities will be able to resume full operations next Monday as part of the fourth phase of de-escalation plan, said the minister of culture, youth and sports. Children of all ages can return to childcare centres, except those who display flu symptoms such as fever or are at high risk of developing a severe infection.  Special needs centres are also open to all, excluding those with chronic diseases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200817154003/https://thescoop.co/2020/08/13/govt-announces-further-easing-of-covid-19-curbs/
notes_H3: It is also a legal requirement for all visitors and residents in Brunei to use the contact-tracing app BruHealth every time they enter/exit a public place. https://web.archive.org/web/20201025200552/https://thescoop.co/2020/10/23/coronavirus-one-new-imported-case-but-no-local-transmission-for-169-days/
notes_E1: No Income support provided as of now, it was provided until June 2020  Refer to:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200425202332/https://thescoop.co/2020/03/13/covid-19-live-updates/
notes_C1: All schools, including tertiary education institutions, can resume the “normal academic term” in the final phase of reopening from July 27, the education minister said.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200729111541/https://thescoop.co/2020/07/23/brunei-proceeds-to-final-phase-of-de-escalation-plan-on-july-27/
notes_H7: (Frontline workers [Sinopharm]; senior citizens aged 60 and above [Oxford-AstraZeneca, Sinopharm]; students studying abroad [Sinopharm])    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    There has been no announcements as to whether the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine drive for the general public has been extended beyond its 29th May enddate.    There are no major updates, except "students who will be pursuing / continuing their studies abroad that they can reserve COVID-19 vaccine injection slots through the Bruhealth app commencing on Tuesday, 01 June 2021". Additionally, the elderly (aged 60 and above) are encouraged to get their vaccines.    See:  The Ministry of Health's press release on COVID-19 VACCINE for students continuing their studies abroad (dated 30 May), archived at https://archive.vn/E8gRc  The Ministry of Health's press release on encouraging COVID-19 VACCINE For The Elderly 60 Years And Over (dated 01 Jun), archived at https://archive.vn/SZA4z
notes_C3: Six types of premises will be allowed to reopen on May 16, including restaurants, gyms and sports facilities, driving schools as well as stalls and markets as part of the government’s “de-escalation plan” to ease coronavirus restrictions. While eateries, markets and sports facilities are now allowed to reopen, they are only permitted host 30 percent of their capacity at any one time.  /web/20200521022736/https://thescoop.co/2020/05/01/covid-19-live-updates-3/
notes_C8: Moving the code from 2 to 4, as entry into Brunei remains severely limited for foreigners from all countries, including Singapore (which has a Reciprocal Green Lane' agreement with Brunei - however, visitors from Singapore are only allowed in on essential business trips and via the same Entry Travel Pass requirements imposed on all other foreigners) except those entering for essential purposes (see Entry Travel Pass requirements).    Per the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Singapore's travel advisory,    "The Bruneian government has imposed an entry ban on all foreign visitors (non-Brunei citizens/non-Brunei permanent residents), including transit passengers, from 24 March 2020 until further notice. Foreign visitors seeking to enter Brunei must receive prior approval from the Brunei Department of Immigration and National Registration."    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 5 Mar, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.  Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Minister’s Office for the latest information.  Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Minister’s Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Minister’s Office.  Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.    Per the Ministry of Health,   From 20 March 2020, all passengers arriving in Brunei Darussalam  through any points of entry are required to undergo mandatory selfisolation for 14 days at a government-designated facility immediately  upon arrival to the country.  i) Self-isolation at private homes are not permitted.  ii) This include all visitors and foreign workers arriving in the  country.  iii) All foreign nationals including foreign workers arriving in the  country are required to bear fully the cost of mandatory selfisolation (including accommodation and meals) and laboratory  test for SARS-CoV-2 ($1000 per test).  iv) Foreign workers must submit special entry application for foreign  workers before arriving in Brunei Darussalam.     Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  • Essential business travel (including official travel)  • Students  • Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  • Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See Ministry of Foreign Affairs Singapore's travel advisory, archived at https://archive.vn/pQ2MH  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/fnAPh  See the Ministry of Health's guidelines on travel, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/mpd9geybded3b1h/BRN-undated-Guidelines_Travel.pdf  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf
notes_C4: On 13th August 2020, the Government raised the limit of people at public and social gatherings from 100 to 200 people at a time.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200817154003/https://thescoop.co/2020/08/13/govt-announces-further-easing-of-covid-19-curbs/
notes_H6: “It is mandatory for those serving food, whether in fast food outlets or restaurants. They are the ones who should be using face masks.” Students it is recommended, and it will be mandatory during an outbreak in an area  https://web.archive.org/web/20200830144253/https://borneobulletin.com.bn/2020/06/face-masks-mandatory-for-food-servers-not-for-students/
notes_H8: Brunei Ministry of Health: "It is advisable for senior citizens and patients with chronic diseases to take extra precautions, such as avoiding crowded places and public transportation, in addition to daily precautionary measures."    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200330114345/http://moh.gov.bn:80/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx

name: Bhutan

From thereon out communicates daily on preventative measures, hence coded as 2G; https://web.archive.org/web/20200607161958/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086568319607&set=a.771480979580187  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607162003/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086571652940&set=a.771480979580187  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607162010/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086611652936&set=a.771480979580187  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607162017/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086654986265&set=a.771480979580187  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607162019/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086664986264&set=a.771480979580187  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607162416/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086748319589&set=a.771480979580187  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607162414/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086714986259&set=a.771480979580187
notes_H2: Officials are also performing random COVID-19 testing for travelers, students, teachers, transporters, and business personnel every two weeks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316112730/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/452441/bhutan-authorities-maintain-domestic-covid-19-restrictions-travel-controls-as-of-march-8-update-23
notes_C7: Inter-district travelers must register via the Check Post Management System. Prior approval is necessary for movement from any high-risk area to a low-risk one; travelers from any designated high-risk area must undergo a seven-day quarantine. Officials are also performing random COVID-19 testing for travelers, students, teachers, transporters, and business personnel every two weeks. Authorities may revise curbs at short notice.  Bhutan is banning all nonessential activity and movements in southern border districts as part of COVID-19 restrictions. Affected locations include Chukha, Dagana, Pemagatshel, Samdrup Jhongkar, Samtse, Sarpang, and Zhemgang. Other nationwide measures continue. Several recreational venues, such as movie theaters, dance clubs, and nightclubs, remain closed nationwide  http://web.archive.org/web/20210510174949/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/469156/bhutan-nonessential-activity-restricted-in-border-districts-as-of-april-20-due-to-covid-19-update-25
notes_E2: The Royal Monetary Authority (RMA) is working with the financial institutions to defer the loan repayment period and waive interest payments for three months. https://web.archive.org/web/20200607175452/https://www.royalkidu.bt/royal-address/index.html
notes_C2: Bhutan is banning all nonessential activity and movements in southern border districts as part of COVID-19 restrictions. Affected locations include Chukha, Dagana, Pemagatshel, Samdrup Jhongkar, Samtse, Sarpang, and Zhemgang. Other nationwide measures continue. Several recreational venues, such as movie theaters, dance clubs, and nightclubs, remain closed nationwide  http://web.archive.org/web/20210510174949/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/469156/bhutan-nonessential-activity-restricted-in-border-districts-as-of-april-20-due-to-covid-19-update-25
notes_H3: Contact tracing of the 76-year-old corona positive patient from the US was immediately set in place (on March 6), covering his itinerary including places visited and people he had associated with. https://web.archive.org/web/20200607153628/http://www.moh.gov.bt/third-batch-of-17-people-tested-negative/; https://web.archive.org/web/20200607153633/https://www.drukair.com.sg/news/covid-19-updates-bhutan-travel-announcement/
notes_E1: The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grant for individuals directly affected by the pandemic and full interest waiver on loans contracted since April 10, 2020 until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waiver will continue until March 2021.  Investments in GovTech is allowing Bhutan to reap benefits during COVID-19 including fast disbursement of cash relief funds.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208102716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  The Druk Gyalpo’s Relief Kidu was launched on 14 April 2020 to provide income support to individuals whose livelihoods were affected because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Between April and September 2020, Nu.1.2 billion was granted to over 33,000 beneficiaries and over 14,000 children.    The Relief Kidu has been extended for three months, from October to December 2020. Individuals who applied for or received Kidu in Phase I and/or Phase II need to re-apply for further assessments. Applications are also open to new applicants who have been displaced by the coronavirus pandemic.  Who is eligible?  Bhutanese who have been displaced by the coronavirus pandemic and are currently residing in Bhutan are eligible for the Druk Gyalpo’s Relief Kidu. The displaced group includes those who have been laid off, placed on unpaid leave or on reduced pay from businesses *** as well as self-employed individuals *** who have lost their earnings either partially or completely.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208103817/https://royalkidu.bt/
notes_C1: All southern border areas under lockdown the national Covid-19 task force decided to lock down all thromdes and satellite towns in southern border dzongkhags since last night. Movement of individuals and vehicles will be restricted in these areas. the second phase of the lockdown relaxation in Phuentsholing, which was supposed to begin today will not happen. Relaxation had started on May 5.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210510172605/https://kuenselonline.com/all-southern-border-areas-under-lockdown/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210510172704/https://kuenselonline.com/mass-testing-round-two-begins-in-pling-tomorrow/
notes_H7: Vaccine: Covishield  Roll-out plan updates: all citizens above 15 years' old are eligible for vaccine registration.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316113559/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/03-03-21-information-series-on-covid-19-vaccines-moh/
notes_C3: Essential gatherings of no more than 25 people can occur provided organizers obtain advance approval from authorities  http://web.archive.org/web/20210531144919/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/485206/bhutan-authorities-maintaining-controls-in-high-risk-areas-as-of-may-31-due-to-covid-19-activity-update-29
notes_C8: Travel RestrictionsBhutanese authorities continue to ban the entry of foreign nationals  http://web.archive.org/web/20210510174949/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/469156/bhutan-nonessential-activity-restricted-in-border-districts-as-of-april-20-due-to-covid-19-update-25

Affected locations include Chukha, Dagana, Pemagatshel, Samdrup Jhongkar, Samtse, Sarpang, and Zhemgang. Other nationwide measures continue. Several recreational venues, such as movie theaters, dance clubs, and nightclubs, remain closed nationwide  http://web.archive.org/web/20210510174949/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/469156/bhutan-nonessential-activity-restricted-in-border-districts-as-of-april-20-due-to-covid-19-update-25
notes_H6: The use of facemasks is compulsory in public places  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614170819/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/490106/bhutan-authorities-maintaining-controls-in-high-risk-areas-including-thimphu-as-of-june-14-due-to-covid-19-activity-update-30
notes_H8: On May 21st, the Bhutan government published the first "Guidance on Prevention & Control of COVID-19 in Elderly People"  to prevent the spread of COVID-19 infection to the elderly people (60 years and above). The guidance includes recommendations to health care workers to periodically conduct medical check-ups on all elderly people (~18% of the population of Bhutan) at home and to discourage "All elderly people [...] from visiting health facilities, unless it is an emergency or if they have regular appointments like Dialysis, Chemotherapy etc.." It also lists a number of recommendations to the elderly itself as well as to caregivers. As those recommendations include "staying home," "hygiene," and "visitor restrictions," this qualifies as a 1G.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210129193925/http://www.moh.gov.bt/wp-content/uploads/ict-files/2020/05/Guidance-on-Prevention-Control-of-COVID-19-in-Elderly-People-1st-edition-1.docx
notes_C5: Inter-district travelers must register via the Check Post Management System. Prior approval is necessary for movement from any high-risk area to a low-risk one; travelers from any designated high-risk area must undergo a seven-day quarantine. Officials are also conducting random COVID-19 testing for travelers, students, teachers, transporters, and business personnel every two weeks. Authorities may revise curbs at short notice.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210531144919/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/485206/bhutan-authorities-maintaining-controls-in-high-risk-areas-as-of-may-31-due-to-covid-19-activity-update-29

name: Botswana
notes_H1: Social media and gov communication providing information, phone number for public questions, and prevention strategies. https://www.facebook.com/OFFICIAL.MOHW.BW/
notes_H2: As of June 7, 2021, according to the U.S. Embassy in Botswana, antigen tests are available at the international airports and major land border crossings and testing centers around Botswana, and PCR tests are available at specific hospitals, laboratories, and lodges. Tests are readily available and are to be paid for by the patient.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032637/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: ”This means there shall be no movement of people from 7pm to 4am from December 24, 2020 to January 3, 2021,” declared Masisi.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210103222510/https://www.mmegi.bw/index.php?aid=88228&dir=2020%2Fdecember%2F23
notes_E2: Subsidy not in place.   “Households are under severe financial strain with wages in the tourism sector cut and the wage subsidy not in place to assist them,” said Dumelang Saleshando, leader of the opposition party, the Botswana Congress Party.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201108232046/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/botswana-extends-emergency-measures-to-combat-virus/2020/09/29/b62cda0e-0259-11eb-b92e-029676f9ebec_story.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20201108231653/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C2: Workplaces can reopen under sanitation and social distancing requirements.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201213214638/https://covid19portal.gov.bw/assistance-businesses
notes_H3: No change.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210531183943/https://covid19portal.gov.bw/sites/default/files/2020-05/COVID-19-Contact-Tracing-Guideline.pdf
notes_E1: No confirmed income support extending through June 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032704/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C1: Most businesses in the rest of the country have been able to resume and schools reopen, albeit under strict health protocols. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200821235638/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/369236/botswana-authorities-lift-lockdown-in-gaborone-august-13-update-12  The reopening of schools will mainly focus on finalists and candidate classes. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200822002029/https://observer.ug/news/headlines/66239-school-reopening-only-15-students-to-be-allowed-per-classroom
notes_H7: As of June 7, 2021, according to the U.S. Embassy in Botswana, Oxford University-AstraZeneca, Moderna, Sinovac, and Pfizer BioNTech have been approved for use. Janssen (Johnson&Johnson) and Gamaleya (Sputnik V) may be used in Botswana in the coming months.     The rollout planned through COVAX will provide 100,800 vaccines for the country. 24,000 AstraZeneca doses have been delivered according to COVAX. Botswana announced the delivery of an additional 38,400 AstraZeneca doses from COVAX.  The Government of Botswana reports 30,000 Covishield vaccines from India were received in early March and 200,000 doses of Sinovac were delivered on April 25. 19,890 Pfizer doses were received through COVAX in early June.  Botswana began its vaccination campaign on March 26-7. They have opened vaccinations as of May 10 for those over 65, followed by those aged 55-64. They will prioritize those over 65 and those over 55 with underlying health conditions as more vaccines become available.  Persons over 18 may already register on the vaccine registration webpage for future availability as eligibility expands.  Government officials are being vaccinated, as confirmed on the government's Twitter.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032613/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032637/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613062420/https://dhis2sms.gov.bw/vaccine/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613053303/https://twitter.com/BWGovernment?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor
notes_C3: Informal public events prohibited, maximum 50 persons in meetings, societies, funerals, faith-based services etc.     State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf).
notes_C8: You must present proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test performed no more than 72 hours prior to your arrival. After arrival, you will have to remain in contact with the local health authority for a period of 14 days for self-monitoring.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210108155848/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/entry-requirements
notes_C4: As of June 7, 2021, according to the U.S. Embassy in Botswana, all gatherings are prohibited with a number of exceptions and restrictions:    Funerals – up to 50 people and no more than 2 hours  Religious services – up to 50 people and no more than 2 hours  Weddings – up to 4 including administrators  Cultural or traditional occasion – up to 16 people and no more than 2 hours  Meetings or workshops – up to 50 people and no more than 2 hours  All sports and recreational activities are suspended except national team events with no spectators.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032637/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: President Mokgweetsi Masisi on Wednesday evening announced a nationwide night curfew from December 24, 2020 to January 3, 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210103222510/https://www.mmegi.bw/index.php?aid=88228&dir=2020%2Fdecember%2F23
notes_H6: According to UK foreign travel advice, face coverings are requirements in accommodations, businesses, and public transportation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032613/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus
notes_H8: No measures specific to elderly people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613053303/https://twitter.com/BWGovernment?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613053756/https://covid19portal.gov.org.bw/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032637/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210613032613/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus
notes_C5: It appears that public transport is still running but that COVID-19 protocols must be adhered to public transport operators, such as not permitting anyone to use public transport without a face mask, cleaning the interior and exterior 2-3 times a day, and using hand sanitiser or washing hands etc.     See the press release from the Government, archived: http://archive.vn/WsNAi

name: Central African Republic
notes_H1: On the vigil of the campaign launch, President Touadéra on 19 May announced that a public health emergency will be declared and a number of measures taken to intensify efforts to contain the second COVID-19 wave. On 21 May, a coordinated public information campaign began for vaccination only.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210531174638/https://reliefweb.int/report/central-african-republic/central-african-republic-situation-report-28-may-2021
notes_H2: The Central African Republic’s authorities have adopted a response plan for the health sector and enacted social distancing measures, including the closing of borders, schools, and most public establishments, a ban on meetings of more than 15 people, and restrictions on the movement of people from Bangui.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200514181918/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    14 March 2020  WHO and the Ministry of Health and Population have already started raising awareness among the population on COVID-19, things to know, the importance of not giving in to panic and d '' observe the simple steps to prevent the disease, namely: wash your hands regularly with soap and water, cough or sneeze into the crease of the elbow or into a handkerchief to be thrown away immediately in a closed bin, keep a distance social at least one meter, avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth or call the alert number of the Ministry of Health and Population, 1212, to report suspected cases.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200515205656/https://www.afro.who.int/fr/news/la-republique-centrafricaine-rca-declare-un-premier-cas-de-covid-19    18 March 2020  A risk communication plan was developed for the Central African Republic.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200515204155/https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/331487/SITREP_COVID-19_WHOAFRO_20200318-eng.pdf    26 March 2020  An initial national prevention and response plan, focusing on public interventions was released in March and activities are ongoing. Prevention measures announced by the President on 26 March include the temporary but ongoing closure of schools, bars, airport and borders. School closures affect over 1,370,000 pupils.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200514103210/https://reliefweb.int/report/central-african-republic/unicef-central-african-republic-covid-19-situation-report-no-1-1-15    26 March 2020  Guidelines set forth by the government to contain the coronavirus range from systematic checks at border entry points and the self-isolation of passengers from countries at risk to mass communication initiatives and the prohibition of mass gatherings and movements.     Reinforcement measures were announced by the Head of State Faustin-Archange Touadera thereafter: limiting air traffic operations at the M’poko International Airport to a few commercial flights, humanitarian flights, cargo flights, aircrafts in difficulty and for technical stopovers without disembarkation; restrictions on the operation of educational establishments, places of recreation conducting mourning and marriage ceremonies; movement restrictions from Bangui to the provinces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200514185240/https://peacekeeping.un.org/en/covid-19-cases-grow-car-minusca-supports-government-urgent-response-to-halt-virus-spread    17 April 2020  The MINUSCA Rwanda Contingent has donated a COVID-19 screening device to the Central African Republic (CAR). The machine will accelerate testing of suspected cases of infection as the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in the country reached 94 over the past few days.  https://www.africanews.com/2020/05/09/coronavirus-rwanda-donates-covid-19-testing-device-to-central-african-republic-car-by-maria-kabatanya//    23 April 2020   The World Bank approved a grant of $7.5 million from the International Development Association (IDA)* to help the Central African Republic respond to the threat posed by the Coronavirus outbreak and strengthen national systems for public health preparedness.    The COVID-19 Preparedness and Response Project will provide immediate support to the Central African Republic to prevent the spread of COVID-19 through containment strategies and by strengthening the public health emergency response for a potential outbreak. The project will bring in essential medical supplies and drugs, testing kits, personal protective equipment for frontline health workers, and water and hygiene supplies for the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200514105511/https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2020/04/23/the-central-african-republic-to-strengthen-preparedness-and-response-to-coronavirus
notes_C7: no measures in place - barrier methods only are being used https://web.archive.org/web/20210531173041/https://reports.unocha.org/en/country/car

The first lot of 60,000 doses is reserved for frontline health personnel and vulnerable people aged 50 and above in greater Bangui, the epidemic’s hotspot, and will extend until 23 June. https://web.archive.org/web/20210531174638/https://reliefweb.int/report/central-african-republic/central-african-republic-situation-report-28-may-2021

CMHC will permit lenders to allow payment deferral beginning immediately."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200514161137/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/news/2020/03/canadas-covid-19-economic-response-plan-support-for-canadians-and-businesses.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20200514161242/https://www.cmhc-schl.gc.ca/en/finance-and-investing/mortgage-loan-insurance/the-resource/covid19-understanding-mortgage-payment-deferral
notes_C2: See note 5 April 2021.
notes_H3: On 6 November, Alberta Health focusses contact tracing on positive test cases who might have links to 3 priority settings -- schools, health care facilities, long-term care homes -- until contact tracing backlog cleared. See CAN_AB note for 6 November.
notes_E1: Initially coded by Femi Adebola. The Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy (CEWS) supports employers that are hardest hit by the pandemic, and protect the jobs Canadians depend on. The subsidy generally covers 75% of an employee's wages – up to $847 per week - for employers of all sizes and across all sectors who have suffered a drop in gross revenues of at least 15% in March, and 30% in April and May. The program will be in place for a 12-week period, from March 15 to June 6, 2020. Also, the Canadian government will provide a taxable benefit of $2,000 every 4 weeks for up to 16 weeks to eligible workers who have lost their income due to COVID-19 under the Canadian Emergency Response Benefit. (Recoded from 2A to 2F after 22 April 2021 discussion.) Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20200318220215/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/economic-response-plan.html
notes_C1: Department of Education Update - November 6, 2020  K-12 Schools  According to Nunavut’s Chief Public Health Officer, Sanikiluaq is now in Stage 4: Community Transmission of COVID-19 until further notice.  All schools in Sanikiluaq are closed to students, staff, and the public until further notice from the Chief Public Health Officer. All instruction in Sanikiluaq will be conducted remotely.  Teachers/school staff will be contacting their students and families as soon as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426195706/https://www.gov.nu.ca/education/news/covid-19-department-education-services-update
notes_H7: As of 4 june 2021,  11:22AM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 22,709,722 Canadians [60% of the total national population and 68% of the vaccine-eligible population aged 12+] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer or AstraZeneca (no longer being offered as a first dose). Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen vaccine has been approved, but shipments have not been distributed pending a quality control check. 2,481,530 Canadians [6.5% of total pop.] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations were initially targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health, education, emergency response), B. clinically vulnerable groups (indigenous communities, prisoners, homeless persons, those with medical conditions, adults in some neighbourhoods with high % of covid cases, pregnant women), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities/retirement homes first, then all seniors wherever they live). With all provinces and territories now making vaccinations available to ages as young as 12, code now at 5 = universal. See CTV news and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210604163830/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-covid-19-vaccine-rollout-in-canada-by-province-explainer/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210604164149/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccination-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509
notes_C3: Alberta and BC both direct events over 250 people to be cancelled  https://web.archive.org/web/20200523183913/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/alberta-covid-coronavirus-1.5496924
notes_C8: Borders shut to all foreign nationals (except Americans on essential travel and Canadians returning home) https://www.canada.ca/en/transport-canada/news/2020/03/new-measures-for-covid-19-response.html Old unarchived link (that doesn't exist any more!): https://www.canada.ca/en/transport-canada/news/2020/03/new-measures-for-covid-19-response.html
notes_C4: Every province/territory has sub-regional restrictions in place on gatherings. A large majority fall within <10 people.  Limits in # of people gathering by province:  Quebec: 2 Ontario: 5 Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Newfoundland and Labrador and Yukon: <10 Northwest Territories, Prince Edward Island and Nunavut: 0 / no gatherings Alberta:15 British Columbia: 50  See:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200618073657/https://nationalpost.com/news/covid-19-time-for-feds-to-take-the-helm-on-social-distancing-measures-experts-say
notes_C6: On 29 may 2021, the latest advice from the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada continues to be “reduce non-essential activities and outings to a minimum, avoid all non-essential travel”. Provinces and territories continue to ask residents “to stay home unless necessary for groceries, pharmacy visits or medical care”. See Government of Canada and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210529145218/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2021/05/statement-from-the-chief-public-health-officer-of-canada-on-may-27-2021.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210529100023/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-coronavirus-rules-by-province-physical-distancing-open-closed/
notes_H6: Based on province, e.g. Calgary: "Citing the rising numbers of coronavirus cases, the City of Calgary says it will make masks mandatory in all indoor public spaces starting Aug. 1."
notes_H8: Effective 2 june 2021, the province of Nova Scotia (NS) relaxed covid restrictions in long-term care homes. “Outdoor social visits are permitted for all residents...Residents who are fully vaccinated may be visited indoors or outdoors by specialized workers (this includes hair stylists, legal counsel, etc.)...Family members, friends and Designated Caregivers are permitted to transport a resident to a medical/dental appointment...two Designated Caregivers may visit a resident at the same time, regardless of immunization status of the resident. Immunization is recommended for Designated Caregivers, but is not mandatory” Other provinces had already relaxed restrictions in long-term care homes now that almost all residents have been vaccinated. Corrected to 2G, after initially maintaining 3T code. See province of NS website, archived:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614193503/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/docs/Guidelines-for-Long-Term-Care-Visits.pdf
notes_C5: Effective 6 January, the Office of Premier Blaine Higgs announced that “the entire province of New Brunswick will move to the Orange level... Public Health recommended the move due to the doubling of cases in less than six days … as well as reports of situations where some individuals were not complying with public health measures.” To comply with orange alert rules requiring 1m distancing on public transit, city transit services reduced bus seating capacity to 50% or 15-20 passengers on each bus.     See New Brunswick government websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110192430/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/news/news_release.2021.01.0007.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110200130/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/recovery.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110200130/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/recovery.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110205043/https://www.saintjohn.ca/news-and-service-updates/saint-john-transit-seating-capacity-reduced-by-covid-19-orange-phase  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110203956/https://www.fredericton.ca/en/transit

name: Switzerland
notes_H1: "Protect yourself and others" campaign started. https://web.archive.org/web/20200304163343/https://foph-coronavirus.ch/
notes_H2: Evidence of recommended and generally available testings. "Rapid tests are also free for people with no symptoms".    http://web.archive.org/web/20210407130103/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html
notes_C7: As of 6 June 2020, there are no more restrictions on workplaces.    The only remaining restrictions are on gatherings in public of more than 30 people, events or demonstrations with more than 300 people and sports competition involving close physical contact.  Keeping a distance, wearing a mask and observing hygiene rules still applies    (see http://web.archive.org/web/20200611185821/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html)
notes_E2: The measure to protect renters expired on 1 June 2020  "Extension of the deadline for payment arrears by the tenant from 30 today to at least 90 days. However, this only applies to payment arrears that arise in connection with the Federal Council's measures to combat the corona virus. It is also only about rents and ancillary costs that are due between March 13 and May 31, 2020."    (http://web.archive.org/web/20200710220151/https://www.bwo.admin.ch/bwo/de/home/mietrecht/coronavirus.html)    Other measures providing debt/contract relief to families are not known.
notes_C2: Recoded from 3T to 2G because Geneva's local lockdown was softened with the reopening of various activities from 21 November: personal services involving physical contacts such as hairdressers, beauticians, barbers, tattoo artists and therapists.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201207191537/https://www.ge.ch/en/covid-19-restrictions-closures-and-other-measures
notes_H3: Contact tracing is in the responsibility of the 26 cantons, making it difficult to assess the exact situation.    In terms of policy, it seems that all cantons continued, resumed or set up contact tracing as of 11 May 2020.  See below for a list of references to the cantons for which explicit documentation was found.  Therefore as of 11 May 2020, H2=2.    HOWEVER:   -the capacities are not always sufficient and information on this is documented in later entries  -there is no strong central coordination (the cantons do their own thing)  -although all cantons see it as their duty to implement contact tracing the wording at the federal level only talks about a "recommendation" as in:   "Contact tracing is recommended for all people with laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 or for hospitalized people with probable COVID-19. The responsible cantonal agency identifies the close contacts and contacts them."  (see http://web.archive.org/web/20200530165857/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/de/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/information-fuer-die-aerzteschaft/contact-tracing.html)    Despite these restrictions, H2=2 seems to reflect the policy of the cantons best. Fribourg	11.05.20	http://web.archive.org/web/20200807073732/https://www.fr.ch/de/covid19/news/testen-tracken-isolieren-neue-strategie-zur-eindaemmung-des-coronavirus Ausserhoden	11.05.20	http://web.archive.org/web/20200807074241/https://www.nau.ch/ort/herisau/appenzell-ausserrhoden-verstarkt-contact-tracing-65704174    St. Gallen	earlier	http://web.archive.org/web/20200807073252/https://www.watson.ch/schweiz/coronavirus/528400132-wildwuchs-beim-contakt-tracing-wie-jeder-kanton-vor-sich-hinwerkelt notes_E1: From 17th September, in certain situations it is possible to claim for income support:  •	Parents who have to stop working because their children are no longer being looked after via schools etc.  •	Income loss due to quarantine  •	Self employed who are forced to stop trading    The income support is 80% of the lost salary.    https://archive.vn/wip/gZQW7
notes_C1: Face to face teaching at higher education institutions is now possible with a limit of 50 persons.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210423082840/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html
notes_H7: Ongoing vaccination campaign.    Groups C (people over 75), A (caregivers) and now B (clinically vulnerable groups) are receiving the vaccine since April 15.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210414194503/https://www.newsd.admin.ch/newsd/message/attachments/65845.pdf
notes_C3: Events once again permitted, in general max. 15 people.   Reopening of leisure facilities and cultural venues.    “With spectators indoors: max 50 people or 1/3 of venue capacity”    “With spectators outdoors: max 100 people or 1/3 of venue capacity”.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210423082840/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html
notes_C8: As of, June 15, Switzerland has lifted all COVID-19 related entry restrictions for travelers from other Schengen countries. The Swiss government has not announced a date when Switzerland will lift the current entry restrictions for U.S. citizens.    This is the updated information at the US embassy site. So, I am coding it to Ban.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201028171227/https://ch.usembassy.gov/covid-19-info/
notes_C4: Applicable from 31 May:   “Rule indoors from gatherings and parties: a maximum of 30 people is allowed.  Rule outdoors: A maximum of 50 people is allowed.”    Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210603192337/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html
notes_C6: From 18 Oct, working from home is explicitly recommended.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201207193013/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/das-bag/aktuell/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-80771.html
notes_H6: Applicable from 31 May: it is compulsory to wear a mask in all publicly accessible areas of businesses and establishments that are permitted to open. This applies to both indoor and outdoor areas.    “The following general rule applies: wear a mask if you’re not at home and can’t distance from other people at all times.”    Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210603192337/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20210603203411/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/masken.html
notes_H8: ***Recoded from 2G to 1G. As of May 1, it seems there are no protections in place beyond social distancing and masking. While reports in April of negative tests being required to visitors to elderly care homes in Zurich, cannot find ongoing evidence of this.   https://verietyinfo.com/switzerlandeng/coronavirus-can-i-visit-nursing-homes-and-nursing-homes/    Previous coding notes:   No evidence of a policy change.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210506072054/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html    No evidence of a policy change.     Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210520200506/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html  No evidence of a policy change.     Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210526125002/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

name: Chile
notes_H1: Ministry of health announces COVID response has moved to Phase three, asks all citizens to take self-care measures, quarantines to be respected, handshakes, kisses and the most efficient measure, which is frequent hand washing, to be avoided. Launches government website; https://web.archive.org/web/20200331183753/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/covid-19-ministerio-de-salud-confirma-que-chile-paso-fase-3/
notes_H2: "COVID-19 testing is available at all public and private hospitals/clinics. Anyone may request a test, whether symptomatic or not, though private hospitals and clinics may require an appointment beforehand."  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://cl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: Jaime Mañalich, Minister of Health, announced that the Chilean government decrees a total mandatory quarantine for the province of Santiago, the country's capital, and other neighboring communes. The decision will take effect at 10:00 p.m. on Friday, May 15 [/web/20200601192955/https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-52655289]
notes_E2: Still appears to be current   https://web.archive.org/web/20200827131007/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/plandeaccion/#v-pills-planeconoemergencia
notes_C2: Jaime Mañalich, Minister of Health, announced that the Chilean government decrees a total mandatory quarantine for the province of Santiago, the country's capital, and other neighboring communes. The decision will take effect at 10:00 p.m. on Friday, May 15 [/web/20200601192955/https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-52655289]
notes_H3: The law ruling the Ministry of Health of Chile establishes that any unforeseen disease (such as COVID-19) should be tested to anybody who is suspect of having it. They released the report with such information on March 30. It is not clear the exact day they started testing.  https://www.minsal.cl/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/INFORME_EPI_COVID19_20200330.pdf  Official Contact Tracing Guidelines published (6 March 2020): https://www.minsal.cl/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/2020.03.06_PROTOCOLO-SEGUIMIENTO-CONTACTOS-CASOS-CONFIRMADOS_COVID-19.pdf
notes_E1: "President Piñera signs a project that expands Emergency Family Income to benefit up to 5.6 million people: "It reaches far beyond vulnerable groups and includes the middle class." The initiative, which is part of the Agreement for Social Protection and Job Recovery, extends the benefit to up to $ 100,000 per person.    The program, part of the transversal agreement promoted by the President for social protection and job recovery, changes its design to act as a complement to the current income of the family group. This encompasses both households with no formal income and those with some formal income, and includes families with other benefits such as the employment protection law, unemployment insurance, support for independent workers and people who collect contributory pensions. and non-contributory.    The law adds a fourth month of payment, which will be 80% of income and may go up to 100% if sanitary conditions so warrant."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200702133937/https://prensa.presidencia.cl/comunicado.aspx?id=152600
notes_C1: Face to face classes are suspended in Tier 1 municipalities. In other regions there are mixed (virtual and face to face) classes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607142610/https://sigamosaprendiendo.mineduc.cl/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210606215830/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/pasoapaso/#situacioncomunal/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210526185811/https://s3.amazonaws.com/gobcl-prod/public_files/Campa%C3%B1as/Corona-Virus/documentos/paso-a-paso/210429_Plan_Paso_a_Paso.pdf
notes_H7: A, B, C: Pfzier, Cansino, Coronavac and AztraZeneca.  Currently the general population aged 23 and up is being offered a vaccine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607030419/https://www.gob.cl/yomevacuno/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607174321/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/ministerio-de-salud-lanza-campana-especial-de-vacunacion-para-rezagados-mayores-de-23-anos/
notes_C3: Holding or participation of social gatherings, events and activities of all kinds not allowed except funerals, services and religious ceremonies.  Based on each area's epidemiology.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502200831/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/pasoapaso/
notes_C8: "Chile’s government has decreed that, starting from April 5, 2021, Chile has closed its borders to foreign nationals without regular residence status and has restricted departures from Chile for all its population, including Chilean nationals and foreign nationals with regular residence status. This measure is due to last through the month of April. Chilean nationals and foreign nationals with regular residence status will be allowed to return to Chile if they are currently abroad, however they will not be allowed to depart except under certain circumstances."    Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210506061733/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2021/04/flash-alert-2021-106.html
notes_C4: Gatherings (except for funerals and religious ceremonies) are forbidden in Tier 1 municipalities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210606215830/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/pasoapaso/#situacioncomunal/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210526185811/https://s3.amazonaws.com/gobcl-prod/public_files/Campa%C3%B1as/Corona-Virus/documentos/paso-a-paso/210429_Plan_Paso_a_Paso.pdf
notes_C6: In Tier 1 areas, people must stay at home, and can only go out to make purchases or specific and essential procedures with an individual permit that can be obtained at comisariavirtual.cl (two a week, maximum one on the weekend).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607153223/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/pasoapaso/
notes_H6: Chilean authorities require the use of face masks in all public spaces / public transport, including the airport. You risk a significant fine for not wearing a mask in public.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210502201924/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chile/coronavirus
notes_H8: The operation of Clubs for Seniors and Day Centers for Seniors etc to encourage staying at home. To better care for our older adults, who are the highest risk group against Covid-19, the government decreed a national quarantine for all adults older than 80 years or older. As of May 15, the limit drops to 75 years.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210502205153/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/pasoapaso/
notes_C5: Ability to perform interregional transfers only between locations that are in Step 3, 4 and 5 is based on step current community is at due to epidemiological situation.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502200831/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/pasoapaso/

name: China
notes_H1: The National Health Commission maintains a dedicated website on prevention and control of covid-19 covering daily official notifications on the situation, news, policy announcements, public health education and Q&As.  Similar contents are also pushed through its official wechat account on the social media in different formats including videos and infographics. notes_H2: Chinas Joint Prevention and Control Mechanism announced efforts to intensify the screening of asymptomatic cases.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.chinadailyhk.com/article/126119
notes_C7: 'Health authorities have imposed travel restrictions in Guangdong and mass testing is under way as they scramble to contain a Covid-19 outbreak in the southern Chinese province, where a fast-spreading strain first found in India has been detected.  Twenty new locally transmitted cases were confirmed on Sunday [30 May 2021] – 18 in Guangzhou and two in neighbouring Foshan, the Guangdong Health Commission said. That brings the total to 47 cases, 21 of them asymptomatic, since the outbreak began on May 21.  A lockdown is in place in the worst-hit area, a district of Guangzhou, and from 10pm on Monday [31 May 2021] anyone who wants to leave the province must show a negative test result from within 72 hours before departure. Nearly 500 flights had been cancelled at airports in Guangzhou and Shenzhen – the third city to report cases in the latest outbreak – as of Monday morning.  ...  No one can enter or leave the affected areas, as interior designer Yang Rui found out when she tried to go to work on Saturday morning.'    https://archive.vn/rNyux
notes_E2: Loan relief policy: http://web.archive.org/web/20200924071933/http://www.gov.cn/zhengce/zhengceku/2020-02/01/content_5473639.htm  Guideline to prevent services such as electricity, gas and heating from stopping: http://web.archive.org/web/20201114104246/http://www.gov.cn/xinwen/gwylflkjz27/index.htm
notes_C2: Mid-risk areas - except one - in Anhui provice were downgraded to low-risk in late-May, while new infections were found in Guangzhou, Shenzhen, and Foshan in Guangdong province; more than half of the new cases reported in 29 and 30 May are locally transmitted. One district is Guangzhou is put into lockdown on 29 May: 'Guangzhou government ordered residents on five streets in the city's Liwan district to remain at home and suspended non-essential activities, while entertainment venues and markets were closed.'    https://archive.vn/rNyux  https://archive.vn/5DE4O
notes_H3: According to the notification of Wuhan health commission, serious contact tracing is being pursued.   163 close contacts have been traced and put under medical observation. name: Cote d'Ivoire
notes_H1: http://info-covid19.gouv.ci/
notes_H2: Tests generally available. Cost is borne by the patient, and results are generally available between 24 and 48 hours from the test.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210606181805if_/https://deplacement-aerien.gouv.ci/#/faq
notes_C7: Domestic flights have resumed, no specific restrictions on domestic movement. https://web.archive.org/web/20200803232532/https://www.worldaware.com/covid-19-alert-cote-divoire-extends-state-emergency-through-july-30-easing-lockdown-greater-abidjan
notes_E2: https://web.archive.org/save/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/ivory-coast-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html    On 21 March 2020, the CBWAS took major measures, in order to mitigate the negative impact of the sanitary crisis:  A FCFA340bn financial help has been granted to commercial banks, so they can sustain the economy;  1,700 companies have been granted loans, while they were not eligible so far, so that they can benefit from further resources;  The West African Development Bank (WADB) will receive FCFA25bn from the CBWAS, in order to lower its interest rate and increase the amount of loans granted to WAMU members, so as to be able to fund the domestic economy;  To accept to delay financial debt reimbursements, especially for SMEs;  To decrease the cost of fund transfers through mobile money, in order to avoid a low in transactions;  To fund commercial banks with enough cash to guarantee a good working of cash machines;  If necessary, to reorganize the schedule of Treasury bills issuance.  The government announced several measures to preserve the key sectors of the economy:  The setting up of a private sector support fund for an amount of XOF 250 billion, in order to strengthen the SMEs with at least XOF 100 billion and the setting up of guarantee funds, in order to facilitate the access to bank credits;  The setting up of a specific support fund for informal sector enterprises affected by the crisis for an amount of XOF100 billion.  Support for the main sectors of the national economy, particularly cashew nuts, cotton, rubber, oil palm, cocoa and coffee with  XOF 250 billion;  Support for food, market gardening and fruit production for an amount of CFAF 50 billion, including CFAF 20 billion for inputs.
notes_C2: "As of July 31, 2020, bars, clubs, movie theaters, and other entertainment venues in Abidjan may now open, but must respect social distancing norms and patrons are expected to wear masks."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200804020937/https://ci.usembassy.gov/health-and-travel-alert-u-s-embassy-abidjan-cote-divoire-august-3-2020/Bars, nightclubs, cinemas and theatres reopen from 31 July." No mention of any other businesses that are closed.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200804015535/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/cote-d-ivoire/coronavirus
notes_H3: Digital tracking system in place. However, this appears to only apply to travelers.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210607205818/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/cote-d-ivoire/entry-requirements
notes_E1: "On March 31, the government announced a package of economic measures to prop the income of the most vulnerable segments of the population through agricultural input support and expanded cash transfers, "  "National Solidarity Fund of 170 billion CFAF (0.5 % of GDP), the Support Fund for the informal sector of 100 billion CFAF (0.3 % of GDP), the Support Fund for the small and medium enterprises of 150 billion CFAF (0.4 % of GDP) and the Support Fund for large companies of 100 billion CFAF (0.3 % of GDP). They will also provide financial support to the agriculture sector by 300 billion CFAF (0.8 % of GDP). "  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607134921/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

name: Cameroon
notes_H1: The Ministry of Health has a webpage dedicated to COVID 19 and the website is functional with fairly regular updates. It also includes different posters on the right way to combat the virus. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231959/https://covid19.minsante.cm/
notes_H2: The US Embassy in Cameroon confirms that there is testing available;  The following facilities provide COVID-19 testing in Cameroon: Centre Pasteur and National Public Health Laboratory in Yaounde, and the Laquintinie Hospital in Douala. The Cameroon government has announced that these tests are free of charge.  Once the patient submits their sample, results are sent to him/her by email, text message, or physical copy within 24 hours unless otherwise specified by the testing facility.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210125013417/https://cm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

notes_H3: No data was found for this placeholder.

notes_C1: Businesses, churches, government offices, and most schools are open and maintain normal hours. notes_H7: A and B.     Democratic Republic of the Congo has administered at least 42,951 doses of COVID vaccines so far. Assuming every person needs 2 doses, that’s enough to have vaccinated less than 0.1% of the country’s population.    web.archive.org/save/https://graphics.reuters.com/world-coronavirus-tracker-and-maps/countries-and-territories/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/

notes_C8: https://web.archive.org/web/20201222020649/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? No  Travelers entering the DRC, regardless of the origin of their travel, are not required to quarantine so long as they show a negative COVID-19 test taken within 7 days of departure from their point of origin and receive a negative COVID-19 test upon arrival.  Following the sample collection at the airport, travelers must self-quarantine until they receive a negative test result, generally within 24 hours.

notes_H2: Healthcare in the Republic of Congo  For contact details for English speaking doctors visit our list of healthcare providers.    If you think you have COVID-19 symptoms, you should call the response number: 3434      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210315201653/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/coronavirus
notes_C7: Public places and services  Gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited, with the exception of public markets, which are open on weekdays (except Wednesday) and Saturday.    Bars and nightclubs are closed.    Face masks must be worn in all public places.    The Republic of Congo authorities have mobilised defence and security forces to ensure compliance with the lockdown measures, at the entrance and exit of all cities across the country.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210315201653/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/coronavirus
notes_E2: The IMF states that the government has adopted some measures to ease tax and duty payments for private enterprises. In particular, more time has been given to companies to pay their taxes and tax assessments on site have been abandoned. The import duty directorate is also strongly encouraging electronic payment of dues and allowing more electronic documents to be accepted at the port. Corporate income tax has been reduced to 28 percent from 30 percent and the turnover tax has been reduced to 5 percent from 7 percent for small businesses with turnover below 100 million XAF, although these measures will apply in 2021.  Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201005218/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C2: According to the website of the US Embassy in  Congo, public markets are open on weekdays (except Wednesday) and Saturday.    Bars and nightclubs that were closed are now open.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129205003/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H3: The sitrep is yet to be updated.     The last sitrep is archived below. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201010226/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-point-epidemiologique-du-03-janvier-2021/
notes_E1: No current information on income support in Congo.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210315143057/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C1: Country-Specific Information:    Curfew: The following provinces have a curfew in place from 10:00 pm to 4:00 am: Kinshasa, North Kivu, South Kivu, Kongo Central, Lualaba, Haut-Katanga. As of April 13, the curfew is lifted entirely in all other provinces.  Masks are required in public spaces.  Businesses, schools, airports, and ports are open. While DRC permits borders open, many neighboring countries continue to restrict border crossings.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210531180308/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H7: Vaccination started on 19 April, initially with 300,000 doses of Sinopharm's BBIBP-CorV vaccine donated by China and 12,000 doses of Sputnik V. By the end of the month (30th April 2021) 41379 persons had received their first inoculation and 11700 had been fully vaccinated. Vaccination started in Pointe-Noire on Monday, April 19, 2021. To date, five (5) vaccination centers are in operation there. In Brazzaville, four (4) new vaccination centers (Madibou, Mfilou, Moukondo and WHO Africa) have been added to the eleven (11) existing centers. Vaccination operations have extended to Owando and Makoua, whose centers opened on April 26 and April 30, 2021, respectively. It is not clear which groups are being targeted for vaccines, if any.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517190932/https://www.adiac-congo.com/content/communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-15
notes_C3: Due to the banning of public gatherings above 50 people (apart from public markets), public events are restricted by implication. However, due to no explicit mention that public events are banned, it is assumed that they are recommended not to be held (rather than required).   https://web.archive.org/web/20201021185847/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/-coronavirus
notes_C8: According to the US EMbassy in the Congo, all international passengers are required to self-quarantine for two weeks in their residence or hotel for 14 day upon arrival. Passengers in transit will be quarantined at their expense at designated facilities until they resume their travels.    There are also health procedures at the point of entry. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129205003/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: Gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited, with the exception of public markets, which are open on weekdays (except Wednesday) and Saturday.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210531181255/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/coronavirus
notes_C6: Country-Specific Information:    The Republic of Congo has confirmed cases of COVID-19 since March 14, 2020. As of March 31, there were 10,084 confirmed cases, 9,286 recoveries and 137 confirmed deaths.  The government of The Republic of Congo extended a State of Health Emergency until May 4 to limit the spread of COVID-19. The curfew in Brazzaville and Pointe Noire is from 23:00 until 05:00, Mondays through Fridays and from 20:00 until 05:00 on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.  The Congolese air borders opened on August 24 for international flights. International air carriers are resuming some services into and from Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire.  Land and river borders remain closed.  Places of worship, schools, restaurants and bars are open.  All international passengers are required to self-quarantine for two weeks in their residence or hotel for 14 day upon arrival. Passengers in transit will be quarantined at their expense at designated facilities until they resume their travels.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419185611/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: From 30 April, the President of the Republic of Congo announced that the use of face masks would be compulsory in public spaces.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200911005454/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/338286/congo-government-extends-covid-19-lockdown-measures-until-may-15-update-4
notes_H8: Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Domestic travelers age 11 and older are required to present a negative COVID-19 test for travel between the provinces when departing from Kinshasa, Lubumbashi, Bukavu, Goma, and Kisangani. Where possible, the test must be taken within 7 days of travel.  Check with your airline about COVID-19 safety measures, testing requirements, and health requirements at your destination.    See: http://web.archive.org/web/20210607113847/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: Transportation Options:    Are commercial flights operating? Yes  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Masks are still required in public and social distancing and hygiene requirements continue to be implemented.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210419185611/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Colombia
notes_H1: There’s an ongoing coordinated public information campaign through traditional channels and social media at least since March 9 onwards. Here’s some examples: Ministry of Health’s campaign, posted on March 9: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JYaA-k2g4Hs  Other videos from the Ministry of Health available here: https://www.youtube.com/user/MinSaludColPrensa/videos  Ministry of Education’s campaign, posted on March 9: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NPGBNjxJcGE Other videos from the Ministry of Education available here:  https://www.youtube.com/user/mineducacion/videos  Plus these: http://web.archive.org/web/20200603125610/https://www.minsalud.gov.co/English/Paginas/historico-noticias.aspx
notes_H2: The first version of the guidelines on the detection of COVID cases that all health providers must follow were issued and approved by the Ministry of Health on January 31, 2020. Since this version of the guidelines, anyone who "fits" the symptoms of COVID must be tested by the health provider.  Here's the link to the first version of the guidelines: http://eselavega-cundinamarca.gov.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/GIPS05-LINEAMIENTOS-IPS.pdf   The revised version of the guidelines was issued on March 19 and it included more details about the description of the types of cases, but maintained the policy of testing anyone who is symptomatic. Here's the link to the second version of the guidelines:  https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Ministerio/Institucional/Procesos%20y%20procedimientos/GIPS05.pdf
notes_C7: 4 × 3 scheme continues - three days a week (Friday, Saturday and Sunday (April 30 – May 2) with total quarantine.  During the other four days of the week - Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday (May 3 until May 7) face-to-face work is allowed (maximum capacity of 30%) and free movement until the night quarantine begins (from eight at night to four in the morning ), always maintaining self-care and biosecurity measures.    https://archive.vn/QFt3c
notes_E2: After the issuance of Decree 417, on March 17 2020,  the citizens that have to pay rent cannot be evicted from their homes during the emergency and up to two months after it. In addition, during the economic emergency, and for two months more, the leasing fees cannot be increased.  Here’s the links:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200501012945/https://dapre.presidencia.gov.co/normativa/normativa/DECRETO%20417%20DEL%2017%20DE%20MARZO%20DE%202020.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20200429211423/https://www.lafm.com.co/colombia/duque-anuncia-que-queda-prohibido-el-desalojo-por-no-pago-de-arriendo  From March 18 onwards the government offered: i) free reconnection of the aqueduct service for those families who have the service suspended; ii) freeze the increase of the water and aqueduct services bills; and iii) suspension of the collection of tariffs for water purification.  Here’s the links:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200501013557/https://id.presidencia.gov.co/Paginas/prensa/2020/MinVivienda-explico-nuevas-medidas-desde-el-sector-de-agua-potable-relacionadas-con-la-contencion-del-coronavirus-200318.aspx  https://id.presidencia.gov.co/especiales/200317-medidas-enfrentar-coronavirus/index.html  According to the IMF the following benefits have been granted by the Colombian government: “ a two-month suspension of pension contributions by both employees and employers, delayed tax collection for the tourism and air transportation sectors, an exemption of tariffs and VAT for strategic health imports and selected food industries and services, delayed utility payments for poor and middle income households, additional taxes for public sector workers (to help fund the response), and expanded transfers for vulnerable groups….
