Beginning February 8, Switzerland requires that all persons arriving in Switzerland from a country or region with a high risk of COVID-19 infection present valid proof of a negative PCR (polymerase chain reaction) test result that is no more than 72 hours old.     Liechtenstein requires that all designated travelers quarantine themselves for a full 10 days regardless of submitting a negative PCR test. This is due to local conditions related to the spread of virus mutations. Your arrival day counts as your first day of quarantine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315080200/http://www.liechtensteinusa.org/article/measures-taken-in-liechtenstein-in-response-to-the-coronavirus-pandemic
notes_C4: Beginning March 29, up to 25 people will be allowed to gather in outdoor public areas. In addition, family and friends may gather indoors in groups of up to 10 people, up from five announced in February. Public events of up to 10 people will continue to be allowed, but the serving of food or drink is prohibited. Public establishments in the areas of culture, entertainment, leisure and sports, allowed to reopen in February, will continue to be open. Bars, nightclubs and dance clubs, as well as casinos will remain closed. Restaurants will also remain closed but are allowed to offer takeaway and delivery services. School cafeterias, as well as business cantinas and hotel restaurants servicing guests are not affected. For all gatherings and establishments, strict protective procedures must be maintained. This also includes maintaining social distances of at least 1.5 meters who do not belong in the same household, as well as the wearing of masks in all public areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315080200/http://www.liechtensteinusa.org/article/measures-taken-in-liechtenstein-in-response-to-the-coronavirus-pandemic
notes_C6: On 24 October 2020, the government began recommending limiting social contact again along with other restrictions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210501200344/https://www.regierung.li/files/attachments/588-corona-regierung-schliesst-gastronomie-1023.pdf?t=637555027160559197
notes_H6: Beginning March 1,  For all gatherings and establishments, strict protective procedures must be maintained. This also includes maintaining social distances of at least 1.5 meters who do not belong in the same household, as well as the wearing of masks in all public areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210315080200/http://www.liechtensteinusa.org/article/measures-taken-in-liechtenstein-in-response-to-the-coronavirus-pandemic
notes_H8: 16th March 2020, Older people should stay at home    Contagion causes mild symptoms in most people. For elderly People and people with certain pre-existing conditions can get the virus though be life-threatening. The government therefore recommends people age 65 and over as well People with previous illnesses urgently, social contacts to the absolute Minimun and stay at home whenever possible. Contacts with Avoid people who show symptoms of the common cold. The government is also calling Relatives when dealing with older people and people with previous illnesses the greatest caution.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110095401/https://www.regierung.li/media/attachments/120-corona-massnahmen-verschaerft-0316.pdf?t=637203447788083667
notes_C5: Masks required on public transportation in Liechtenstein.  source: https://archive.vn/ZiAL7

name: Sri Lanka
notes_H1: From 14 March, Sri Lanka announcements start increasing. Since then the President and Ministry of Health have been quite active on social media. This continued throughout the nationwide curfew which started on 20 March.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200504162625/http://www.epid.gov.lk/web/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=225&Itemid=487&lang=en  https://web.archive.org/web/20200504163456/https://twitter.com/gotabayar  https://web.archive.org/web/20200504163534/https://twitter.com/moh_srilanka  https://web.archive.org/web/20200408194539/https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/coronavirus-sri-lanka-bans-public-events-as-cases-rises-to-8/article31069806.ece  https://web.archive.org/web/20200504143121/https://www.deccanherald.com/international/coronavirus-sri-lanka-to-lift-nationwide-curfew-on-april-27-829717.html
notes_H2: Multiple  new reports from Jan 3 suggest that random Rapid Antigen Tests are being conducted and available at Fish Stalls in the Western Province (the country's capital Colombo is in the Western Province):   - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126065207/https://colombogazette.com/2021/01/03/rapid-antigen-tests-conducted-at-fish-stalls-in-western-province/  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210126065251/https://www.newsradio.lk/local/random-tests-to-be-conducted-at-fish-stalls-markets/
notes_C7: There are restrictions on intercity and interstate travel following a spike in infections, with numerous isolated areas  see here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210508201029/https://lk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210508201114/https://colombogazette.com/2021/05/08/several-areas-in-wattala-and-mahabage-isolated/
notes_E2: MONETARY AND MACRO-FINANCIAL  The Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) has reduced monetary policy rates by 100 basis points since March. The required reserve ratio on domestic currency deposits of commercial banks has been lowered by one percentage point, the liquidity coverage ratio and net stable funding ratios have been reduced to 90 percent and the rate at which CBSL grants advances to commercial banks has been lowered by 500 basis points. Commercial banks cannot declare dividends, share buy backs or increase payments to directors until end-2020. The President announced a debt repayment moratorium, which includes a six month moratorium on bank loans for the tourism, garment, plantation and IT sectors, and small & medium industries, with reduced rate working capital loans and investment-purpose loans for these sectors. There will also be a three-month moratorium on small-value personal banking and leasing loans. The interest rate on credit cards will be capped, for transactions up to a certain amount, with a reduction in the minimum monthly repayment. Financial institutions are also requested to reschedule non-performing loans. Lower capital conservation buffer requirements and a relaxation of loan classification rules have been announced. In addition, state-owned institutions will invest in treasury securities to stabilize the money market rate at 7 percent.    http://archive.fo/nKJdw
notes_C2: All workplaces must utilize telecommuting to the extent possible; they must also collect and update employee details to facilitate contact tracing if and when necessary. Officials may reintroduce or implement stricter nationwide measures in the coming weeks..     Business, gathering, and transport restrictions remain in effect under a Level Three alert through May 31. Nonessential inter-provincial travel remains suspended nationwide; public transport services along such routes are available only to essential workers. Private and public gatherings are banned, except for permitted events. Transport services and most establishments are operating at a maximum of 50 percent capacity; grooming and recreational facilities are closed. The use of facemasks remains mandatory in public.     see here: https://archive.ph/fxKsM (Garda)   https://archive.ph/nRg5e (US Embassy)
notes_H3: Government issues initial testing and contact tracing protocols. https://web.archive.org/web/20200329223450/http://www.epid.gov.lk/web/images/pdf/Circulars/Corona_virus/revisionsummary.pdf
notes_C1: following a spike in cases, schools are closed until further notice     see here:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210502171414/https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/sri-lanka-issues-new-tough-guidelines-amid-spike-in-covid-19-cases/article34462911.ece    https://web.archive.org/web/20210502172908/https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/sri-lanka-braces-for-imminent-third-covid-19-wave/article34417392.ece    https://web.archive.org//web/20210502173627/http://www.colombopage.com/archive_21A/May01_1619881000CH.php
notes_H7: no change in policy
notes_C3: As of May 1st, there is a general ban on public events and gatherings, which includes weddings and religious sites. This will be until 21.05.21 when the decision will be reviewed     see here: see here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502171414/https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/sri-lanka-issues-new-tough-guidelines-amid-spike-in-covid-19-cases/article34462911.ece    The British Government website also indicates that Public gatherings such as exhibitions, conferences, parties, indoor and outdoor events, carnivals, musical shows and processions have been banned    https://web.archive.org//web/20210502173627/http://www.colombopage.com/archive_21A/May01_1619881000CH.php
notes_C8: Sri Lanka will allow resumption of inbound international commercial flights from 00:01 June 1; such flights are currently banned. However, only up to 75 passengers may board each flight. Those with a travel or transit history to India in the past 14 days are also not allowed to enter Sri Lanka until further notice. Officials are tightening nationwide bans on nonessential vehicular and public movement through June 7. Ongoing movement restrictions will be in place continuously through 04:00 June   see here: https://archive.ph/5sLTT  https://archive.ph/K0Y4U
notes_C4: All public events and gatherings have been banned as of May 1st due to a spike in cases    see here: https://web.archive.org/web/20210502171414/https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/sri-lanka-issues-new-tough-guidelines-amid-spike-in-covid-19-cases/article34462911.ece    https://web.archive.org/web/20210502172248/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/sri-lanka/coronavirus    https://web.archive.org//web/20210502173627/http://www.colombopage.com/archive_21A/May01_1619881000CH.php
notes_C6: Sri Lanka is banning nonessential vehicular and public movement through 04:00 May 17 due to COVID-19 activity. Similar curbs will apply nightly 23:00-04:00 May 17-31. Cargo transit, delivery services, and industrial operations are unaffected. Residents must stay home except for essential, emergency, and employment purposes.     People exiting homes for permitted activities 04:01-22:59 must adhere to an odd-even rule; those with an even National Identity Card or passport number may go out on even days and vice versa. Those on emergency trips and essential workers with valid employment passes are typically exempt from such curbs.    See more here:   https://archive.ph/Wwsfv (Garda)   https://archive.ph/gf4Bf (U.S. Embassy)   https://archive.ph/KAcMN (Tamil Guardian)
notes_H6: The use of facemasks remains mandatory in public.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412175517/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/454241/sri-lanka-government-maintaining-coronavirus-related-measures-as-of-march-12-update-42  https://web.archive.org/web/20210412175656/https://lk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H8: Mimicking C6:     Sri Lanka is banning nonessential vehicular and public movement through 04:00 May 17 due to COVID-19 activity. Similar curbs will apply nightly 23:00-04:00 May 17-31. Cargo transit, delivery services, and industrial operations are unaffected. Residents must stay home except for essential, emergency, and employment purposes.     People exiting homes for permitted activities 04:01-22:59 must adhere to an odd-even rule; those with an even National Identity Card or passport number may go out on even days and vice versa. Those on emergency trips and essential workers with valid employment passes are typically exempt from such curbs.    See more here:   https://archive.ph/Wwsfv (Garda)   https://archive.ph/gf4Bf (U.S. Embassy)   https://archive.ph/KAcMN (Tamil Guardian)
notes_C5: A 50-percent capacity limit applies to transport services     https://web.archive.org/web/20210508195932/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/475601/sri-lanka-officials-ban-passengers-from-india-effective-may-6-due-to-covid-19-activity-update-46     https://web.archive.org/web/20210508201029/https://lk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Lesotho
notes_H1: Lesotho is providing COVID updates through its NACOSEC twitter page.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605064218/https://twitter.com/nacosec?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor  https://web.archive.org/web/20210605064218/https://twitter.com/nacosec?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor
notes_H2: Testing is available at private clinics at patients' expense.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605044507/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/
notes_C7: There are no restrictions on domestic travel assuming it occurs outside the curfew hours.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605044507/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/
notes_E2: No new debt/contract relief.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605043934/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C2: As of April 26, 2021, workers are recommended to work from home where possible. Curfews are in place from 10 PM to 4 AM. Supermarkets, pharmacies, and most businesses can operate in line with safety protocols.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210605044507/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605043934/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_H3: No change.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301095534/https://www.pih.org/article/local-health-systems-key-responding-global-covid-19-pandemic-and-beyond
notes_C1: Schools are fully open with COVID protocols in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605043934/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_H7: Lesotho received the first batch of AstraZeneca vaccines on 3 March 2021. The 36 000 doses enabled the government to roll out its mass vaccination programme a week later. King Letsie III and Prime Minister Moeketsi Majoro were among the first to vaccinated against the deadly virus which had infected 10 720 people and killed 316 by yesterday in Lesotho.  The vaccination campaign was then spread to essential workers such as health workers and media practitioners. The ministry also vaccinated the elderly and those with life-threatening conditions like HIV/AIDS and tuberculosis.  The latest donation will enable these groups to receive their second and final dose of the vaccine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614074521/https://allafrica.com/stories/202106100503.html
notes_C3: Political rallies and other gatherings are banned.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210614072933/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus
notes_C8: Lesotho is open for regular travel, including tourism, through all border crossings and the Moshoeshoe I International Airport; any travelers to Lesotho will need to present a negative COVID-19 test not older than 72 hours from the time of departure; no quarantine in case of test negativity; health screening procedures are in place at airports and other ports of entry; source: /web/20210524104259/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/
notes_C4: According to NACOSEC, family and social gatherings are limited at 50 for indoors and 100 for outdoors. Gyms are limited at 30% capacity. Outdoor events are limited a 200 people, unless in a large open area in which case the limit is 2000 people. Weddings can have 100 people for indoors settings and 200 people for outdoors. Churches can have 50% capacity up to 500 people. Sporting events are permitted with a 2500 person limit for upper divisions. Entertainment is limited to 200 people per 300 sq. meters.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210605064358/https://twitter.com/nacosec/status/1386750833975513091
notes_C6: Industries and business have opened with limited capacity and protective measures. Tourism and entertainment industries are open. A curfew is still in place from 10 PM to 4 AM.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605043934/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605053358/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus
notes_H6: Facial coverings are required in all spaces outside the home, including when walking on the street.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605053358/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus
notes_H8: Lesotho is under “Blue Level” restrictions. A curfew is in place from 10pm to 4am.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614072933/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus
notes_C5: Public transport is available at full-seated capacity. Masks are required as they are in all public spaces, and eating is prohibited.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210605053358/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

name: Lithuania
notes_H1: there's a fully informative website provided by Lithuania Government giving organized information about COVID-19 control measures   http://web.archive.org/web/20210526215420/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1
notes_H2: Quote: "If you have symptoms of COVID-19 or have been in contact with a confirmed case within the previous 14 days, call the Lithuanian COVID-19 hotline on +370 37367 963 to request a COVID-19 PCR test. "  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210612063937/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lithuania/coronavirus
notes_C7: No change in policy  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614105002/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1
notes_E2: Quote: "In the government’s 2021 budget, 1.1 billion euros was allocated to economic support measures during the second quarantine and through June 2021. This includes an extension of wage subsidies, job search allowances, interest expense compensation, soft loans to businesses, and funds for the acquisition of COVID-19 vaccines. Additional targeted measures were later introduced including extra subsidies for businesses with the largest drop in sales due to national quarantine restrictions."  Archive Link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620221203/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  ________________________________________________  Quote: Emergency tax loans, with deferred taxes or paying them by instalments under an agreed schedule, with no interest applied.    • The suspension of the recovery of tax arrears on the basis of reasonableness criteria.    • Tax-payers’ exemption from paying fines and interest on late tax obligations.    • The possibility to defer the payment of the personal income tax.    • Increase the guarantee ceiling of the Agricultural Loan Guarantee Fund and INVEGA by EUR 500 million and extend the conditions for granting guarantees. To compensate between 50 % and 100 % of the actually paid interest amount for small and medium-sized enterprises.    • Make it possible for the business to defer charges for electricity and natural gas to be paid to UAB Ignitis or pay them by installments.    • Recommendation to exempt tax payers from commercial real estate and land taxes.    • Recommendation that municipalities should be given a possibility to defer public utility payments and payments for heat energy or pay them by installments."  Archive link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620222332/https://eimin.lrv.lt/en/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus/important-information-for-business-on-coronavirus-1
notes_C2: No change in policy  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614105002/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1
notes_H3: On 23rd of February 2021  NVSC stated that over the past week its tracers on average reached 90% of people tested positive for COVID-19 within 24 hours to interview them about route of infection and contacts.(17)    From 29th of March 2021, the designated dashboard provides an interactive map of COVID-19 outbreaks (two or more related cases), based on tracing conducted by epidemiologists at the National Center for Public Health: https://nvsc.lrv.lt/lt/naujienos/sukurtas-interaktyvus-covid-19-protrukiu-zemelapis    http://web.archive.org/web/20210413095845/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/lithuania/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5+Testing&Type=Chapter
notes_E1: Quote: "Key Policy Responses as of June 3, 2021    FISCAL  On March 16, 2020, the government announced an overall fiscal package of 2.5 billion euros (5 percent of 2019 GDP). Within this amount, spending measures by the General Government amounts to 1.1 billion euros (2.3 percent of 2019 GDP) which includes (i) additional funds for the healthcare system and emergency management (500 million euros), (ii) additional funds for caring for the sick and disabled, including for parents of school children who now need to stay home, support for the self-employed (250 million euros), and wage subsidies for employees in affected firms (250 million euros), and (iii) co-financing of climate change investment projects (about 20 percent of 250 million euros). In addition, the government expanded guarantee schemes, including guarantees for agricultural as well as SME loans by around 1.3 billion euros (2.6 percent of 2019 GDP). Finally, the government increased the borrowing limit by 5 billion euros (10 percent of 2019 GDP)."  Also, "On May 7, 2020, the government approved to support an economic recovery for businesses and households. The package includes extended wage subsidies for persons returning from downtime or unemployment (380 million euros), job search allowances of 200 euros for those who have dropped out of the labor force (265 million euros), an increase in social benefits to pensioners and others (182 million euros), additional funds for the self-employed and for vocational training (15.6 million euros), and an increase in unemployment benefits of 42 euros per benefit. In addition, the universal child benefit of 60 euros has been increased to 100 euros for a period of six months after the end of the national quarantine for families who lost income during the quarantine"  "In the government’s 2021 budget, 1.1 billion euros was allocated to economic support measures during the second quarantine and through June 2021. This includes an extension of wage subsidies, job search allowances, interest expense compensation, soft loans to businesses, and funds for the acquisition of COVID-19 vaccines. Additional targeted measures were later introduced including extra subsidies for businesses with the largest drop in sales due to national quarantine restrictions."  Archive link  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620221203/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C1: Restrictions remain in place (until 31st January)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210124173336/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1
notes_H7: from may 24, the vaccines will be available for people >35 years old. They are free of charge. Are available the AstraZeneca, Moderna, Janssen and Pfizer vaccines.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210526222330/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/vaccination
notes_C3: From the 19th of April, cultural events will be permitted up to 150 spectators.  Non-cultural/commercial events that do not fulfil the inclusion criteria are not permitted.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210502205318/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1  https://web.archive.org/web/20210502205318/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1
notes_C8: Passengers FROM ALL THE COUNTRIES (listed or not listed as affected) travelling on international routes organised and operated by carriers as regular, special and charter services by all modes of transport must complete a QUESTIONNAIRE and present the confirmation of the completed electronic form (QR code) to the carrier before boarding the vehicle.  •    Those arriving in Lithuania from ALL COUNTRIES by their own transport until the moment of crossing the border of the Republic of Lithuania must fill in the QUESTIONNAIRE and provide confirmation of the completed electronic questionnaire (QR code) to NVSC specialists or other officials at the border checkpoint or passenger checkpoint.  People must be tested in the arrival and, despite the result, they must self-isolate per 10 days.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210526220335/https://nvsc.lrv.lt/en/information-on-covid-19/for-arrivals-from-abroad/list-of-countries-affected-by-covid-19-and-requirements-valid-from-24-to-30-may
notes_C4: Lithuania’s government on Wednesday declared a three-week lockdown starting on Nov.7 (extended end of November), to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus which has accelerated in recent weeks in the Baltic nation.    Public groups of more than 5 people will be banned and no more than 10 people will be allowed at marriages or funerals.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201114114424/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-lithuania/update-1-lithuania-to-enter-three-week-covid-lockdown-on-saturday-idINL8N2HQ525    See also for official communication:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201202092539/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/news/covid-19-related-restrictions-updated-on-25-november-2020
notes_C6: No change in policy  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614105002/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1
notes_H6: From the 21st of February, wearing facemasks will not be mandatory in outdoor public spaces as long as people can remain at least 2 metres apart.
notes_H8: https://web.archive.org/web/20210614105002/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1
notes_C5: No change in policy. Social distancing and hygiene measures are in force on public transport.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210614105002/https://koronastop.lrv.lt/en/covid-19-related-restrictions-1

name: Luxembourg
notes_H1: Opening of a dedicated Site for information relating to COVID and the states response. Mentioned initially in a facebook post on the 28th of February. Site seems to have gone online on 5th of February. www.gouvernement.lu/coronavirus was the initial site, moving to covid19.lu on the 23rd of March.      https://www.infocrise.lu/fr/web/guest/accueil/-/asset_publisher/uJAlpeXURbmf/content/toutes-les-informations-officielles-et-utiles-regroupe-sur-covid19-lu?inheritRedirect=false&redirect=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.infocrise.lu%2Ffr%2Fweb%2Fguest%2Faccueil%3Fp_p_id%3D101_INSTANCE_uJAlpeXURbmf%26p_p_lifecycle%3D0%26p_p_state%3Dnormal%26p_p_mode%3Dview%26p_p_col_id%3Dcolumn-1%26p_p_col_count%3D1%23article_78291#p_101_INSTANCE_uJAlpeXURbmf
notes_H2: Tests available for those exhibiting symptoms as well as for people without symptoms (as part of the Large Scale Testing program).    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405112232/https://covid19.public.lu/en/testing/faq.html
notes_C7: There is no indication that internal movement is restricted. The requirements to wear a facemask persist, especially on public transit and in public spaces where social distancing cannot be achieved.   http://archive.vn/4jnOQ
notes_E2: With regard to direct taxes, the modalities of the advance tax payments and payment deadlines will be adapted for corporations and self-employed persons. More specifically, legal persons and natural persons carrying out an activity generating trade and business income, agriculture and forestry income, or income from independent professional services, who are experiencing liquidity problems due to the Covid-19 pandemic, can apply for a cancellation of the two first quarterly advance tax payments of the year 2020 (due in March and June 2020). Covered by this measure are (corporate) income and municipal business taxes.    In addition, these same persons may request, for taxes due after 29 February 2020, a payment extension of four months. On this deferral, no interest on late payment will be due and it covers (corporate) income, municipal business, and net wealth taxes.  https://mfin.gouvernement.lu/en/actualites.gouvernement%2Ben%2Bactualites%2Btoutes_actualites%2Bcommuniques%2B2020%2B03-mars%2B17-mesures-fiscales-covid19.html
notes_C2: No policy change. Businesses are allowed to open but must comply with sanitary measures and limits on store capacity.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210208183059/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/shops.html
notes_H3: First case of COVID on March 1st has been reported and the a team of sanitary inspectors have "retracer son entourage", traced whom he has been in contact with. https://web.archive.org/save/https://coronavirus.gouvernement.lu/en/communications-officielles.gouvernement%2Ben%2Bactualites%2Btoutes_actualites%2Bcommuniques%2B2020%2B03-mars%2B01-premier-cas-corona.html
notes_E1: No policy change.     More details here:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130210640/https://meco.gouvernement.lu/dam-assets/dossiers/Neistart-Letzebuerg-Tableau-Mesures.pdf
notes_C1: Schools are open but sanitary measures apply. Masks are required for all adults and for students from cycle 2, protective and sanitary measures must be observed, and recreation breaks or circulation of pupils must be staggered.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405111126/https://men.public.lu/fr/support/coronavirus/faq-fr.html
notes_H7: In Luxembourg, vaccine availability is universal. People over 16 years old are eligible to register for the vaccine waiting list, although priority will be given to the oldest people. Residents aged between 30 and 54 have the opportunity to register online to get the Vaxzevria (Astrazeneca) vaccine. According to Prime Minister Xavier Bettel, more than 31.000 people have already registered for this waitlist.     Links:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210508095540/https://covid19.public.lu/en/vaccination.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210508095738/https://delano.lu/d/detail/news/covid-further-easing-restrictions/214519
notes_C3: Re-opening of sports, culture & cults under strict sanitary conditions. Bars and restaurants   remain closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210119032645/https://covid19.public.lu/dam-assets/covid-19/toolbox/nouvelles-mesures/affiche/11-01-2021/10206-DISA-Cov19-Mesures-Jan21-A4-EN.pdf
notes_C8: “Measures concerning the entry into Luxembourg of third-county nationals” were updated on the 21st August. “Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, the ban on the entry of third-country nationals into the territory of Luxembourg is valid until 15 September 2020.” However, there are exceptions, including for diplomats, third-country nationals travelling for the purpose of study, and healthcare professionals, health researchers, and elderly care professionals. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200902223324/https://guichet.public.lu/en/actualites/2020/aout/11-nouvelles-mesures-entree-ressortissant-tiers.html
notes_C4: Up to 150 people are allowed to attend events. Mask-wearing and respecting a minimum distance of 2 meters are mandatory. Gatherings of more than 150 people are only permitted under stricter prevention conditions and with the special dispensation of the health authorities.    Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517101836/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/gatherings.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20210517100731/https://delano.lu/d/detail/news/covid-further-easing-restrictions/214519
notes_C6: The curfew has been lifted. People can now circulate in public at nighttime. However, there are various restrictions that pose limits to quotidian activities such as gatherings or shopping.     Link:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210620082647/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures.html
notes_H6: - in all circumstances for activities open to the public that are circulating and which are taking place in a closed place (e.g. in administrations open to the public, shops and supermarkets), as well as on public transport.  - for any gathering of people that brings together more than 4 people at the same time, either in a closed area or in the open air.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210105163404/https://covid19.public.lu/en/health-protection/protective-measures.html
notes_H8: Curfew in effect from Oct. 30: "between 11 P.M. and 6 A.M., movements of people in the public space are prohibited". According to coding interpretation guideline, record curfew as a level 2.  Sources:   http://web.archive.org/web/20201106013231/https://covid19.public.lu/en/sanitary-measures/curfew.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20201106013947/https://today.rtl.lu/news/luxembourg/a/1604513.html    *Recoding because there has been a curfew in effect since October 30th which by default applies to H8
notes_C5: Wearing a mask is compulsory for staff and travelers.  The front door of the bus remains closed. Travelers are asked to get on and off through the rear doors.  The 1 st row of passenger seats must remain unoccupied to the extent possible.  The driver does not sell tickets (RegioZone).  Travelers are requested to keep their distance    source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200616041859/https://www.mobiliteit.lu/fr/coronavirus-fr/

name: Latvia
notes_H1: 2 websites are dedicated to Covid-19: the Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and covid19.org.lv, both of which provide sufficient information on various aspects of the pandemic.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200608214453/https://spkc.gov.lv/en/for-general-public/covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20200617213719/https://covid19.gov.lv/index.php/en
notes_H2: https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/latvia/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5%20Testing&Type=Section
notes_E2: There some measures for rent payments from public entities. Otherwise creditors might approach lenders on a case by case basis to negotiate debt moratoriums, but no specific programme is in place.   /web/20210501143322/https://covid19.gov.lv/index.php/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ekonomika/atbalsts-uznemejiem-un-darbiniekiem
notes_C2: Starting from June 1st many additional restrictions were eased.   Shopping centres with a total trade area of more than 7000 m2 may also resume full operation, subject to compliance with the requirements of safe trade. The changes also affect the locations where street sales are organised, as the number of traders is no longer limited to 20. From now on, the maximum number of participants at a location of street sale is determined by the municipalities in their administrative territory, maintaining the requirement to ensure an epidemiologically safe shopping environment (2-metre distance and obligatory use of face masks), as well as controlling and reducing the risk of the Covid-19 infection.  From 1 June, individual service providers who have been vaccinated against Covid-19 or have recovered from the virus will be allowed to work on site. In order to prevent hairdressers, manicure and pedicure professionals, and podiatrists from having to interrupt the provision of services, the vaccination must be completed by 1 September 2021.  From 15 June, more restrictions are planned to be eased on gatherings and receiving services for people who have recovered from Covid-19 or have been vaccinated. It is planned that, upon presentation of a certificate, it will be possible to participate in public outdoor and indoor events, visit sports clubs, restaurants, film concerts, and receive other services in person without wearing masks or having to observe physical distancing.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607080929/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607082252/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/aktualites/percentage-vaccinated-population-growing-restrictions-will-be-eased-gatherings-and
notes_H3: There is a voluntary contact tracing app available, however its not mandatory to use.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201014154613/https://www.baltictimes.com/around_40_000_people_have_downloaded_latvia_s_covid-19_contact_tracing_app/
notes_E1: No changes (support has been limited to those sectors, which are affected).   https://web.archive.org/web/20210621104440/https://covid19.gov.lv/index.php/atbalsts-sabiedribai/ekonomika/atbalsts-uznemejiem-un-darbiniekiem
notes_C1: Ministry of Health  Similarly, in order to reduce the spread of the virus and it would be time for epidemiologists to observe fluctuations in the number of infections, the government decided that pupils in grades 7-12 would learn remotely.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/aktualitates/uz-laiku-jaierobezo-cilveku-kustiba-arpus-katra-sociala-burbula
notes_H7: Starting from May3, 2021, everyone can register to receive a vaccine.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210509180545/https://covid19.gov.lv/aktualites/no-sodienas-ikviens-latvijas-pieaugusais-iedzivotajs-vietne-manavakcinalv-var-izveleties
notes_C3: As of June 15, public events are available for people who are vaccinated, recovered or tested negative. Public events organisation is still subject to epidemiological requirements.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210621102402/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures
notes_C8: As of June 15 entry to Latvia is allowed for tourism too. Returning from abroad is still subject to self-isolation.   A test must be taken when returning to Latvia from high-risk and very high-risk countries. The Covid-19 test does not need to be taken when returning from the EU, the EEA, Switzerland, the United Kingdom and low-risk third countries.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621102402/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures
notes_C4: Restrictions have also been eased on the organisation of certain private events, allowing gatherings of up to 20 people outdoors and up to 10 people indoors for baptism and funeral ceremonies, regardless of the number of households. It is also allowed to organise services dedicated to the memory of the deceased, subject to ensuring that epidemiological safety requirements are observed at the place where such services are held: a distance of 2 metres must be observed, the use of face masks is obligatory, and gatherings must be limited. Until now, two households (up to 10 people) were allowed to meet or visit each other outdoors. The new rules allow two households to gather indoors for private events of up to 10 people and outdoors for up to 20 people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607082546/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/aktualites/increase-vaccination-rates-and-arrival-summer-allow-us-take-next-step-reducing-covid-19
notes_C6: No specific measures implemented. There are currently no plans to restrict daytime movement. The clarifications in the security measures for the holiday season approved by the Cabinet of Ministers do not restrict freedom of movement. Public transport will continue to run and people are encouraged to take the opportunity to spend time outdoors in nature.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210111214926/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/during-holiday-season-period-silence-must-be-observed-reducing-contact-and-refraining  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111220036/https://mk.gov.lv/en/aktualitates/government-conceptually-agrees-new-years-eve-curfew
notes_H6: - From 24 October mouth and nose covering should be worn in any public place.  - Mouth and nose covering should be used during indoor cultural events. The covering can not be removed if you are sitting in a fixed, personalized seat at a cultural event.   - A homemade mask should be made of at least three layers of suitable material (cotton, nylon, etc.) and have ties to secure it behind the ears or behind the head  - May not be used for children under 13 years of age and people who cannot use it for medical reasons, such as functional impairment    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026215815/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures
notes_H8: Authorities in Latvia have extended the nation's COVID-19-related state of emergency until April 6 amid increasing infection rates in the country. No curfew in place.   Link: https://archive.ph/XTHUs
notes_C5: "Nose and mouth coverings must be used (a self-made or purchased mask, scarf, shawl, and other solutions are accepted). Hygiene measures must be observed." Those who have tested positive for Covid-19 must not use public transport. Neither should those who have been in contact with a Covid-19 positive citizen. https://web.archive.org/web/20200617214914/https://covid19.gov.lv/en/support-society/how-behave-safely/covid-19-control-measures

name: Macao
notes_H2: Nucleic acid tests are open for online reservation for cross-boundary travellers starting from 10am on 15 July.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201116151921/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20GONHgtC;jsessionid=1B46FD21318D0ECC755125E34F5001FD.app02?0
notes_E2: The Government announces subsidy for a period of three months of all electricity and water tariffs for the housing units of Macao residents ; rebate of 70 percent of the personal income tax for the fiscal year 2018 paid by each Macao resident liable for such tax; waiver of waive property tax levied on all housing units of Macao residents for the year 2019. Links: https://web.archive.org/web/20200521223141/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20BMQ4RQa;jsessionid=D8FFCC6F49F88A8F26D204A136AEEE98.app03?0 ; https://web.archive.org/save/http://finance.eastmoney.com/a/202002141383532963.html
notes_C2: public services resume as normal  https://web.archive.org/web/20201118121305/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20Bbsudzy?1
notes_H3: 'In response to the first case of new coronavirus infection in Australia, the SAR government has launched and deployed anti-epidemic work in an all-round way, taking necessary measures including implementing heat detection at ports and filling in entry declaration forms to fully respond to, prevent and control the epidemic.'  https://web.archive.org/web/20200403075243/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AV4AiJe;jsessionid=AE280AF2AFB28803D49190392A304F09.app03?0
notes_E1: Apart from the e-voucher, there is a 600-pataca medical voucher to every permanent resident, extra 1-month's relief to means-tested fragile families. Source:    http://web.archive.org/web/20200928182541/http://www.gov.cn/xinwen/2020-06/24/content_5521649.htm  The Government would allocate an e-voucher – with a value of 3,000 patacas – to each resident. Such e-vouchers would have to be used within a three-month period and would be accepted only in certain restaurants, retail outlets and shopping centres.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200521223141/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20BMQ4RQa;jsessionid=D8FFCC6F49F88A8F26D204A136AEEE98.app03?0.   [second round of income support was announced on 8 April, see below]
notes_C1: Primary school completely resumes. So far, all schools and universities in Macau have resumed, with social distancing and other public health precautions in place. Kindergarten, which is not part of the K-12, remains suspended.      https://web.archive.org/web/20200520135120/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20EKbDD24;jsessionid=A76EFED4B05FE6FC79888F499FE2EFCC.app01?0
notes_H7: Macau's second stage of vaccine roll-out started on 22 Feb 2021: all Macau residents are eligible to get a jab. The government calls all eligible people to book a slot.    https://archive.vn/2ZPEF  https://archive.vn/W2AER
notes_C3: Due to the resent small outbreaks in mainland China, Macao government on 8 June called off a local major exhibition planned to be hold from 11 to 20 June.    https://archive.vn/5zYRf
notes_C8: non-resident workers from Zhuhai eligible for exemption from 14-day Macao medical observation.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200520134950/https://news.gov.mo/detail/en/N20EJuYISW;jsessionid=A369E9ABEE675477120F48351381622C.app02?0
notes_H6: Bus, ferry, taxi passengers must wear facial masks. Visitors to casinos or other entertainment venues must wear facial masks. Source:     http://web.archive.org/web/20200928200710/https://www.gov.mo/zh-hans/global-search/page/4/?q=%E6%88%B4%E5%8F%A3%E7%BD%A9%E6%8C%87%E5%BC%95

name: Morocco
notes_H1: No change in policy. The Ministry of Health website (http://www.covidmaroc.ma/) has public information on the virus, safety tips, and statistics.    Bulletin example: https://web.archive.org/web/20210210180925/http://www.covidmaroc.ma/Documents/SITUATION_Epid%C3%A9mie_COVID-19/B%20u%20l%20l%20e%20t%20i%20n%20%C3%A9%20p%20i%20d%20%C3%A9%20m%20i%20o%20l%20o%20g%20i%20q%20u%20e%20N%209-06082020.pdf
notes_H2: If you are exhibiting signs or symptoms of COVID-19, please contact the Moroccan Ministry of Health’s hotline at +212 (0)8-0100-4747. Assistance is available in English, French or Arabic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201121090354/https://ma.usembassy.gov/25161/
notes_C7: A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Regional or local authorities may put into place (sometimes with little notice) travel or other restrictions aimed at stopping the spread of COVID-19.  Individuals entering or departing from the Casablanca city limits must have a letter of permission issued by Moroccan authorities. In Casablanca, there is an evening curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Those who circulate within Casablanca during these hours must have proper authorization from local authorities.    Is a curfew in place? There is a curfew in Casablanca between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: There is no evidence that the previous debt/contract relief was extended beyond the end of March 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419160858/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C2: On December 21, the Government of Morocco announced additional restrictions aimed at stopping the spread of COVID-19.  The measures will take effect on Wednesday, December 23 and will remain in place for three weeks. The new measures include the following:  A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am;  A daily closing time for restaurants, cafes, shops, and supermarkets of 8:00 pm;  The closure of all restaurants and cafes in Agadir, Casablanca, Marrakech, and Tangier; and  A ban on all public and private gatherings and parties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H3: no reliable source found
notes_E1: There is no evidence that the previous income support was extended beyond the end of March 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210419160858/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C1: Partially open; source: /web/20210623042552/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H7: government of Morocco approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use; vaccines available in Morocco are AstraZeneca (UK), Sinopharm (China), and Sputnik V (Russia); source: /web/20210623042902/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/?ftag=MSF0951a18
notes_C3: nationwide curfew in place between the hours of 11:00 PM and 4:30 AM; source: /web/20210623042902/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/?ftag=MSF0951a18
notes_C8: Government reopens borders to 67 visa-exempt countries with some restrictions. Citizens of those countries cleared to travel to Morocco without a visa will be allowed entry, provided that they have an express invitation from a Morocco company or a confirmed hotel reservation.(MSN News, 14.09.2020).    All travellers planning to fly to Morocco must have valid negative Covid-19 test results issued no more than 48 hours before their flight.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200925052707/https://travelbans.org/africa/morocco/
notes_C4: nationwide curfew in place between the hours of 11:00 PM and 4:30 AM; source: /web/20210623042902/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/?ftag=MSF0951a18
notes_C6: A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am. . In Casablanca, there is an evening curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Those who circulate within Casablanca during these hours must have proper authorization from local authorities.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: The use of masks is mandatory.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201019012009/https://ma.usembassy.gov/25161/  Also see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201019005808/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/morocco/coronavirus
notes_H8: All age groups are required to stay at home in cities and districts that are under curfew. Now the curfew is nationwide. A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am. Thus, that requires elderly people to stay at home as well in these hours by default.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: nationwide curfew in place between the hours of 11:00 PM and 4:30 AM; who are vaccinated can move freely after 11:00 PM; restrictions on intercity or interstate travel; source: /web/20210623042902/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/?ftag=MSF0951a18

name: Monaco
notes_H1: From 9 am tomorrow, Friday 6 March, the COVID-19 Call Centre, a telephone information service, will take over, staffed by a dedicated team from the Department of Health Affairs (DASA), first aiders from the Monaco Red Cross and a medical supervisor.    Monegasque nationals, residents and employees can contact the centre to discuss any questions they may have about COVID-19 by calling 92 05 55 00. The line will be open every day from 9 am to 6 pm. The centre can also be emailed at the following address: covid19@gouv.mc .    The Prince’s Government would like to remind readers that in the event of any doubt, particularly if you have visited an area where the virus is circulating and have significant symptoms consistent with the disease (fever, cough, breathing difficulties, etc.) you should contact the emergency services directly on 18 or 112.    To avoid infecting others, people with symptoms are asked not to visit their normal doctor.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201203123750/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/CORONAVIRUS-Prince-s-Government-to-expand-COVID-19-telephone-information-service
notes_H2: PCR test is available to anyone: "If I am not in one of these 4 cases, but still want to do a PCR test, I can go to a laboratory in town. My test will be reimbursed with or without a prescription". Also, "It is recommended to do an antigen test in the following cases: If you want to be tested, without being identified as a high or low risk contact case, If you have had symptoms for less than 4 days."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115163618/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-tests-diagnostics/
notes_C7: Curfew in place from 8pm to 6am, but no restrictions on internal movement otherwise.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409141322/https://covid19.mc/en/thematiques/sorties/
notes_E2: No measures in place.
notes_C2: As of June 12, teleworking is no longer compulsory but it remains strongly recommended in the private and public sectors.     Restaurants, theaters, shops, and casinos are allowed to open with additional restrictions in place. Restaurants are allowed to open for service from 3 PM to 12 AM and tables must be limited to 8 people. Theaters and casinos can open to the public until 12 AM at 70% capacity. Shops are open but must respect the curfew hours and limit capacity to  one person per 4 m².      Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210614090855/https://covid19.mc/en/measures-from-12-06-21/
notes_H3: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126123014/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/jai-ete-en-contact-avec-une-personne-positive-a-la-covid-19-que-faire/
notes_E1: Employees who have been laid off and who usually receive a gross base salary of less than or equal to EUR 2,075.16 for 169 hours per month are entitled to their full net salary. Employees earning a gross base salary of between EUR 2,075.17 and EUR 2,571.43, for 169 hours per month, will be entitled to the safeguard clause at a rate of EUR 1,800.00. In the case of higher salaries, a cap has been set at 4.5 times the minimum wage.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409144615/https://covid19.mc/en/thematiques/travail/
notes_C1: " Alesi    On 7 September 2020, Minister of State H.E. Mr Pierre Dartout visited Lycée Albert I upon the return of Year 13 (Terminale) pupils, who will sit the newly reformed General Baccalaureate examinations next June.    H.E. the Minister of State was accompanied by Mr Patrice Cellario, Minister of the Interior, and Ms Isabelle Bonnal, Director of Education, Youth and Sport.    During the early afternoon, H.E. the Minister of State, Mgr David, Archbishop of Monaco, Mr Patrice Cellario and Ms Isabelle Bonnal were also keen to meet students and staff at the François d’Assise-Nicolas Barré primary school.    After witnessing the return of the five-year-old (Grande Section) nursery pupils, H.E. the Minister of State chatted to Year 2 (CP) and Year 5 (CM1) pupils and teaching staff.    During his discussions at the Principality’s schools, H.E. the Minister of State asked pupils how they felt about returning to school this year. They told him that they were happy to be able to get back to their lessons and to be with their friends again.    In the course of his visits, H.E. the Minister of State also welcomed the rigorous compliance with health guidelines on the part of all pupils and staff.    This September marks the beginning of a new school year for the 518 teachers and 5,774 pupils enrolled in Monaco’s schools."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201226070954/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/2020-2021-school-year-begins
notes_H7: Anyone over 18 can now receive the vaccine. Vaccine: Pfizer    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210606133625/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-vaccins/
notes_C3: Public gatherings are limited to six people, but places of worship are allowed to remain open with a limit of 1 person per 6 square meters.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_C8: Travelers are required to quarantine unless they are able to show proof of a negative PCR test taken at most 72 hours prior to arrival. In the event of a positive PCR, or if the person refuses to be tested, the quarantine will be maintained.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409142722/https://covid19.mc/en/i-come-from-abroad/
notes_C4: Due to the worldwide COVID-19 epidemic, Monaco has imposed severe restrictions on public life: A curfew has been in effect since Tuesday (17 March). People are only allowed to leave their homes for justified purposes, while restaurants, museums, and non-essential shops are closed throughout the country. Persons entering the country from risk areas must undergo a 14-day domestic quarantine.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201216070845/https://global-monitoring.com/gm/page/events/epidemic-0002086.Eg778z0AGwE9.html?lang=en
notes_C6: Curfew in place from 8pm to 6am, with exceptions for work, health and family reasons.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_H6: Masks must be worn in all public spaces, and in all closed spaces open to the public and shared areas of private spaces.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210126122206/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_H8: No policy updates. Measures introduced on November 1st 2020 will remain in place until March 19 at least.   A curfew remains in place (7pm-6am).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316061327/https://covid19.mc/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_C5: The Monegasque Bus Company (CAM) is resuming normal service for all buses, including the Bateau Bus (water bus). The only exceptions to this are the night services, N1 and N2, which will remain closed.     The following health measures apply:    The wearing of masks is mandatory on public transport  Tickets can be purchased on board, on condition that you pay the exact amount  Tickets are also available from the 12 automatic ticket machines located throughout the Principality, and the shop at 22/24 Rue du Gabian is open from 8.30 am to 4.30 pm Monday to Friday  The following procedures continue to apply:    Buses will be disinfected twice a day  Dispensers of hydro-alcoholic gel have been installed in every bus  Buses will stop at every stop (to avoid the need for people to press the buttons)  Passenger information showing the direction in which you should walk when boarding, leaving and while on the bus, is displayed on the floor and doors of the bus  It is forbidden to get off the bus  at the front    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

name: Moldova
notes_H1: Public Information campaign appears organised with posters giving specific advice and instructions. https://web.archive.org/web/20200727231717/https://msmps.gov.md/minister/comunicare/covid-19/
notes_H2: COVID-19 testing is available at both public and private medical laboratories.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426235106/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: No policy change.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210614213831/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/474396/moldova-covid-19-related-international-entry-and-domestic-restrictions-remain-in-effect-nationwide-as-of-may-3-update-17
notes_E2: Banks are allowed to instigate payment holidays until June 30. Income tax payments have been suspended. https://www.ebrd.com/where-we-are/moldova/overview.html;https://www.ebrd.com/where-we-are/moldova/overview.html
notes_C2: On April 30th, the previous national state of emergency was declared unconstitutional and has been lifted. This state of emergency was meant to last from 1 April until 30 May 2021. This included a curfew between 11 p.m. and 5 a.m. in Chisinau and Balti cities, and banning people’s presence in parks, forests, playgrounds, and sport or leisure areas in these cities. Curfews are no longer in place in Chisinau and Balti. In designated "red code" areas where infection rates are high, individuals are allowed to leave their homes only for essential purposes.     The National Public Health Commission also convened a meeting. CNESP members have mandated the territorial commissions to take the decision to establish a state of emergency in public health at local level in case the incidence of cases exceeds 100 infections per 100 thousand citizens.    Under existing directives, public institutions and private businesses are limited to operating with no more than 30 percent of their staff working on-site, with the remainder working remotely. Most businesses in Moldova are permitted to operate provided they adhere to strict health and safety measures, though all public offices close at 16:00 daily, and bars and restaurants must close from 20:00-07:00. Markets are permitted to operate between the hours of 07:00-15:00; shopping malls must close by 18:00. Concert halls and nightclubs remain closed until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210504064411/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/474396/moldova-covid-19-related-international-entry-and-domestic-restrictions-remain-in-effect-nationwide-as-of-may-3-update-17  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504062617/https://www.moldova.org/en/there-will-be-snap-elections-constitutional-court-cancelled-the-state-of-emergency-the-president-announced-a-ballot-date/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405143119/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/01/21002456  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405150436/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/04/02/21002488  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405144922/https://www.moldova.org/en/state-of-emergency-in-moldova-controlling-coronavirus-infections-or-parliaments-dissolution/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405142342/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H3: Moldova has asked people who may had contact an infected person to self-isolate at home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210426235106/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_E1: "The government will also assist businesses that have suspended their activities (fully or partially) by refunding personal income taxes and social security contributions up to 100%. Those that had to stop their operations due to decision of authorities will receive a subsidy amounting to 100% of their income tax, social security and health contributions, and other compulsory state payments. Persons who have worked for at least nine months at one enterprise and have lost their jobs will be paid from 60 to 80% of their final salary. Banks were also incentivised to delay payment deadlines and/or the amounts of due payments on loans until 30 June."https://www.oecd.org/coronavirus/policy-responses/covid-19-crisis-response-in-eu-eastern-partner-countries/
notes_C1: Schooling is both online and in-person. May 31 marked the end of the academic school year in Moldova and examinations will continue (seemingly in-person) over the course of June. The school-leaving exams in elementary schools, gymnasiums and lyceums were cancelled because of the COVID-19 pandemic.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210614183607/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/06/07/21004051    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614183720/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/05/31/21003861
notes_H7: The third stage of vaccination begins with the immunisation of people in the following areas: processing, distribution and marketing of basic foods; water plants, water treatment, transportation and distribution; power plants, production and transmission of electricity; gas production, transmission and distribution units; units for the production, transport and distribution of medicines and medical devices; transport of people and goods. Also the third stage includes employees of the special telecommunications, radio and national television service; hotel and restaurant workers; hairdressers and employees of body maintenance centers; theater workers; bank employees, postal staff, representatives of religious denominations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210531142128/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/05/11/21003378
notes_C3: A maximum of three people are permitted to gather in public and most public events are prohibited.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210614213831/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/474396/moldova-covid-19-related-international-entry-and-domestic-restrictions-remain-in-effect-nationwide-as-of-may-3-update-17    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614213937/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Effective March 5, 2021, anyone entering Moldova must present a negative COVID-19 test taken within the previous 72 hours or they will be subject to mandatory quarantine for 14 days.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210322184956/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: Gatherings limited to three people or fewer.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210614213831/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/474396/moldova-covid-19-related-international-entry-and-domestic-restrictions-remain-in-effect-nationwide-as-of-may-3-update-17    https://web.archive.org/web/20210614213937/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: Curfews are no longer in place in Chisinau and Balti. In designated "red code" areas where infection rates are high, individuals are allowed to leave their homes only for essential purposes. Persons over 63 years of age must remain in their accommodations except for essential purposes.  The national state of emergency has also been lifted.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210614213831/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/474396/moldova-covid-19-related-international-entry-and-domestic-restrictions-remain-in-effect-nationwide-as-of-may-3-update-17
notes_H6: Face masks required in all public spaces, including on public transport.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210614213937/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H8: The elderly are prioritized for vaccines and persons over 63 years of age must remain in their accommodations except for essential purposes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504064411/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/474396/moldova-covid-19-related-international-entry-and-domestic-restrictions-remain-in-effect-nationwide-as-of-may-3-update-17
notes_C5: Public transport is operating at 50 percent capacity. Facemasks are mandatory in enclosed public spaces and on public transport.   All passengers in public transportation, including bus, train and taxis, must wear a mask. When getting on or off a bus or taxi, passengers should use an alcohol- based hand sanitizer or should wash with soap and water. Hand sanitizer is available on public buses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210504064411/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/474396/moldova-covid-19-related-international-entry-and-domestic-restrictions-remain-in-effect-nationwide-as-of-may-3-update-17  https://web.archive.org/web/20210504063036/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

name: Madagascar
notes_H1: No policy change
notes_H2: Tests readily available at 2 locations, with results available within 24 hours. However, the cost is borne by the individual.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210524194221/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: As announced on May 30, 2021 in a State of Emergency update, domestic flights are allowed as of June 4th. Health screening procedures are in place at airports.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606035011/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: Private sector supported through tax relief and suspension of government fees, but no similar policy applied to households.    See IMF's Policy Response Tracker (https://web.archive.org/web/20210308152023/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#M).
notes_C2: According to the US Embassy, "Local markets are open from 6 AM to 6 PM but only one member of household may run errands.  Bars and night clubs remain closed. Restaurants may operate at half-capacity. For Analamanga, Vakinankaratra, and Haute Matsiatra, a curfew applies from 11 PM to 4 AM."    Certain businesses, such as those in the entertainment industry, remain closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606035011/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
notes_H3: https://web.archive.org/web/20210405085741/https://www.voanews.com/covid-19-pandemic/how-contact-tracers-could-help-control-covid-19
notes_E1: No evidence found that income support extended into May 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606045009/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#M
notes_C1: According to UNESCO school are partially open.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621145656/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H7: The AstraZeneca/CovidShield vaccine is available in limited supply for any individuals 18 and older. Walk-ins are welcome at three sites in the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606035011/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
notes_C3: Gatherings and events are allowed up to 100 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606035011/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: "International flights, previously authorized in and out of Nosy Be, are suspended. "  https://web.archive.org/web/20210524194221/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: As of May 30th, gatherings of over 100 people remain prohibited by the Madagascar State of Emergency.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606035011/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: For Analamanga, Vakinankaratra, and Haute Matsiatra, a curfew applies from 11 PM to 4 AM. Local markets are open from 6 AM to 6 PM but only one member of household may run errands.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210606035011/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: It is mandatory to wear a face mask in all public places, including in shops, parks and streets.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210606035006/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus
notes_H8: For Analamanga, Vakinankaratra, and Haute Matsiatra, a curfew applies from 11 PM to 4 AM.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210621150432/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: Recommended only to use public transport for essential reasons, but public transport is still running.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210524194221/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/

name: Mexico
notes_H1: #QuedateEnCasa: https://web.archive.org/web/20201112133725/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/ Since 24th March: https://web.archive.org/web/20200920220127/https://mexico.as.com/mexico/2020/03/25/actualidad/1585105801_984693.html
notes_H2: The Ministry of Health (Health) maintains a list of approved laboratories (only in Spanish) for viral COVID-19 tests. Many local hospitals, clinics, and labs offer private travel tests.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210604023533/https://mx.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: Restrictions on internal movement to be upheld according to "traffic light system" per state   /web/20200611070223/https://www.milenio.com/politica/coronavirus-mexico-10-junio-noticias-covid-19
notes_E2: 3 month loan extensions are available:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210223132720/https://www.gob.mx/covid19medidaseconomicas/acciones-y-programas/creditos-infonavit
notes_C2: highest alert level is Orange which has these restrictions:  In addition to essential economic activities, companies of non-essential economic activities will be allowed to work with 30% of the personnel for their operation, always taking into account the maximum care measures for people with a greater risk of presenting a serious picture of COVID-19, open public spaces will be opened with a reduced capacity (number of people).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226000705/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/semaforo/
notes_H3: According to the report, 555 persons were contacted. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210118023002/https://covid19.cdmx.gob.mx/storage/app/media/Reportes%20CSP/CS_4_ENERO_compressed.pdf
notes_E1: Government-provided low-interest loans are available:  Credits to support family micro-businesses and self-employed workers in the face of the effects caused by COVID-19  Financing of 25 thousand pesos per business or person, to be paid in three years, including three months of grace.  In other words, the beneficiaries will pay 824 pesos in 33 installments.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210223132600/https://www.gob.mx/covid19medidaseconomicas/acciones-y-programas/apoyos-financieros-a-microempresas-y-trabajadores-independientes
notes_C1: Between 15 Feb and 28 Feb there are 2 regions under Red alert, 21 under Orange alert, 8 under Yellow alert and 1 under Green alert. School activities are allowed under Green alert only.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217220733/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/semaforo/
notes_H7: A,B,C:  On April 6th 2021, National Government updated their report on the national strategy for COVID vaccination which is organised in 5 stages. Stage 3 (general population aged 50-59) was scheduled to start in April but due to delays in the supply of vaccines it has been postponed to start May 2021.   Stage 1: Front line health workers (Dec 2020-Feb 2021)  Stage 2: Rest of health workers and elderly population (aged 60 and over) (Feb 2021-May 2021)  Stage 3: General population aged 50-59 (May 2021-June 2021)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503160048/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/28Abr2021_13h00_PNVx_COVID_19.pdf
notes_C3: In "orange" areas cinemas, theatres, cultural (up to 500 people) and religious events are allowed with a 25% capacity. "Yellow" areas add massive events, nightclubs and bars and increase the permitted capacity to 50%. "Green" areas have no restrictions. Currently, there are no "red" areas.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210413183359/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/semaforo/
notes_C8: "The Mexican government encourages people to continue respecting social distancing measures, washing their hands, and coughing or sneezing in the inner part of the elbow to prevent the spread of COVID-19.  A variety of prevention measures can be found at https://coronavirus.gob.mx  For U.S. citizens who have participated in higher risk activities or think that they may have been exposed before or during a trip, the CDC encourages people to take the following extra precautions to protect others for 14 days after arrival:  Stay home as much as possible.  Avoid staying around people at higher risk for severe illness from COVID-19.  Consider getting tested for COVID-19.  In the United States, quarantine requirements and recommendations may vary by state.  Therefore, travelers should review an individual state’s entry requirements before traveling."      http://web.archive.org/web/20200927195013/https://mx.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: No specific restrictions on gatherings in levels green, yellow, or orange. There are capacity restrictions on public spaces within levels yellow and orange.     https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/semaforo/  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://mx.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: "Is a curfew in place? [Yes]  Curfews are not universal.  Restrictions vary based on state and/or city.  Please see the “Local Resources” section for curfew-specific information below."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210312165454/https://mx.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: National Government recommends use of facial covering in asymptomatic people when it is not possible to maintain a safe distance from other people (public transport)  https://web.archive.org/web/20210411061502/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/prevencion/  "Several states and municipalities have imposed curfews and movement restrictions on non-essential activities and have required citizens to wear masks when outside the home."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210417161111/https://mx.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H8: On March 15, the National Government gave a list of 13 recommendations for elderly people. Recommendations involved keeping social distancing, avoiding physical contact, washing hand frequently, trusting official sources, etc. Interestingly, one recommendation was to avoid facial covering if there are no symptoms of the disease. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213224027/https://www.infobae.com/america/mexico/2020/03/16/estas-son-las-medidas-de-prevencion-para-cuidar-a-los-adultos-mayores-y-evitar-contagios-de-coronavirus/
notes_C5: Is public transportation operating? [Yes]  Some states and municipalities have implemented additional transportation restrictions  https://archive.vn/6kDtz

name: Mali
notes_H1: In addition, social, sporting, cultural and political groupings of more than 50 people such as weddings, baptisms, funerals were banned.  Public, private and denominational schools, including madarsas will be closed for three weeks  https://web.archive.org/web/20200408211603/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/mali-suspends-flights-from-covid-19-hit-countries-/1769908
notes_H2: "Testing is available for symptomatic people and travelers. No strong evidence of widespread testing capacity; in the latest situation report, ""low detection in community"" is listed under gaps and urgent challenges (page 9). Also, the laboratories listed under the Laboratory section (page 9) are primarily located in the capital city of Bamako.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517010847/https://reliefweb.int/report/mali/rapport-de-situation-covid-19-au-mali-03-au-09-mai-2021-n-153    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517003800/https://covid19-ml.org/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210517000259/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: THere is no information on internal movement after the curfew being lifted.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.worldaware.com/covid-19-alert-mali-lifts-nationwide-curfew-may-10
notes_E2: The three-month exemption (starting from May) would have expired in August and there is no indication that this was renewed. See https://web.archive.org/web/20201109002858/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C2: https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/mali-declares-10-day-emergency-to-fight-covid-19/2082011#
notes_H3: http://malijet.com/a_la_une_du_mali/241897-covid-19-bonne-nouvelle-baisse-du-nombre-de-nouvelles-contaminat.html
notes_E1: It does not seem like the measures were extended up until now. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20201109002858/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C1: https://web.archive.org/web/20210517002518/https://data.humdata.org/visualization/covid19-humanitarian-operations/?c=MLI
notes_H7: Mali's government says it has chosen to use the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine in its plan to initially immunise 4.2 million people. Health minister Fanta Siby said that the vaccination would first target medical staff, the elderly and those with co-morbidities. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406040809/https://www.africanews.com/2021/01/22/mali-picks-astrazeneca-covid-19-vaccine-to-begin-vaccination-april//
notes_C3: Correct link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210321190255/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/435086/mali-domestic-covid-19-restrictions-remain-mostly-unchanged-as-of-jan-26-update-8
notes_C8: The Government of Mali has implemented enhanced screening and quarantine measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19.  Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to go into effect with little or no advanced notice.
