notes_H6: Masks to be worn by all, including any staff present. Those exercising or participating in sports are excluded.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210517231346/https://covid19.moph.gov.qa/EN/Precautions-for-lifting-restrictions/Gatherings/Pages/Social-Gatherings.aspx
notes_H8: ‘The elderly are the most vulnerable to COVID-19 and have been advised to avoid going out unless absolutely necessary. People should still visit elderly people if necessary, but exercise caution and follow proper hygiene principles.’  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405163048/https://www.gco.gov.qa/en/preventative-measures/
notes_C5: No change in policy, as of 28 May, "Increasing metro capacity to 30%, continuing bus services at 50% capacity. "  https://web.archive.org/web/20210614083051/https://www.gco.gov.qa/en/preventative-measures/

name: Romania
notes_H1: Starting on 25/02/2020, an online information campaign was launched on the official Government of Romania Facebook page on the "Prevention and limitation of eventual infection with coronavirus". New, updated information has since been provided daily on the facebook page (https://web.archive.org/web/20200812130651/https://www.facebook.com/guv.ro)  On the 24/02/2020, this campaign was announced: "The information campaign of the population regarding the infection with COVID-19 will be extended, as well as the individual and collective prevention measures which should be taken and a daily newscast will be drafted regarding the development at international level and possible additional measures taken by the Romanian authorities" (https://web.archive.org/web/20200812130808/https://www.nineoclock.ro/2020/02/24/pm-designate-orban-urges-romanians-to-learn-about-coronavirus-from-official-sources-only/)
notes_H2: The Romanian Ministry of Health provides the list of accredited facilities in Romania certified for RT-PCT COVID-19 testing, these facilities prioritizes tests for hospitalized patients, individuals suspected of being infected with COVID-19 and individuals who are in a high-risk group. Depending on their availability, they may perform testing on demand and may set the cost of the tests performed on demand. The cost of COVID-19 testing on demand varies between $70 – $100.   LFD tests are available for everyone asymptomatic.      https://archive.vn/qnADk   https://web.archive.org/web/20210621222056/https://www.nhsinform.scot/translations/languages/romanian/illnesses-and-conditions/coronavirus-covid-19-romanian
notes_C7: According to Order 29/14.05.2021, starting with 15.05, the for traffic persons outside the home during the night was removed.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210516190812/https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA3dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjEl/MkYwNSUyRjE0JTJGMTMyNjA3OV8xMzI2/MDc5X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtbnJfLTI5/LWRpbi0xNF8wNV8yMDIxLnBkZiZoYXNo/PTRlNGYwNDk5ZmZlMzVhMmU1YjA4OWI5ZDMzZDg3YWVk.pdf
notes_E2: On 22nd of October, the government approved the application of the simplified alternative procedure for granting payment rescheduling for a maximum of 12 months. Beneficiaries of the simplified staggering facility are all taxpayers. According to Emergency Ordinance 69/14.05.2020, the authorities have adopted fiscal measures to help taxpayers overcome the problems caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (granting bonuses, extension of the deadline for submitting the Single Declaration, tax facilities for incentives and bonuses granted by the employer from the salary fund for the period of emergency to employees whose activity involves risk of infection with SARS-CoV-2, bonuses regarding the annual building tax and the monthly building tax, cancellation of ancillary payment obligations.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210315184933/https://archive.fo/OJIQT and https://web.archive.org/web/20210315185046/https://archive.fo/hVM21
notes_C2: According to the Decision no.293/10.03.21, the organization and development of activity in cinemas, performance institutions and / or concerts are allowed with the participation of the public up to 50% of the maximum capacity of the space, if the incidence accumulated in the last 14 days of cases in the county / locality is less than or equal to 1.5 / 1,000 inhabitants. Also, the activity of restaurants and cafes inside hotels, boarding houses or other accommodation units is allowed without exceeding 50% of the maximum capacity of the space and in the time interval 6.00-22.00, in the counties / localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is less than or equal to 1.5 / 1,000 inhabitants, not exceeding 30% of the maximum capacity of the space.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322062833/https://archive.fo/TWKy02JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf
notes_H3: An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr
notes_E1: A Government Emergency Ordinance (GEO 30/2020) has been published, outlining social protection measures during the state of emergency due to COVID-19. The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 come into force on 21 March 2020.  'The Labor Code provides that employers can decide unilaterally to suspend individual employment agreements of their employees and place the employees in technical unemployment. The employer is required to ensure from its own funds the payment of a minimum allowance of 75% of the employee’s base salary. However, if the employers meet one of the following criteria, during the state of emergency, the technical unemployment allowance can be supported by the Unemployment Insurance Budget up to the limit of 75% of the average gross salary provided for under the law for the social insurance budget for 2020'.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200502180616/https://home.kpmg/ro/en/home/insights/2020/03/social-protection-measures-during-the-state-of-emergency.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20200812125709/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C1: Romania began to reopen schools on 8 February, three months after the Government closed schools throughout the country to limit the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic.    There are 3 scenarios for reopening schools based on the epidemiological situation in each locality:    The green scenario, which applies to towns with low incidence rates of COVID-19, allows all children to return to school.    The yellow scenario, which applies to cities with moderate incidence rates, only kindergarten children and primary school (I-IV grades) pupils return to school, plus those in the eighth and twelfth grades, who have to prepare for the national exams.    The red scenario, which applies in localities with incidence rates of over 3 per 1,000 inhabitants (over a 14-day period), only kindergarten and primary school children return to school.    Students who can’t return to school, either due to the yellow or red scenarios, will continue online courses, which have been going on for most of the first semester.    Currently, the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is over 3 per 1,000 occupants in Timis and Maramures counties, therefore, these counties are in the red scenario.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211716/https://www.romaniajournal.ro/society-people/education/physical-classes-in-schools-resumed-as-of-february-8/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211543/https://www.edu.ro/sites/default/files/ordin%20comun%20nr.%203.235_93_4.02.2021.pdf    https://archive.fo/85fHU
notes_H7: On 15th of March, the third stage of the vaccination program for the general population began. Also, on 15th of March, the National Coordinating Committee for Vaccination Activities against COVID-19 decided to continue the vaccination campaign in Romania will all vaccines against COVID-19, following the analysis of the adverse reaction reports registered in Romania and the recommendations of the European Medicines Agency.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322055714/https://vaccinare-covid.gov.ro/peste-47-000-de-persoane-programate-si-peste-350-000-de-persoane-pe-lista-de-asteptare-pentru-etapa-a-iii-a/  and  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322054356/https://stirioficiale.ro/informatii/precizari-privind-vaccinarea-cu-vaccinul-produs-de-compania-oxford-astrazeneca-15-03-2020
notes_C3: Authorities in Romania have eased several domestic COVID-19-related restrictions on June 1 following a significant decrease in infection rates. Among unvaccinated residents, groups of up to eight persons may gather outdoors, overall, Outdoor gatherings are limited to 1,000 persons. Limitations on attendance at indoor gatherings including concerts, weddings and other cultural, leisure, or religious activities, have been lifted provided all the attendees are vaccinated. Gyms, fitness centres, museums, public swimming pools, and restaurants may operate at 70 per cent capacity.   Private events (weddings, baptisms, and birthdays) may accommodate a maximum of 70 guests outdoor, 50 guests indoor, or unlimited guests if those attending are all vaccinated.     https://archive.vn/qnADk   https://archive.vn/vztLy
notes_C8: International Entry RestrictionsUnder most circumstances, only travellers from European Economic Area (EEA) and EU countries are permitted to enter Romania. Exceptions are in place for family members of EEA citizens and residents, individuals travelling for essential work or study, individuals in transit, and individuals travelling for urgent reasons. Authorities keep and regularly update a list of "high-risk" countries. The list of high-risk countries includes Estonia, Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, Cyprus, Sweden, France, Italy, Austria, Belgium, Turkey, and the Netherlands, among others.    Permitted individuals arriving from countries not included on the list of high-risk areas can enter without restriction. Individuals arriving from high-risk countries must provide a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken within the previous 72 hours and self-isolate for 14 days on arrival; this can be reduced to 10 days by testing negative for COVID-19 on day eight of self-isolation. Cross-border workers, transport workers, and individuals in transit remaining in Romania for less than 24 hours are exempt from the quarantine requirements. Individuals who can present proof they have received a full course of vaccination against COVID-19 no less than 10 days ago or have been confirmed positive for COVID-19 and recovered in the previous 90 days are also exempt from the quarantine requirements.    https://archive.vn/vztLy
notes_C4: More than six people gathering is not allowed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210522194324/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/478491/romania-authorities-to-ease-covid-19-related-domestic-restrictions-from-may-15-update-19
notes_C6: According to Order 29/14.05.2021, starting with 15.05, the ban for traffic persons outside the home during the night was removed.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210516190812/https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA3dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjEl/MkYwNSUyRjE0JTJGMTMyNjA3OV8xMzI2/MDc5X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtbnJfLTI5/LWRpbi0xNF8wNV8yMDIxLnBkZiZoYXNo/PTRlNGYwNDk5ZmZlMzVhMmU1YjA4OWI5ZDMzZDg3YWVk.pdf
notes_H6: According to the Decision no.29/14.05.2021 of the Government of Romania, there is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask only in public transport stations, markets, fairs, and areas where rallies, demonstrations, processions, concerts, or other types of meetings, during their conduct, as well as other areas with agglomeration potential.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210516190812/https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA3dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjEl/MkYwNSUyRjE0JTJGMTMyNjA3OV8xMzI2/MDc5X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtbnJfLTI5/LWRpbi0xNF8wNV8yMDIxLnBkZiZoYXNo/PTRlNGYwNDk5ZmZlMzVhMmU1YjA4OWI5ZDMzZDg3YWVk.pdf
notes_H8: On 15th of March, the third stage of the vaccination program for the general population began.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210322055714/https://vaccinare-covid.gov.ro/peste-47-000-de-persoane-programate-si-peste-350-000-de-persoane-pe-lista-de-asteptare-pentru-etapa-a-iii-a/
notes_C5: According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours.  Link: https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf

name: Russia
notes_H1: Prime Minister announces a plan to roll out a public information campaign about the coronavirus progression in the near future. (http://web.archive.org/web/20200505222301/https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/4290524)
notes_H2: tests are available to anyone symptomatic and/or that have contact with positive cases.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Link: https://archive.vn/MxaXR
notes_E2: unemployment benefits increased to the minimum wage level, cash transfers to the unemployed with children, an easing of utility and financial obligations, paid sick leave, and possible delays in loan repayments for those who have lost 30 percent of their income    http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: Employers are advised to keep 30 percent of their employees working remotely. Company managers are free to decide whether their employees should return to the workplace. It is recommended to step up compliance with safety measures at factories and in offices.    Moscow authorities announced a “non-working week” from June 15-19 in an attempt to curb the growing number of infections. After that, businesses are advised to transfer at least 30% of their unvaccinated to working from home.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H3: Service organizations are recommended to use check-in systems for visitors and employees. Visitors must scan the QR code or send an SMS to 7377 at the entrance. Visitors will receive confirmation to enter that must be shown to the security guard at the entrance to the bar. This is necessary to alert visitors about the possible risk of contracting COVID-19. If any visitors are found to have the coronavirus, others will be notified that they must get tested immediately.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_E1: Moscow increased unemployment benefits to support the unemployed. One was able to apply for this payment online without leaving one’s home. The employment service continued to employ people even during the most difficult months. 177 thousand people were provided with jobs in 2020.  The unemployed will shortly begin receiving monthly child support benefits worth of 3,000 rubles. This money will supplement the federal and regional unemployment benefits. Benefits for low-income families with children aged 3 to 7 were raised in Moscow to 7,613 rubles per month. This amount will continue to be paid after the coronavirus pandemic is over. Besides, the city supports low-income families with children, disabled people and other people in need. Many state services can be received online. Mos.ru comprises almost 400 electronic services.  (...)  Automatic extension of social benefits without the need to submit any additional information or apply to the authorities in person  Additional cash transfers for families with children (RUB 5,000 [US$64] a month) for each child under the age of three)  Moratorium on cutting utility services for debts and fines for late payments from April 1 to December 31, 2020  - Social insurance:  Increase in unemployment benefits from RUB 8,000 (US$103) to RUB 12,130 (US$157) a month  Increase in compensation for employees on sick leave—at least one minimum wage RUB 12,130 (US$152) per month until December 31,2020  Increase in social pensions (6.1 percent)  Reduction in social insurance contributions for small and medium-sized businesses from 30  to 15 percent on the share of wages that is above the minimum wage      http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Lessons at Moscow schools were not interrupted even during the pandemic. They managed to establish a distance learning system in just one week in March 2020. Lessons were held in such a way till the end of the academic year.     Schoolchildren without their own gadgets were provided with laptops and tablets: over 18 thousand children received them. The main training resource was Moscow Electronic School. This is an online platform with over 53 thousand scripts of lessons for all classes and all subjects, 1.7 thousand study guides, virtual labs, tests and everything you need for the training process.    All of the universities reporting to the federal ministry (248) have transferred their educational operations to an online format. Several online resources have also been launched: a situation center and a hot line,  a YouTube channel for online broadcasts of meetings and workshops, a Telegram channel @minobrnaukiofficial, and a website for universities (“Keep learning, Keep teaching”) with methodological support. An online platform established by the Agency of Strategic Initiatives, The University 2035, provides additional methodological support to universities.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H7: The City Government is regularly extending the groups of residents who can sign up for vaccination. Currently, these groups include muscovites over 60 (they are at the highest risk of severe COVID-19 and complications), people with chronic conditions, college and university students aged 18 and older. Also, people aged 18 and over who work in the following fields and organisations can get vaccinated. In the future, it will be available to all Moscow residents. The vaccine available is Sputnik V, EpiVacCorona, CoviVac and it's free.       http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C3: Events at theatres, cinemas, concert halls, museums, libraries, stadiums are allowed, but with a limited number of visitors and a special arrangement of seats. The number of viewers must not exceed 50 percent of the site capacity. This measure is meant to ensure social distancing.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: The Government of the Russian Federation banned the entry of foreign nationals, including American citizens, with a few exceptions.  The ban does not apply to: airplane crew members, permanent residents of the Russian Federation who hold a valid residence permit, or transit passengers. In addition, the Russian government allows entry of foreigners for medical treatment or in order to care for relatives in Russia.    The Russian government requires that all foreign travelers present a negative PCR COVID-19 test result upon arrival, dated no later than three days prior to arrival in Russia. The results can be in English and/or digital. Foreign travelers must also complete the attached form (PDF, 210Kb), print, and present to customs upon arrival in Russia  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  Mandatory temperature screenings and other diagnostic and protective measures are being implemented at international airports and other major transit hubs. The Russian Federation no longer requires all travelers to quarantine for 14 days directly after arrival in Russia.  Local jurisdictions set their own rules regarding quarantine requirements for travelers arriving in the country.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: Events at theatres, cinemas, concert halls, museums, libraries, stadiums are allowed, but with a limited number of visitors and a special arrangement of seats. The number of viewers must not exceed 50 percent of the site capacity. This measure is meant to ensure social distancing.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: The Russian Government recommends staying at home if you're feeling sick or if >65 years old or commorbities. Besides that, there's no requirement of home isolation.       http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: It is necessary to wear a face mask and gloves in shops, on public transport and in other crowded places.      http://web.archive.org/web/20210617183930/https://www.mos.ru/en/city/projects/covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191412/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-poor-vulnerable-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191538/https://www.worldbank.org/en/country/russia/brief/covid-19-response-macro-fiscal-russia  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617191754/https://www.themoscowtimes.com/2021/06/17/coronavirus-in-russia-the-latest-news-june-17-a69117  http://web.archive.org/web/20210617192006/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H8: “Sputnik V” vaccine is available without an appointment. Also, “EpiVacCorona” and “Kovivak” vaccines can be used.  Link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210404160929/https://www.dw.com/en/russia-free-mass-coronavirus-vaccinations-and-an-ice-pop-to-boot/a-56532772  and https://web.archive.org/web/20210327232107/https://%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B0.%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BF%D0%BA%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81.%D1%80%D1%84/
notes_C5: No measures found relative to closing transports on the RF's coronavirus official website nor in the news, other than masks are mandatory in some cities.

name: Rwanda
notes_H1: The Rwandan government hastened safety measures against coronavirus and were consistent in reminding Rwanda citizens to be more vigilant on preventing novel coronavirus.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200430191424/https://www.afro.who.int/news/rwanda-hastens-safety-measures-against-novel-coronavirus   https://web.archive.org/web/20200430185258/https://www.primature.gov.rw/index.php?id=40  https://web.archive.org/web/20201120191729/https://www.newvision.co.ug/news/1516513/coronavirus-rwanda-closes-churches-schools
notes_H2: PCR tests can be booked online through Irembo, found here. PCR tests cost $50 (or RWF 47,200). PCR test results are generally delivered within 48 hours via text message (results only) and through the RBC’s COVID-19 Test Results Portal. Only available at two sites in Kigali.    RBC offers rapid antigen testing without appointment at 42 accredited private hospitals/clinics throughout Rwanda. Rapid antigen tests cost $10. Rapid antigen test results are available shortly after the sample is taken and are delivered in person. Available at 45 private hospitals.
notes_C7: Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  – Travel between Kigali and all other provinces has resumed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210611220227/https://rw.usembassy.gov/health-alert-covid-19-information/
notes_E2: 18/03 announced  National Bank of Rwanda announced easing of loan repayment conditions for borrowers affected by the Covid-19: banks are exceptionally allowed to restructure outstanding loans of borrowers temporarily facing cash flow challenges due to Covid-19: https://web.archive.org/web/20200507084813/https://www.cnbcafrica.com/east-africa/2020/03/23/central-bank-of-rwanda-takes-measures-to-mitigate-the-economic-impact-of-covid-19/    The Rwandan Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning has announced a series of tax exemptions as part of efforts to support different sectors of the economy to recover from the effects of COVID 19 pandemic. Pay As You Earn (PAYE) will be waived for a period of six months from April to September for teachers in private schools earning up to 150,000 Rwandan francs net salary (about 161 U.S. dollars), a statement issued by the ministry said. The waiver will also apply for a period of three months from April to June for employees of companies operating in the tourism and hotel sector who earn up to 150,000 Rwandan francs net salary, the statement said. PAYE waiver lasts till September for teachers, and till June for everyone else. The government also exempted masks made in Rwanda to prevent COVID-19 spread from paying Value Added Tax (VAT).  https://web.archive.org/web/20200825035927/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-05/10/c_139045597.htm
notes_C2: Business must close by 18:00. Restaurants can offer take away service until 20:00.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210304095728/https://rw.usembassy.gov/health-alert-covid-19-information/
notes_H3: Rwanda confirmed its first case of coronavirus, an Indian citizen who arrived in the East African nation from Mumbai on March 8, according to the Health Ministry. Since then the World Health Organisation (WHO) has confirmed that the tracing of all contacts in Rwanda has been conducted for further management.       https://web.archive.org/web/20200430194341/https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-rwanda/rwanda-confirms-first-case-of-coronavirus-health-ministry-idUKKBN2110G0     https://web.archive.org/web/20200430194919/https://www.afro.who.int/countries/842/news?page=3
notes_E1: Full IMF statement: As of November 4, 2020 "Tax deferral and relief measures include the following: (i) suspension of down payments on outstanding tax for amicable settlement, (ii)softening of enforcement for tax arrears collection, (iii) extension of the deadline for filing and paying CIT, (iv) fast-tracking of VAT refunds to SMEs, (v) CIT and PIT payments based on current year transactions, (vi) PIT exemption for private school teachers and tourism and hotel employees earning less than RWF 150,000/month, and (vi) VAT exemption for locally produced masks."    Main impact on indicator is cash transfers to casual workers  https://web.archive.org/web/20200904183810/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  PIT exemption for private school teachers and tourism and hotel employees earning less than RWF 150,000/month - as per the update on 10th Sept 2020  https://web.archive.org/web/20200914124848/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C1: From 23-Feb-21 - All schools (public and private), including universities, will resume.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210304095728/https://rw.usembassy.gov/health-alert-covid-19-information/
notes_H7: A - Key workers via Covax  & C - Elderly groups - it doesn't say which type.   The vaccination is expected to be done in phases. In the first phase, the vaccine will go to front-line workers in healthcare including but not limited to those working in treatment centres and Intensive Care Units (ICUs). This phase will also see the vaccination of people above 65 and those whose immunity is weak and is likely to easily be compromised like those with cancer, diabetes, HIV and other serious diseases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210223001542/https://www.pmnewsnigeria.com/2021/02/15/rwanda-begins-covid-19-vaccination-for-health-workers-others/   https://web.archive.org/web/20210128052530/https://www.newtimes.co.rw/news/unpacking-rwanda-plan-distribute-covid-19-vaccine
notes_C3: Attendance at a wake/vigil (Ikiriyo) should not exceed 10 persons at any one time. Funeral gatherings should not exceed 30 persons.  Civil and religious weddings should not exceed 30 persons.  Traditional weddings and related receptions shall resume not exceeding 30 persons. However, when conducted in hotels/entertainment venues or open gardens they should not exceed 30% of venue capacity and COVID-19 testing will be required.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210615084833/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/rwanda/coronavirus
notes_C8: Everyone will be tested on arrival and must quarantine in a designated hotel for 24 hours pending the result. If staying longer than seven days, thereafter seven days quarantine at home.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210218085810/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-situation-in-kosovo.html
notes_C4: As of May 6th,Funeral gatherings should not exceed 30   Weeding gatherings should not exceed 30  http://web.archive.org/web/20210517202211/https://primature.gov.rw/index.php?id=2&no_cache=1&tx_drblob_pi1%5BdownloadUid%5D=870
notes_C6: Stay-at-home orders have been eased, although a night-time curfew remains in effect.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210210002042/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/rwanda-eases-covid-19-lockdown-in-capital/2137274
notes_H6: Masks/face coverings are required in public.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210304095728/https://rw.usembassy.gov/health-alert-covid-19-information/
notes_H8: Interpreted from C6 - curfews are currently in place
notes_C5: It appears that restrictions on public transport have been eased.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210210002042/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/rwanda-eases-covid-19-lockdown-in-capital/2137274

name: Saudi Arabia
notes_H1: The Ministry of Health conducts campaigns that target citizens and residents (in Arabic, English, Hindy, Tagalog, among others) reporting the number of cases and recommending people how to take preventative measures. https://web.archive.org/web/20200608033137/https://twitter.com/SaudiMOH/status/1244341052196163585
notes_H2: "The ministry highlighted that the new phase will not include COVID-19 examination inside houses or by visiting residences. Instead, the ministry will provide different outlets and options to conduct the tests. It will establish drive-through centers for testing people inside their cars in several cities while also offering testing services at primary health care centers, and allow citizens and residents to book appointments to collect their own test samples through an online application."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200608034049/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1677726/saudi-arabia
notes_C7: "There are currently no curfew or movement restrictions in effect within the country (...)"    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20200819124650/https://sa.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: Eligible people (social insurance beneficiaries, orphans and the disabled) were waived from paying rent for 3 months. https://web.archive.org/web/20200414205607/http://saudigazette.com.sa/article/591775/SAUDI-ARABIA/Social-insurance-beneficiaries-orphans-and-disabled-exempted-from-paying-rent-for-3-months
notes_C2: Authorities in Saudi Arabia will allow the resumption of indoor dining in restaurants and cafes, in addition to allowing cinemas, malls, and gyms to reopen on March 7. Establishments that remain open must implement enhanced COVID-19 sanitization procedures, perform temperature checks of employees and patrons, and comply with social distancing guidelines.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329220134/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/451796/saudi-arabia-authorities-to-lift-some-domestic-restrictions-nationwide-beginning-march-7-update-54
notes_H3: In February, the Saudi Center for Disease Prevention and control released a comprehensive set of Coronavirus Health Guidelines. The guidelines instruct the public health team or rapid response team to conduct a number of measures for a patient that has the virus, including filling out a contact tracing form (Appendix  3 in the guidelines) https://www.moh.gov.sa/CCC/healthp/regulations/Documents/Coronavirus%20Disease%202019%20Guidelines%20v1.1..pdf
notes_E1: Saudi Government has announced to pay 60% of the salaries of Saudi employees working in the Private sector for a period of three months with a ceiling of USD 2.39 billion. The Compensation will be paid in accordance with the conditions stipulated in the unemployment insurance system (SANID)  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221220947/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/saudi-arabia-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html
notes_C1: The Ministry of Education determined schools and universities would close to stop the spread of the virus. https://web.archive.org/web/20200608023056/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1638606/saudi-arabia
notes_H7: RIYADH: Saudi Arabia’s Ministry of Health announced it is expanding its coronavirus (COVID-19) inoculation campaign to reach a wider segment of society.  The ministry said that the registered priority groups have been covered and it will make vaccinations available to other groups.  There are plans to launch more vaccination centers across all regions of the Kingdom, with the cooperation of public and private health service providers.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210324213316/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1823451/saudi-arabia    More than seven million people have been vaccinated against the coronavirus disease in Saudi Arabia, the Ministry of Health announced on Sunday.  For more coronavirus news, visit our dedicated page.  Over 587 vaccination centers have opened across the Kingdom to ensure all citizens and residents have easy access to the dose, according to the ministry.    Last month, the Kingdom announced it would be expanding its national coronavirus vaccine campaign to include a much larger segment of its population.  The registered priority groups have all received their COVID-19 vaccines, which is why the ministry has now made the dose available to other groups of people.  Individuals who wish to be vaccinated must first register on the official Sehhaty application.  They can then book direct appointments according to the available dates and the nearest vaccination center, according to the health ministry.  “This step comes as a continuation of health efforts to preserve the safety of citizens and residents and limit the spread of COVID-19 and facilitate vaccination,” the health ministry had said at the time.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210418035700/https://english.alarabiya.net/coronavirus/2021/04/18/More-than-7-mln-people-in-Saudi-Arabia-received-COVID-19-vaccine-Ministry-
notes_C3: "Saudi Arabia suspended events in wedding halls, rest houses, event venues and in hotels, an official source in the Saudi Ministry of Interior announced on Friday"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200426202621/https://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/gulf/2020/03/13/Saudi-Arabia-suspends-events-in-wedding-halls-rest-houses-hotels
notes_C8: The announcement to resume travel on May 17th does not lift the previous ban on travelers coming from 9 countries. The full list of countries from which travel is suspended is as follows:  Argentina, Indonesia, Pakistan, Brazil, Turkey, South Africa, Lebanon, Egypt, and India. Saudi citizens, diplomats, health practitioners and their families are exempt from this restriction.    Travelers not arriving from the list of 9 countries are subject to a one-week institutional quarantine (at their own expense) in government-approved accommodation upon arrival to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210615081812/https://sa.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: "Saudi Arabia has allowed social events — including wedding receptions and other celebrations — to be held from Thursday, with up to 50 people, ensuring guests must wear face masks and abide by the social distancing protocol."    Source   https://web.archive.org/world/gulf/saudi/saudi-arabia-allows-social-events-weddings-with-up-to-50-people-1.1593635688372
notes_C6: Cannot find any government guidance that recommends to people to stay at home, including the source used for the previous 1G coding.
notes_H6: On 30 May, face masks become mandatory in public places. Non-compliance is fined with up to SR1,000 ($266).     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200831214012/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1686821/saudi-arabia
notes_H8: "????The Ministry of Health (MOH) pointed out that older persons come among the most vulnerable groups to Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) complications.        Through an infographic published on its Twitter page, MOH has advised household workers, who care for older persons, to adhere to a number of precautionary measures. They include wearing face masks while accompanying the elderly, washing hands before and after contact with them, maintaining physical distancing if there is no need to, not sharing personal tools with them, wearing face masks and gloves while providing personal hygiene for them, as well as disposing of their waste properly?."     http://web.archive.org/web/20210218114441/https://www.moh.gov.sa/en/Ministry/MediaCenter/News/Pages/News-2020-07-15-003.aspx
notes_C5: "Domestic air travel and travel within the country by bus, train, and other means of transportation has resumed (...)"    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20200819124650/https://sa.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

notes_H1: Due to Rising COVID cases, and Vaccine Role out there seems to be public awareness-raising campaign   http://web.archive.org/web/20210322143633/https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/covid-19-face-masks-in-sudan-s-workplaces-become-mandatory

""Last week, three women spoke with the BBC about their experiences of living in Sudan during the pandemic and explained that many people cannot afford tests or masks. This means that most COVID-19 patients are never tested and their infections remain unrecorded.""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503050555/https://www.facebook.com/FMOH.SUDAN/photos/a.2159000517706248/2883940198545606/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503050151/https://www.facebook.com/FMOH.SUDAN/photos/a.2159000517706248/2886407118298914    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503034231/https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/sudan-covid-19-cases-continue-to-rise-as-the-country-suspends-flights-from-india
notes_E1: Since February, the government has been introducing a donor-funded plan that aims to provide a temporary basic monthly income of $ 5 to 80% of its population of 43 million.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210507103310/https://www.reuters.com/world/africa/sudans-basic-income-scheme-aims-ease-economic-pain-2021-04-29/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210507104234/https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/sudan-officially-launches-samarat-family-support-programme
notes_C1: """All schools have been closed in Sudan’s El Gedaref state since yesterday and will remain shut until further notice. The state Ministry of Education said that this decision was because of a third wave of COVID-19 and recommended by the technical Committee for Health Emergencies.""  ""All primary and secondary schools in the localities of Port Sudan, Suakin, and Sinkat in the Red Sea state have been closed from the beginning of this month""  https://web.archive.org/web/20210503000843/https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/third-wave-of-covid-19-infections-in-sudan-shuts-schools-in-el-gedaref    https://web.archive.org/web/20210503023423/https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/sudan-s-3rd-covid-19-wave-continues
notes_H7: A,B,C: Oxford/Astrazeneca ,   https://archive.vn/dQsT6
notes_C3: Tawir said that the committee’s decisions on new measures include banning social events, and holding sports matches without an audience.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210521125406/https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/sudan-announces-several-new-measures-to-combat-covid-19
notes_C8: Effective May 20, 2021, the Sudanese Civil Aviation Authority prohibits entry of Sudanese and foreign passengers who originate from or transit through India or through any other country after having visited India in the past 14 days.  Effective May 20, 2021 the Sudanese Civil Aviation Authority requires passengers arriving from Egypt and Ethiopia to possess a certified negative PCR test dated within 72 hours of arrival. In addition, passengers will be subject to rapid COVID-19 testing upon arrival at the airport in Sudan.  Sudan can conduct COVID-19 tests domestically.   All passengers must possess a certified negative polymerise chain reaction (PCR) test certificate dated within 72 hours of arrival. Persons 6 years old and younger are exempt.  Effective immediately, the Sudanese Civil Aviation Authority requires passengers who originate from or transit through the UK, South Africa, and the Netherlands to possess a certified negative polymerase chain (PCR) reaction test certificate dated within 72 hours of arrival.  These passengers are subject to a mandatory 14-day home quarantine.    https://archive.vn/VnxYJ   https://archive.vn/QclWd
notes_C4: Tawir said that the committee’s decisions on new measures include the banning of public gatherings.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210521125406/https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/sudan-announces-several-new-measures-to-combat-covid-19
notes_C6: There is no curfew in place.  Effective September 16, 2020, the Higher Committee for Public Health Emergencies lifted the 6:00 p.m. – 6:00 a.m. curfew that had been in place for Khartoum since July 8, 2020.   Siddig Tawir, the acting chair of the COVID-19 Health Emergency Committee, announced several health measures to combat the spread of the coronavirus, including the suspension of studies in universities and schools for one month. The committee’s decisions on new measures include the banning of public gatherings, social events, and reducing the number of employees on working sites, holding sports matches without an audience, and adhering to the COVID-19 health requirements in places of worship.    https://archive.vn/hkX9u   https://archive.vn/QclWd
notes_H6: https://archive.vn/XtNqa   Face masks, disinfection, and social distancing are to become mandatory in Sudan’s state institutions, schools, public transport, and all gathering places subject to overcrowding, the Supreme Committee for Health Emergencies has said
notes_H8: People over sixty who suffer from chronic diseases (respiratory system, cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular disease) are more likely to develop severe complications from COVID-19 that’s why they are recommended to wear the mask and keep a distance of at least one meter from others and make sure to follow the preventive instructions.    https://archive.vn/2ctBN
notes_C5: Is public transportation operating? Yes.    Effective August 15, 2020, the Government of Sudan has allowed public transportation to operate between cities and states.  Intercity public transportation is available outside of curfew hours    https://web.archive.org/web/20200910223157/https://sd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Senegal
notes_H1: The president calls on religious authorities to support the government with adopted measures.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200518002240/http://www.sante.gouv.sn/Actualites/covid-19-les-decisions-de-son-execellence-monsieur-macky-sall-president-de-la-republique
notes_H2: "Individuals in Senegal may obtain COVID-19 testing at the following locations. The cost is FCFA 40,000 per test."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111200501/https://sn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: The motorways between the international airport and Thiès and between the airport and Mbour are closed between 8pm and 6am.    The Government of Senegal has advised that the airport will remain open and existing flight schedules will not change. People can still travel to the airport during curfew if they are passengers arriving and departing or the driver (no other people accompanying passengers are allowed). All of these people must carry a copy of their passport and plane ticket, which will allow for movement to the airport or to their accommodation. If you are arriving into Senegal at the airport in curfew hours, you should contact the person or taxi company you have arranged to collect you in advance to make sure they can still access the airport and have all the necessary paperwork.    There is currently no restriction on travel between regions, and authorisation is not needed to travel between regions. Internal flights have also restarted. Masks must be worn at all times in public areas and when travelling, including in a private car if there are two or more people in the car.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125055820/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/senegal/coronavirus
notes_E2: Previous note referred to this note    "One million households receive food aid (FCFA 69 billion) and utility payments for (for water and electricity) for poorer customers were suspended for a 2-month period (FCFA 18,5 billion)." name: Singapore
notes_H1: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/precautionary-measures-in-response-to-severe-pneumonia-cases-in-wuhan-china
notes_H2: "“As Singapore has made good progress to support a further resumption of activities, the Multi-Ministry Taskforce (MTF) will start Phase 3 of re-opening from 28 Dec 2020.  Update on pre-conditions for moving into Phase 3  To move into Phase 3, we needed:  (…) Sufficient testing capabilities for early detection and public health action: Singapore ramped up Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) test capacity significantly to be able to run over 50,000 tests a day. Antigen rapid tests were also introduced for larger and higher-risk events.”    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201231155002/https://www.gov.sg/article/moving-into-phase-3-of-re-opening-on-28-dec-2020
notes_C7: From June 19, Singapore has entered Phase Two of its COVID19 policy, where most sectors of the economy and most schools have reopened and public transport is operating. In a small city-state like Singapore, this effectively means internal movement is no longer restricted.     https://archive.vn/qVq8N
notes_E2: "The Act covers contracts for rentals in the industrial and commercial sectors, construction and supply contracts, as well as certain secured loan facilities granted by a bank or a finance company to small and medium-sized enterprises.  Contracts for events such as weddings or conferences, as well as in tourism, such as cruise and hotel bookings, are also covered."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201210010413/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/how-to-seek-contractual-relief-for-yourself-or-your-business-under-the-covid-19-temporary
notes_C2: Quote: ""We are asking the various companies to put in place the various measures and they will start to prepare now...As soon as they are ready by 12 May, they can resume work," Minister of Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing said at a virtual press conference on Sunday." "We will not be able to open some of the social entertainment outlets, but we are focused on our manufacturing capacities and production capabilities," he said.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210117171016/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2020/05/bf158de5d991-singapore-to-ease-lockdown-let-businesses-reopen-from-may-12.html
notes_H3: In update to public, Singapore MOH lays out strategy once case is confirmed:"Once a case is confirmed, contact tracing will be initiated, and we will implement strict isolation, quarantine, and infection control and prevention measures to prevent further transmission." Since this is clear indication of a contract tracing policy in place, coded as start date; https://web.archive.org/web/20200527191250/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/moh-steps-up-precautionary-measures-in-response-to-increase-in-cases-of-novel-coronavirus-pneumonia-in-wuhan
notes_E1: On 26 May, the government announced the Fortitude Budget. The Job Support Scheme (JSS) will be extended for 1 more month to cover wages in August 2020. For firms that cannot resume operations immediately after the circuit breaker, the Government will continue to provide wage support at 75% until August 2020, or when they are allowed to re-open (whichever is earlier). There will also be increased support for some affected sectors (eg. aerospace sector, retail, marine and offshore) - an increase from the previous 25% to either 50% or 75%.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200712075233/https://www.gov.sg/article/a-summary-of-the-fortitude-budget-2020
notes_C1: Due to a recent spike in covid cases in the community, Singapore has moved back into phase 2. The new variants that seem to be affecting minors are of particular concern as new clusters are forming in various educational institutions, including schools and tuition centres. In light of this, all schools have now moved into online classes (Home-based learning - HBL for short) from 19-28May 2021 (when the school term ends).    Although higher learning institutions such universities have more time to move into online classes, as this is course dependent, they are encouraged to do so as soon as possible and as much as possible.    **** Considering this, the code will be given to reflect this and there a "3" for all levels rather than a "2".  _________________  Quote (1):  "SINGAPORE - All schools will start full home-based learning (HBL) from Wednesday (May 19) until May 28 when the school term ends, amid a sharp spike in Covid-19 cases in the community.    This applies to all primary, secondary and junior college students, as well as those from Millennia Institute and special education schools."    "Institutes of higher learning will convert more classes to online learning where possible until June 13, when the current set of tightened measures end, or further notice, with the exception of essential in-person sessions such as labs, practicals and final-year projects."    Link (1):  https://web.archive.org/web/20210521073008/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/parenting-education/spore-schools-to-start-full-home-based-learning-from-may-19-amid-spike  _______________  Quote (2):  "SINGAPORE - Full home-based learning for schools will only start on Wednesday (May 19) as most schools will need a day or two to prepare, Education Minister Chan Chun Sing said on Sunday."    Link (2):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210521073216/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/full-home-based-learning-to-only-start-on-may-19-to-give-schools-time-to-prepare  _______________  Quote (3):  "SINGAPORE - All centre-based tuition and enrichment classes must move activities online till the end of Phase 2 (heightened alert) on June 13, or until further notice is given, Education Minister Chan Chun Sing announced on Sunday (May 16)."    Link (3):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210519112103mp_/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/tuition-enrichment-classes-must-move-online-till-june-13
notes_H7: Groups: Universal availability   Vaccines: Moderna, Pfizer-BioNTech    From the 11 June 2021, the last remaining group in the population, individuals aged 12-39 years oldare not able to register and book appointments for their Covid Vaccine jabs!  This brings the country to universal availability.   ________________________    Quote(1):  "Singapore residents aged 39 and below can now register for their vaccination. Singaporeans in this age group will be given a two-week priority window to book their appointments, before opening up to non-local residents who wish to be vaccinated."    Link (1):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614142648/https://www.gov.sg/features/covid-19-vaccination  ______________________    Quote (2):  "Updates on the Vaccination Programme    From 11 June 2021 onwards, the vaccination programme will be extended to the following groups:    1. Singapore Citizens Aged 12 to 39 Years Old    Singapore citizens aged 12-39 years old will be able to register online for their COVID-19 vaccinations from 11 June 2021 onwards. Children who turn 12 in 2021 must have crossed their birthday before they are eligible to book an appointment. Registration can be done at vaccine.gov.sg. An SMS with a personalised booking link will be sent to registrants progressively to invite them to book their appointments. Those who had registered their interest earlier will not need to register again. Parental Consent Required for Persons Below 18 Years Old. Those who are under the age of 18 will require the consent of their parent/guardian to book an appointment. The child will be required to bring along documentary proof of their consent to the vaccination site for verification. Parents/guardians of children/wards aged 13 and above are not required to accompany them to the vaccination site on the day of vaccination, However, children/wards aged 12 will need to be accompanied by a parent or guardian.      2. Individuals who have recovered from an earlier infection    Individuals who have recovered from an earlier COVID-19 infection are recommended to receive a single dose of vaccine. Evidence has indicated that a single dose would further boost their immunity against COVID-19. Individuals who had an earlier COVID-19 infection from over six months ago will be prioritised for the single-dose vaccination, as recovered individuals who have had infection within the past six months are likely to still have a strong immune response that has not faded. Eligible persons will be able to register from 11 June 2021 onwards, if they are part of a population group that is already eligible for vaccination. Vaccination remains a key enabler in keeping our community safe. Those who are medically eligible are strongly encouraged to be vaccinated when it is offered to you. For more information, click here for MOH's press release."    Link (2):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614143540/https://www.gov.sg/article/covid-19-vaccination-extended-to-singapore-citizens-aged-12-to-39  ___________________    Quote (3):  "SINGAPORE: Singapore citizens aged 12 to 39 can register online for their COVID-19 vaccinations from Friday (Jun 11), the Ministry of Health (MOH) announced on Thursday.  "This is a big group of 1.5 million people who have yet to be vaccinated," Health Minister Ong Ye Kung said at a COVID-19 multi-ministry task force press conference on Thursday."    Link (3):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614142642/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/covid-19-vaccination-age-12-to-39-recovered-single-dose-14986126    __________________    Quote (4):  "SINGAPORE - More than 30,000 people will soon be invited to register for a Covid-19 vaccination after restrictions stopping people with a history of severe allergic reactions from getting the jabs were lifted, said Health Minister Ong Ye Kung on Tuesday (June 8)."    Link (4):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210614143824/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/more-than-30k-people-in-singapore-with-history-of-severe-allergies-to-get-invite-to  _________________    ***please also refer to notes dated 05 June 2021:  Groups: A,B,C + others  Vaccines: Moderna, Pfizer-BioNTech  ________________    Coding has not changed for for coding period of 01-05 June, even though the addition of a 4th group has been made (B- Clinically vulnerable groups (non elderly).     Other brands of vaccines which are WHO-approved for emergency-use are available in Singapore; however, they are not provided free of charge through the government scheme and may only be obtained through the private sector under a special program called the Special Access Route (SAR).    Cancer patients on active treatment are now able to obtain the free government provided Covid vaccines. Pregnant women are also not able to obtain the vaccines if they want to - although for these women, the age group roll out phases still apply, i.e. those 39 and below will only be able to start registering their interests from mid-June.    Due to recent spikes in educational institutions, Covid vaccines drives for school aged children between the ages of 12-17 years have begun on June 1. This is also following the recent approval of the use of these vaccines in the same group.    Individuals who have a medical history of allergic reactions are also now able to obtain the vaccines; however, those with a medical history of allergic reactions to other vaccines are still not allowed to be vaccinated with the covid vaccine (this sub-group of individuals might be allowed the vaccine before the end of the year, pending further expert reviews of the vaccine)     A recent announcement was also made to focus on the first dose of the vaccine so that a greater number of people can be vaccinated with at least the first dose as the government continues to work on its vaccine supply chain.    According to the age group roll out phases, a coding change for H7 should be happening in the coming weeks.  ________________________________  Quote (1):  "Covid-19 vaccination exercise for S'pore students to begin June 1; those 39 and below can register from mid-June.    SINGAPORE - Students will be able to book appointments to receive the Covid-19 vaccine from Tuesday (June 1), Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced on Monday. PM Lee noted that there have been more cases of children getting infected in schools and tuition centres in Singapore's latest outbreak - which has left parents "naturally worried" although no serious illnesses have been recorded. "Therefore, we will take full advantage of the June holidays to vaccinate students," he said. Priority will be given to students sitting for their O-, N- and A-level examinations, as well as special needs students. Next, students 12 years and above will take their turn, including those in institutions of higher learning, said PM Lee. Vaccination of those aged 40 to 44 is currently under way, along with a recently announced move to prioritise first-dose vaccinations."    Link (1):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210605062212/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/politics/covid-19-vaccination-exercise-for-spore-students-to-begin-june-1-those-39-and  ___________________________________    Quote (2):  "S'pore delays 2nd Covid-19 vaccine dose to 6-8 weeks later; those aged 40-44 can register for jabs from Wednesday    SINGAPORE - Singapore has tweaked its vaccination strategy to protect more residents faster. From Wednesday (May 19), those who register for Covid-19 vaccination will have their second dose scheduled six to eight weeks after the first, instead of three to four weeks later. The nationwide vaccination roll-out will also be expanded to those aged 40 to 44 from Wednesday, said Health Minister Ong Ye Kung."    Link (2):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210602042331/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/spore-delays-2nd-vaccine-dose-to-6-8-weeks-later-those-aged-40-44-can-register-for-jabs  ___________________________________    Quote (3):  "SINGAPORE - Over 9,000 students booked appointments to receive their Covid-19 jabs on Thursday (June 3) as the national vaccination drive for more than 400,000 students kicked off.  Since Tuesday, students taking their N, O, and A-level examinations as well as those in polytechnics or their first year of junior college have been invited to take the vaccine.     "For now, only those aged 12 and above as at June 1 can be vaccinated. The national effort aims to keep educational institutions and the community safe. Those aged between 12 and 17 can take only the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, while those aged 18 and above can opt for either the Pfizer or the Moderna jab."    "On Tuesday, the first day students were invited to book their Covid-19 vaccination slots, more than half of the 52,000 parents or students who received SMSes to sign up did so. Over the next two weeks, invitations for jabs will be extended to other full-time students, including those in madrasahs and special education (Sped) schools. Eligible students will continue to be notified through SMS until June 13, said Mr Chan.'    "The entire vaccination exercise for students - which includes full-time students in continuing education and training programmes, such as those enrolled in master's programmes - is estimated to be completed by August. Vaccinations are available at community clubs islandwide and will soon begin at four dedicated Ministry of Education vaccination centres from next Monday."    Link (3):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210605062947/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/covid-19-vaccination-drive-for-400000-students-aged-12-and-above-kicks-off  ______________________________    Quote (4):  "Pregnant women, cancer patients on active treatment can get Covid-19 jabs. SINGAPORE - Pregnant women and cancer patients on active treatment are among the sub-groups of individuals that can also be vaccinated, said the multi-ministry task force (MTF) in an update on Monday (May 31). Pregnant women will be able to register and book a vaccination appointment from Friday if they are part of the population group eligible for vaccination."    "Meanwhile, cancer patients on active treatment can also be vaccinated, MTF said. But they should do so in a hospital setting, after assessment by their treating specialists on their suitability. Active treatment includes chemotherapy, immunotherapy or radiation therapy that individuals have undergone in the past three months or plan to undergo in the next two months.Under the current guidelines, cancer patients on hormonal therapy can continue to be vaccinated at any available vaccination site. MTF said: "Cancer patients on active cancer treatment remain a vulnerable population that is at an increased risk of complications from Covid-19."    "Additionally, those with severe cutaneous adverse reactions, which are rare drug-induced disorders, can also receive the vaccine. Such reactions include the Stevens-Johnson Syndrome - a rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes; toxic epidermal necrolysis - a reaction where the skin blisters and peels, and can be life threatening; and severe hypersensitivity and rash."    Link (4):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210605063318/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/pregnant-women-can-register-for-covid-19-jabs-from-june-4-cancer-patients-on-active  _______________________________________    Quote (5):  "SINGAPORE - Individuals with a history of anaphylaxis and allergic reactions to other drugs, food, insect stings or unknown triggers can now be vaccinated with mRNA vaccines, the Ministry of Health (MOH) said on Friday (June 4). The expert committee on Covid-19 vaccination had recommended allowing this group of people to take mRNA vaccines after careful study of data both globally and locally. This restriction will be removed from Saturday (June 5). A large majority of the 32,000 people here who have not been able to take the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna mRNA vaccines because of medical reasons will now be able to do so under the national programme, MOH said. But a minority with a history of anaphylaxis or allergic reactions to other vaccines will still not be eligible. Another 2,000 people who developed allergic reactions after receiving the first dose of an mRNA Covid-19 vaccine should not receive an mRNA-based vaccine again, the ministry added. MOH said it is evaluating and will bring in non-mRNA vaccines which are more suited to these individuals. It expects to do so before the end of the year after the vaccines are approved by the Health Sciences Authority (HSA)."    Link (5):  http://web.archive.org/web/20210605063653/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/health/moh-lifts-covid-19-mrna-vaccine-restrictions-on-those-with-allergies-to-food-or  _____________________________    Quote (6):  "SINGAPORE is making a wider range of Covid-19 vaccines available through the private sector to enhance flexibility and vaccine coverage of the population. This is on top of the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines, which rely on messenger ribonucleic acid (mRNA) technology and are being used in the national vaccine drive. The Ministry of Health (MOH) will now also allow Covid-19 vaccines that are approved for emergency use by the World Health Organisation (WHO), it said on Monday. Besides Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna, the WHO has also green-lit the AstraZeneca, Johnson & Johnson, Sinopharm and Indian Covishield vaccines. But individuals who want to take these shots will do so at their own cost and risk - in contrast with the official vaccine roll-out, which is free for all long-term residents. The government will not subsidise vaccines given under the Special Access Route (SAR), and those who get such vaccines are not eligible for the scheme that grants one-time goodwill financial assistance for serious vaccine side effects. The MOH noted that "there has been interest to access alternate vaccines used in other countries", especially for those with medical conditions, such as pregnancy or life-threatening allergies; these individuals were previously excluded from the two mRNA vaccines. "However, there have either been no applications for approval of these alternate vaccines in Singapore, or evaluation is still ongoing," it added, referring to the vaccine, which is not yet approved by the Health Sciences Authority. The authorities will therefore let WHO-approved emergency-use vaccine brands be used by private healthcare providers under the SAR, for as long as the pandemic lasts."    Link (6):  http://archive.today/2021.06.05-064307/https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/government-economy/singapore-residents-can-get-wider-range-of-covid-19-vaccines-from-private-clinics

This includes reviewing visitor management and testing policies at the nursing homes, welfare homes, sheltered homes and adult disability homes. As at Thursday noon, the facility in Hougang for adults with intellectual disabilities has 27 cases." name: San Marino
notes_H1: Covid-19 hotline active since February 25. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200226181438/https://www.sanmarinortv.sm/news/italia-c7/coronavirus-anziani-vittime-del-virus-e-degli-sciacalli-e-r-attiva-numero-verde-a184161 // Official information also available in  http://web.archive.org/web/20200606125109/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home.html
notes_H2: voluntary testing is suspended to give priority to contact tracing  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110184644/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49121874.html
notes_C7: No new policies, no movement restriction.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210510191327/https://www.visitsanmarino.com/en/visitnews/Informazioni-utili-COVID-19.html
notes_E2: The key measures approved by the government include: i) suspension of payment deadlines for government tax and non-tax obligations, utility bills, and other dues to provide liquidity to the private sector; ii) temporary freeze of all non-essential government spending and reduction in public sector wage bill to redirect spending to the health sector; and iii) extension of supplemental wage scheme to support workers displaced by COVID-19 containment measures; iv) deferral of income tax payment; v)minimum guaranteed income for poorer households; vi) other measures to support businesses, including tax credits, tax payments postponement and rescheduling. Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200729163904/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C2: from April 19th in public markets, businesses selling goods different from food, can re-open  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426165746/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49124053.html
notes_H3: "In San Marino there is an event-based surveillance system in place and the country has the ability to quickly enhance current surveillance (this enhancement is in place for Covid-19) and the specific case and contact definitions and other criteria for investigation have been added to the system." Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200507173122/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/sanmarino/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.3%20Isolation%20and%20quarantine&Type=Chapter
notes_E1: "Viene introdotto, "dal 1° marzo 2020 e fino alla data di cessazione della emergenza sanitaria", il reddito minimo garantito per le famiglie, "già costituiti alla data del 1° marzo 2020, anche se composti da una persona sola, che si trovano in stato di difficoltà economica e con insufficienti mezzi di sostentamento". L'importo erogato alle famiglie bisognose sarà di 580 euro mensili per ogni nucleo familiare, maggiorato di 150 euro per il coniuge o per il convivente more uxorio o per il contraente l’unione civile, e di 50 euro per ogni altro convivente del nucleo familiare." Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200606125817/http://www.libertas.sm/notizie/2020/04/22/san-marino-coronavirus-decreto-a-favore-di-imprese-operatori-lavoratori-e-famiglie.html
notes_C1: Since April 12th all schools, all levels can be in presence  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426165746/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49124053.html
notes_H7: Vaccinations in phase 1 were covering healthcare workers, elderly people and clinically vulnerable groups.  since April 9th vaccinations to people above 50 years old are now possible  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426180514/https://vaccinocovid.iss.sm/vaccinazione-anticovid-estesa-a%20tutta%20la%20popolazionev
notes_C3: Art. 7(Provisions on museums, theaters and cinemas and events in general)1.Theaters, museums, libraries and places of culture are open to the public, which mustbe arranged by occupying the seats, where provided, alternately for each row, alin order to ensure compliance with the distances, with the exception of those belonging to the same nucleus ascohabitants and those who are vaccinated.2.In museums, libraries and other places of culture, access and use musttake place according to the prescriptions of the ISS Prevention Department and of the Civil Protection.3.Events, including sports, parties, shows and events are allowedof entertainment carried out in public and private places both outdoors and indoors in compliance with theguidelines defined in specific Regulations adopted by the State Congress on the proposal ofPrevention Department of the Social Security and Civil Protection Institute and issued byRegency.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210510202311/http://www.esteri.sm/on-line/en/home/right-banners/information-covid-19.html
notes_C8: Entryinto the Republic of San Marino, for those who come from countries other than Italy and Vatican City, or who have stayed outside these two countries in the previous 14 days, is allowed against the presentation of a special certificate certifying the negativity to the coronavirus, through molecular buffer subposition in the 48 hours before entering the territory, or of a special certificate of anti-SARS-CoV-2 vaccination.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210201155314/http://www.esteri.sm/on-line/home/link/informazioni-per-chi-viaggia.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222091520/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/san-marino/coronavirus
notes_C4: Gatherings (Groups over 10 people where social distancing cannot be maintained) in public or private places are strictly forbidden.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210607135647/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/san-marino/coronavirus
notes_C6: curfews have been removed since April 26th  https://web.archive.org/web/20210426165746/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49124053.html
notes_H6: It is mandatory to wear the mask correctly, both outdoors and indoors,except in cases where:a) either alone or together with his or her group of cohabitants;b) the exemption from using the mask is expressly provided for.The use of parafiato plexiglass visors is not allowed.    2. As of June 7, 2021, the use of the mask outdoors is highly recommended.  It remains the obligation of its correct use in indoor premises with the exceptions referred to in paragraph 1,letters a) and b).    3.The following are not subject to the obligation referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2:a) children under the age of six;b) subjects with forms of disability not compatible with the continuous use of the mask and isubjects who interact with the aforementioned;c) vaccinated subjects.    4.Vaccinated private and public sector workers are exempted from the obligation to use the mask    http://web.archive.org/web/20210510202311/http://www.esteri.sm/on-line/en/home/right-banners/information-covid-19.html
